Title: Jiwaka Leaders Call For Action As Writs Return Date Looms
Content:
Community leaders from wards within the Anglimp and Kuna Komun Local Level Governments (LLGs) of Jiwaka province are calling on the PNG Electoral Commission (PNGEC) to conduct their delayed elections before the deadline of November 21st.
Their appeal follows a recent letter from the Minister for Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs, Soroi Eoe, addressed to the PNG Electoral Commissioner. In the letter, Minister Eoe concurred with the Electoral Commissioner’s request for an extension of the deadline for the return of writs for some LLGs due to special circumstances, citing Sections 277(2)(b) and 288(2) of the Organic Law on Provincial and Local-level Governments.
The Minister explained that while many LLGs across the country have progressed well, some experienced delays due to various issues and require additional time to complete their elections. He however, advised the Electoral Commissioner to return the writs for the completed LLGs to his office on November 21, 2025.
Councilors Peter Saina, Joe Win an Kerewa Mekenti of Anglimp and Kuna Komun are now urging the PNGEC and Jiwaka’s Election Manager to proceed with the elections without further delay. They are also calling for the return of the official writs by the end of next week to ensure timely completion.
The delays for these LLGs were initially caused by confusion surrounding the creation of new wards. However, leaders have confirmed that the new wards for Anglimp and Kuna Komun are legal and have followed all required procedures. They also emphasized that no court orders prevent them from voting.
The creation of the new LLGs—Anglimp, Kuna Komun, and Kambia—was approved by the Provincial and Local Government Affairs Office to support the upcoming split of Anglim South Waghi into two separate electorates in 2027. While the Kambia LLG elections have already progressed and declarations have been made, only Anglimp and Kuna Komun remain delayed.
The community leaders are firm in their stance that these the election for these two LLGs should proceed to ensure they exercise their democratic rights to choose their leaders.

Title: SHMS Multipurpose Hall Unveiled
Content:
The School of Medicine and Health Sciences at the University of Papua New Guinea opened its new multi-purpose school hall yesterday.
The school is on its way to becoming the new University of Medicine and Health Sciences after Parliament passed the legislation last month, enabling its inception. The multipurpose hall is the first of several buildings in the project’s phase 1 plan.
Prime Minister James Marape when officiating at the event thanked those who have worked hard to bring about this infrastructure development.
“I want to thank the University of PNG and Chancellor, Sir Robert Igara, and the Executive Dean of the Medical Faculty, Prof. Nakapi Tefuarani, for working very hard to make this small but important milestone and a pointer, a moment in our nation’s history to remind us of what can be done if we work together in the direction we must take travelling forward,” said Prime Minister Marape.
Highlighting the need for SMHS to be granted a stand-alone university of its own, the Prime Minister set a timeline on when he wants the institution to be fully functional.
“UPNG, let this campus go. This country needs its own medical university. The statistics is compelling – the doctor-to-patient ratio in Papua New Guinea is among the lowest in the world. For 10 million people, we now need up to 10,000 doctors to be on par with world levels.
“This is why it is of the utmost importance to get this university up at the earliest, and I give to you our government’s fullest commitment to getting this university up as soon as possible.
Before we step out into the 2030’s, this campus must be fully functional to meet the needs of our country going forward.
“We hope as we set up the new university, enrolment increases, vacancies are filled, and we get to employ enough doctors in the country and send doctors and medical practitioners out to our region.”
The Prime Minister said he sees the strong value of having the medical university independent of the University of PNG and functioning symbiotically with the Port Moresby General Hospital – both because of their physical location next to each other and professionally because of the relationship of the work they do.
He said his government is determined to upgrade PMGH to a Level 7 status hospital as it develops the new university to its highest potential.
“Port Moresby General Hospital is in a symbiosis with this university. Our government will invest heavily in the cancer facility and soon we will open this facility which will be the best cancer treatment facility in the Pacific, comparable to Australian standards.
We have stepped up on the heart facility. We witnessed the first heart bypass in 50 years. And I witnessed the first two successful kidney transplant, another first for our country.
“Our government will keep investing in PMGH to take it to a Level 7, fully-run specialist hospital as well as embracing general duties for the rest of the country.
“Utilising latest technology, this university will train highly qualified Papua New Guineans to serve all the needs in our country,” said PM Marape.
The University of Medicine and Health Sciences project is a national project. It began after an NEC decision was taken in 2017 but delayed when the former UPNG council went to court challenging the decision to stop the splitting of UPNG.
Project restarted after Sir Robert took chancellorship of UPNG and Prime Minister Marape resumed the momentum to install a separate university that would concentrate on producing doctors and medical practitioners to fill the wide gap in the health sector in the country.
It is estimated it will take up to three years to get the new university functioning from completion of all building infrastructure to transferring the administrative functions from UPNG, and taking enrolments.

Title: ‘You can be billionaires’, small-scale miners told
Content:
Small-scale miners in Papua New Guinea have the potential to become billionaires if they make sound investment decisions, diversify into other businesses, and manage their earnings responsibly.
Managing Director of Mineral Resources Authority (MRA) Jerry Garry. made these remarks in Wau on Thursday, November 13, during celebrations marking the 15th anniversary of MRA’s Small-Scale Mining Training Center (SSMTC).
About 3,000 people including miners, Wau locals, and stakeholders gathered to commemorate the milestone.
In his address, Mr Garry shared a motivational story about Placer Dome, one of the world’s largest gold mining companies, which began its journey, mining alluvial gold in Wau.
Historical records show that in 1926, two expatriates—an Australian and a New Zealander—discovered abundant gold resources in Wau-Bulolo. They established Placer Development Proprietary Limited, raised funds, and purchased eight dredging machines to mine the Wau-Bulolo goldfields. Importantly, they did not limit themselves to gold mining, they diversified into cattle farming, fishing, and forestry. The pine trees harvested today by PNG Forest Products in the Wau-Bulolo area were first introduced by these men as part of their diversification strategy.
After more than five decades, Placer Development Proprietary Limited acquired a mining license to operate the Porgera mine. The company later merged with Dome to form Placer Dome. By 2005, Placer Dome operated 16 gold mines across seven countries and had a market capitalization of USD 6.7 billion.
The MD encouraged miners to follow this example, stressing that with wise investments and careful management of profits, they too could become billionaires.

Title: Nipa Kutubu DDA Upholds Tax Compliance
Content:
With the Internal Revenue Commission’s presence now visible in Southern Highlands, tax collection efforts have been made easier.
IRC received a GST Withholding Section 65A payment of K3,330,011.57 from the Nipa-Kutubu District Development Authority (NK DDA) on Friday, 14 November.
Provincial IRC Manager of Southern Highlands, George Nathan acknowledged the payment as a strong demonstration of leadership, accountability, and commitment to tax compliance.
“This timely payment reflects the district’s responsible financial management and its dedication to supporting national revenue mobilization,” said Mr. Nathan.
Mr. Nathan emphasized the importance of GST Withholding (Section 65A), reminding all Withholders to deduct the mandatory 10% GST and lodge and remit payments by the 21st of every month.
He further commended the NK DDA for their transparency and swift response to IRC’s reminders, noting that such actions contribute meaningfully to rebuilding and restoring the Southern Highlands Province.
Special appreciation was also extended to Defense Minister and Member for Nipa-Kutubu Electorate, Dr. Billy Joseph, for his continued stewardship and support.

Title: Kwikila Secondary graduates told to be contributors to development
Content:
Kwikila Secondary School in Rigo District of Central Province marked its 23rd Grade 12 Graduation Ceremony on Thursday, 13 November 2025, celebrating the milestone of the graduating class while reflecting on the growth and success of the school since its establishment as a high school in the 60s.
The invited keynote speaker, Member for Rigo and Minister for National Planning, Sir Ano Pala, was unable to attend due to ministerial commitments but was represented by his second secretary, Charles Amini, who extended Sir Ano’s heartfelt congratulations to all graduands on behalf of the Member.
In his prepared remarks, Sir Ano reflected on his own journey as a former student of Kwikila High School, recalling his graduation in 1969, and how his experiences there shaped the path he later pursued in public service.
He emphasized the importance of responsibility and contribution.
“You all have a role to play in our society depending on how serious you take your role as a contributor. Not only to Rigo but to Central Province, to Papua New Guinea and even to the rest of the world.”
He further reminded the graduates of Rigo’s legacy of producing exceptional leaders.
“Rigo has produced Chief Justices, Judges, State Ministers, Police Commissioners, Defence Brigadier Generals, Departmental Heads, Clerks of Parliament, Heads of Missions, Sporting icons, to name a few. One of you can aspire to hold one of these positions and carry on this fine tradition. Congratulations to the class of 2025.”
As part of his support for education, Sir Ano awarded laptops and WiFi devices to the dux of the three streams—Science, Social Science, and Business Studies.
The runner-up dux recipients were each presented with a tablet device, a gesture underscoring his commitment to empowering young leaders with tools for success in the digital age.

Title: Nangu Chef wins “Yumi Stap Wanatim” SME Award
Content:
The Australian Government has recognised the ingenuity, resilience and contribution of Papua New Guinea’s micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) at the annual PNG SME Awards.
This year, the PNG SME Awards marked the introduction of the inaugural Yumi Stap Wantaim Award, sponsored by the Australian Government through the PNG–Australia Partnership. The award is designed to celebrate SMEs in Papua New Guinea that demonstrate strong business growth and resilience – in terms of turnover, market share, and profitability – and also exemplify the values of partnership, community engagement, and service. This award comprises a value of PGK15,000: a cash prize of PGK5,000 and PGK10,000 in tailored business development support.
Australian High Commission representative, Acting Minister Counsellor Richelle Turner, presented the award to Chef Nicky Pohonhelan.
Mr Pohonhelan is the owner of Nangu Chef Catering and was recognised for his achievement of successfully expanding from a solo operator to a team of five, including three dedicated kitchen hands. Nangu Chef Catering celebrates Papua New Guinean cuisine’s diverse flavours.
In her remarks, Acting Minister Counsellor Richelle Turner spoke to the important role SMEs play and the contribution they make to Papua New Guinea’s economy.
“Papua New Guinea’s small and medium enterprises contribute to a dynamic and inclusive economy by driving innovation and excellence every day. The annual SME Awards night places a spotlight on the contribution businesses of all sizes make,” she said.
In accepting the Yumi Stap Wantaim Award, Mr Pohonhelan, thanked the Australian Government.
“As an SME out there, right now I’m thinking of what kind of stove am I going to get, what kind of oven am I going to get. I appreciate the Australian Government for giving me this opportunity to basically wonder how else I can grow my business, because there has been plans, but the issue was finance,” he said.
Australia continues to supports Papua New Guinea’s MSME sector through initiatives that provide business training, access to finance, and practical support including:
•	the largest-ever survey of PNG’s MSME sector, with over 2,600 businesses across 21 provinces sharing insights to inform responsive programs;
•	the EmployAbility initiative that places jobseekers with disabilities in roles across Information and Communications Technology (ICT), Human Resource (HR), administration and sign language training; and
•	providing support to the Lily Magazine Homemade Business Competition to showcase innovative micro and small businesses.
These efforts align with Papua New Guinea’s Medium Term Development Plan IV, which recognises the importance of SMEs in building a strong and diversified economy.
The Australian Government remains committed to supporting Papua New Guinea’s entrepreneurs and strengthening the SME sector as a cornerstone of inclusive and sustainable economic growth.

Title: PNG Chief Censor Raises Alarm Over AI 'Theft' of Local Music
Content:
Chief Censor of the Office of Censorship of Papua New Guinea, Jim Abani, has raised an alarming issue: the unauthorized transformation of PNG's local, authentic music into Artificial Intelligence (AI) versions. Mr. Abani warns that this practice constitutes a significant copyright breach and is "draining the future" of the country’s music industry.
The alleged copyright breaches emerged this year, with familiar songs from veteran artists being remixed and distributed as AI-generated tracks. It has come to the attention of Mr. Abani’s office that original music created and sung by Papua New Guinea's local artists has been transformed by unknown creators into AI versions.
According to Mr. Abani, this practice is a breach of copyright laws because the AI output is "substantially similar" to the original works. He stated that local artists face a genuine threat to their artistic products going forward.
Mr. Abani emphasized the importance of preserving the country's artistic integrity, adding that all original content including videos, music, and other creative products must remain authentic to promote PNG's genuine artistic identity.
Familiar local songs already being transformed into AI versions include "Madang" by Demas Saul and "Asua" by Edwin Baffe.
To combat this growing threat of copyright infringement, Mr. Abani strongly advocates for an "all-of-government approach" as the only viable way to assist local artists.
“I strongly believe that an all-of-government approach is the only way that we can assist our local artists. Regulating AI music in Papua New Guinea requires a phased approach,” he stated.
He identified key strategies to help local artists and called on relevant agencies to act:
•	Copyright Law Review: "If it is outdated, we need to review that."
•	Licensing and Royalties: "We have to establish this licensing so that they can benefit those music artists.

Title: Forest body urged to implement ban of round logs
Content:
Environment NGO, ACT NOW PNG doubts the National Forest Authority’s ability to implement the Prime Minister’s commitment to end the export of round logs by 2025.
ACT NOW Campaign Manager Eddie Tanago while congratulating the PM for his declaration, outlined instances in the past where NFA has not implemented decisions made by previous governments.
“The PNG Forest Authority has an appalling record when it comes to following the law and implementing government policy” says Eddie Tanago.
“The Prime Minister’s reputation and the reputation of our nation is now on the line, as the whole world will be watching to see if the promise is upheld.”
In 1991, the new Forestry Act which created the PNGFA, replaced the concept of the Timber Rights Purchase and Local Forest Area with a new type of logging licence, the Forest Management Agreement. Yet over thirty years later, less than 15% of log exports come from FMA areas and the TRP and LFA still dominate the sector.
The government’s Vision 2050 banned log exports from 2010, a ban that was endorsed by the then Prime Minster, Peter O’Neill in 2008. Yet in 2010 log export volumes reached record highs and in 2015 PNG became the world’s largest exporter of tropical logs.
In 2018, the O’Neill government promised log exports would end by 2020; a pledge that was repeated by the new Marape government in in 2020, Prime Minister Marape made a new pledge that there would be no new export licences issued but within two years, twenty new export logging projects had started up.
Then, in Nov 2022, the National Forest Board imposed a moratorium on the issuing of new Forest Clearing Authorities.
Yet in 2023 and 2024 there were five new FCA projects that started log exports.
Eddie Tanago says he hope his pessimism is proved wrong and that the PNG Forest Authority can step up and break the cycle of history by ensuring there are no exports of round logs from January 2026.
“Hopefully now is the time the Forest Authority can show a different face and ensure the Prime Minister’s promise to the world is fulfilled”, says Tanago.

Title: Police presence continues in LLG elections
Content:
Police will continue their support towards the Local Level Government Elections, ensuring that the polling and counting are completed successfully, says the Police Commissioner David Manning.
Manning stated that, despite isolated challenges, particularly in the Highlands region, police will maintain their presence and support the Electoral Commission in conducting the election.
“There have been isolated incidents in the upper highlands, and there have been ongoing tribal fights that have impacted the smooth running of LLG elections in certain districts and electorates.
We will continue to support the electoral commission, ensuring that the democratic process is completed, which does present its challenges as well.
“Mainly, Southern Highlands and Enga have continued to pose significant challenges for us and the electoral commission, but this is electoral commission business; we are just supporting with security. We will advise the electoral commission on whether or not the environment is conducive to safely running the election and make the call to discontinue polling in any part of the country if the environment is not conducive,” he said.
The commissioner further urged everyone to follow the democratic process of voting and refrain from conflicts.

Title: PNG Develops Inclusive Agriculture Policy
Content:
Papua New Guinea is developing its first-ever National Women and Youth in Agriculture Policy (2025–2035), with support from the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) through the EU-STREIT PNG Programme. The policy aims to place women and youth at the centre of agriculture and agribusiness, ensuring equal access to land, finance, markets and services.
The first regional consultation held in Wewak brought together farmers, cooperatives, NGOs, church groups and private sector representatives from East Sepik, West Sepik and Madang provinces to validate findings and include voices from women, youths and persons with disabilities.
Deputy Secretary for DAL’s Policy Division, Francis Daink, said stakeholder ownership is vital, adding that DAL will coordinate and provide secretarial support to a high-level advisory body led by women and youth.
FAO’s Patu Shang said the consultation unites voices to address key challenges: “Without this policy, we risk losing more years of opportunities to strengthen our economy and empower our people.”
Ali Said Yesuf, EU-STREIT PNG Coordinator, emphasized that implementation must tackle real barriers and include a strong monitoring framework. The policy supports PNG Vision 2050 and aims to unlock the full potential of women and youth in agriculture.

Title: Biliau Primary School commended
Content:
The Board of Management and the teaching staff of Biliau primary school in the Raicoast district of Madang province have been applauded for their efforts, leading to the completion of an impressive double classroom project within schedule and budget.
Governor for Madang, Ramsey Pariwa, praised the school during the official opening of the new learning facility which was funded by the Madang Provincial Government at a cost of K100, 000 through the Provincial Services Improvement Program (PSIP) fund.
Pariwa was impressed as funding for this project was only released mid this year to a number of schools to assist in infrastructure projects such as classrooms and teachers houses but most are yet to complete theirs.
"Biliau is the third school to have successfully completed its classroom project upon receiving funding and I want to thank the head teacher, the school board and the contractor for working together in collaboration," Pariwa said.
"That's the way it should be. We should put our differences aside and work together hand in hand to see productive results not only in education but also in other sectors,” he added.
Madang Education Advisor, Alphonse Igag outlined how his office is driving policies set out by the provincial government.
"We at the Madang Provincial Education Division and the Administration are happy that the Governor is pushing for us to come up with proper systems and ways which the government and the administration is supposed to run in the province," Mr. Igag said.
Mr. Igag urged the teaching staff, the board and students to look after school infrastructure whilst encouraging parents and teachers to set standards and ethical values in the school and community and be role models to the students to see positive change going forward.
Head Teacher Siloi Dimas, when presenting a brief report of the project completion, thanked Governor Pariwa for the support, adding that the school looks forward to working alongside the Madang Provincial Administration to deliver more projects.

Title: EC seeks approval for Dei & NIP by-elections
Content:
Electoral Commissioner, Simon Sinai has written to the Governor General, Grand Chief Sir Bob Dadae seeking approval for the by-elections for New Ireland Provincial seat and Dei open seat in Western Highlands Province.
“It is my great pleasure to submit to you under Section 106 of the Constitution the by-election dates for the Dei Open Electorate and New Ireland Provincial.
“I therefore seek your concurrence, and approval for the election program to be confirmed as follows:
1.	Issue of Writs – Thursday November 27, 2025
2.	Close of Nomination – Thursday December 04, 2025
3.	Commencement of Polling – Saturday January 03, 2026
4.	End of Polling – Monday January 19, 2026
5.	Return of Writs On or Before – Monday February 08, 2026.
“My office will inform the people of Dei and New Irland as soon as you approve the by-election program.”
Mr Sinai stated that preparation will begin as soon as the Governor General approve the dates.
Both seats were left vacant after the elected MPs passed on.

Title: East Sepik UOG students await repatriation
Content:
Close to 300 East Sepik students from the University of Goroka, are waiting in Lae for arrangements to be made for their return home.
The students reached Lae on Tuesday evening, and were accommodated at the Lae Secondary School.
Classes at UOG were suspended for two weeks following an incident at Ato Market, in Goroka, between a student and a group of intoxicated locals, sparking a confrontation that started on Saturday, November 8th, 2025, and continued to Sunday morning, ending at around 4pm.
The University of Goroka’s Yangoru-Saussia student association president, Sebron Yembihahu, outlined that aside from injuries and damages to property, students were traumatised and had to leave campus for fear of their safety.
This is not the first time students have been attacked by locals, hence, while waiting for word from their provincial administration, the East Sepik students followed their Morobean counterparts to Lae.
“We arrived in Morobe last night (November 11th),” said Yembihahu. “The first group arrived at 7pm and the second group arrived around 10pm.
“We were catered for here at the Lae Secondary School, where we spent the night.
“From Lae secondary, they have relocated us and we will be moving to Bugandi Secondary School, where we will remain there until Sunday, when we should be heading back to East Sepik Province.”
The second-year bachelor of science student drew attention to the fact that they were into their second week of examinations when the incident happened.
The university confirmed that approximately 75 percent of examinations have already been completed, with the remaining 25 percent to be conducted online in two weeks’ time for Years 1 to 3 students.
“The vice chancellor said we are going to do our exams online, through Google classroom and the date for the examinations is 24th-29th November. During that time, all students will go online and do their remaining exams.”
Meantime, Governor Allan Bird said the East Sepik Provincial Government is grateful to Lae MP, John Rosso, Morobe leaders and the people of Morobe for their assistance in moving their students to Lae.
Governor Bird confirmed that a representative from his office will be in Lae to coordinate the repatriation of students home as soon as possible.

Title: Simbu UOG Students Return Home Safely
Content:
The Simbu Provincial Government has stepped in to ensure the safety of its students at the University of Goroka (UOG) following the recent unrest on campus. Led by the Division of Education Principal Advisor, Bevwek Kutne, a rescue team travelled to Eastern Highlands on Monday with K10,000 in financial assistance, three coaster buses, and two Hino Dyna trucks to evacuate Simbu students.
The operation, organised by Governor Noah Kool and Provincial Administrator John Punde, demonstrated swift leadership and concern for students’ welfare. The funds were officially handed over by Mrs. Kutne to Simbu Student President, Kewe Kiwai, in the presence of all Simbu students at UOG.
After waiting for the UOG management’s official decision, which announced a two-week suspension, the students departed Goroka at midnight under police escort, arriving safely in Kundiawa at 2 a.m.
Mrs. Kutne said education remains Simbu’s greatest contribution to the nation.
“Simbu may not bring much revenue to the government, but our human resource is our strongest weapon,” she stated. “We are here for our students and their safety.”

Title: Ok Tedi Supports UPNG Law Students
Content:
Ok Tedi Mining Limited (Ok Tedi) has once again demonstrated its commitment to supporting the education of Papua New Guinea’s future leaders by sponsoring the 36th Moot Court Competition at the UPNG Law School.
The grand finals of the Moot Court competition were held on September 4th at UPNG’s main campus, showcasing the courtroom skills of law students as they prepared to become the country’s next legal practitioners.
Prizes for the grand finalists and consolation prizes for participants were sponsored by Ok Tedi and presented during the Law Students Society Closing Program on October 2nd.
Speaking at the event, Ok Tedi Manager Government and External Relations, Martin Paining, highlighted the company’s long-standing investment in education and training. “As a 100% PNG owned company, Ok Tedi is honoured to support the education of our future leaders. Our K159 million investment from 1981 to 2024 spans scholarships, apprenticeships, graduate programs, and trade training across institutions including UPNG, PNG University of Technology, and Divine Word University,” he said.
Mr Paining also noted that 98 percent of Ok Tedi’s workforce are Papua New Guinean, with 18 percent female representation, reflecting the company’s commitment to local talent and gender diversity.
He acknowledged UPNG’s role in producing some of PNG’s finest legal minds, including those now working within Ok Tedi’s Legal and Contracts divisions.
As PNG celebrates 50 years of independence, Ok Tedi continues to play a key role in shaping the nation’s future through education and leadership development.

Title: Doctors Bring Health Services to YUS
Content:
The Tree Kangaroo Conservation Program (TKCP) has welcomed seven international doctors and health professionals from the United States to Papua New Guinea’s YUS Conservation Area this week, marking another milestone under its One Health program.
The visiting team will spend a week in YUS providing vital medical education, health checks, and community awareness sessions focused on improving the wellbeing of rural communities. This year’s visit, coordinated by TKCP’s One Health Partnerships Coordinator Roseylita Opa, focuses on maternal and physical health, with specialists in obstetrics, gynaecology, and physiotherapy joining the mission.
“The doctors aim to strengthen local health capacity, support Village Birth Attendants, and promote healthy living through the One Health approach,” said Ms Opa. “Community health workers and midwives will attend workshops on safe pregnancy and childbirth, reproductive health, nutrition, and common illness prevention.”
Founded by Dr. Lisa Dabek, TKCP’s One Health program links the health of people, wildlife, and the environment — promoting clean water, balanced nutrition, and food security. Dr. Dabek, who is travelling with the team, said the program ensures that conservation also benefits people’s lives.
“These remote communities are in desperate need of government medical care,” Dr. Dabek said. “We care equally about the villagers, tree kangaroos, and the environment.”
For the first time, TKCP has coordinated with both the Madang and Morobe Provincial Health Authorities and is preparing to sign a Memorandum of Understanding to strengthen long-term government health support to YUS.

Title: Bureaucratic red tape blamed for slow release of funds to MaPHA
Content:
The Parliamentary Advisory Committee on Health has been told that a K15 million funding for Madang Provincial Health Authority has been sitting in Waigani for more than two years pending approvals.
MaPHA Chief Executive Officer, Martin Daimen revealed this when asked by the advisory committee why this money has not been utilized while health infrastructure in the province deteriorate.
The Committee conducted a two-day inquiry in Madang this week and took an interest in the K15 million currently sitting in the MaPHA trust account and has not been accessed in the last two years.
Chairman of the Committee and Member for Bogia, Robert Naguri led the inquiry, taking the MaPHA CEO to task over the delay in drawing these funds.
The CEO in explaining the delay, outlined the process involved in accessing this money. He said in order to access the funding, MaPHA had to submit its plans for vetting and deliberation to the Project Steering Committee which is made up of Treasury, National Planning and the Prime Ministers departments. He revealed that MaPHA has been waiting ever since the submission as the PSC keeps deferring.
In response, Naguri said, "This is not good enough, we think we are doing the right thing, but we are not. In the process of waiting, lives are lost, and we keep moving backward. We've got to move forward and deliver the best patient care and service to the people, that is our primary role," Mr. Naguri emphasized.
Appalled by this process, Naguri said he would personally pay a visit to the Ministers for Health and National Planning and ask them to release the money immediately.
As a level 5 hospital, Mr. Naguri stated that the infrastructure and environment of the hospital is not conducive and it is disheartening to see that there is no proper emergency building as the former building is still under construction and currently a ward is being used for emergency cases with patients scattered around waiting to be attended to.
Toilets are closed with only one ablution block containing four bathrooms and toilets for males and females each, currently being used for the entire hospital.
The morgue chillers are in need of maintenance with dead bodies kept refrigerated containers at freezing temperatures.
Another serious concern raised by the Committee affirming the need of K15 million was that most of the infrastructures still had the toxic asbestos, which needs to be changed immediately.
The inquiry is an extension from Morobe's Angau Memorial Hospital last week.

Title: Goilala Teachers gain skills in inclusive and effective teaching
Content:
More than 86 teachers from Goilala in Central Province have strengthened their skills and confidence in the classroom.
A recent training led by the Central Provincial Division of Education, in collaboration with the Catholic Diocese of Bereina, National Department of Education and Australian funded Partnerships for Improving Education program, showed them the importance of including every child in teaching and learning.
Kanansio Kito, the teacher-in-charge at Kerau Primary School, who has been teaching there for 14 years, says it opened his eyes to drawing on policies more efffectively.
“Before this session, I did not know much about GESI and WASH. I am now ready to implement these new policies,” Mr Kito said.
For Francis Paru, who has taught in Kivori Primary School for 11 years, the training was transformative.
“The training showed me how to maintain a safe and hygienic environment for both school and community”.
Mr Paru also highlighted that the policies provided practical strategies for preventing the spread of illness and promoting equal participation in class, to ensure every student has the opportunity to learn.
The policy in-service supported by Australia’s Partnerships for Improving Education program has reached over 700 teachers and almost 100 trainers, who are education officials. It has not only equipped teachers with critical knowledge and skills but also empowered them to champion inclusive and safe education practices, in some of Papua New Guinea’s most remote schools.
As these educators return to their classrooms, they are determined to share what they have learnt, to foster equity, and to nurture the potential of every student.

Title: Sonoma WNB Students Return Home
Content:
Fourteen self-sponsored students from West New Britain Province studying at Sonoma Adventist College have safely returned home.
The students were met and welcomed in Kimbe by Acting Deputy Provincial Administrator for Social Services, John Sitapai, who assured families that the provincial government remains committed to helping all students affected by the situation.
He said the government has also begun repatriating 260 students from the University of Goroka (UOG), who were caught up in the same unrest.
Mr. Sitapai said arrangements are being made to move the UOG students from Goroka to Lae, where they will be flown home with the support of Air Niugini and local leaders.
He thanked the West New Britain administration, Governor’s Office, and other provincial leaders for working together to ensure the safety of all students.
Student spokesperson Benedict Diden expressed heartfelt gratitude, saying the students felt fear and uncertainty but were comforted by the government’s swift response.
“The government of West New Britain rescued us from the chaos,” Diden said. “You gave us a second chance at life. We promise to study hard and help rebuild our province.”
The West New Britain Provincial Government continues to monitor and assist all students from the province studying in other parts of Papua New Guinea to ensure their safety and wellbeing.

Title: UOG SRC Calls for Security Fencing and Dorm Repairs
Content:
The University Council of the University of Goroka (UOG) has resolved to commission an independent investigation to establish the real cause of the continuous disturbances caused by members of the surrounding communities.
According to a statement released from the Vice Chancellors office, it stated that repeated conflicts and disruptions have caused instability and great fear among the students and staff, even resulting in several deaths.
Vice Chancellor Dr. Teng Waninga (PhD), whilst informing the National Government, the Department of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology, parents, guardians, sponsors, and the general public, said the recent clash was stressful and undermined the main focus of providing quality teacher trainings program in a more secure and peaceful environment.
The students, through their Student Representative Council, appealed to the National Government, local members, and the top management to give immediate attention and priority in funding a permanent perimeter fencing, construction of additional dormitories and maintenance of damaged dormitories for student lodging. They appealed to have those safety measures in place before the commencement of 2026 academic year so as to avoid further confrontations in future.
Students have been living in the surrounding communities after dormitories were damaged during an earthquake in 2022.
Around 51 students were reportedly injured during the fighting and received medical attention at the Goroka General Hospital. Most of them have since been discharged while five students remain in critical but stable condition.
It was also reported that several staff houses were destroyed and personal valuables stolen. The Vice Chancellor stated that the university will provide financial assistance to staff who were affected.
Police from Simbu and Western Highlands are currently providing security and maintaining stability in and around the campus and will remain there imdefinitely.
"On behalf of the council, top management team, staff, students and sponsors, I would like to pass my sincere gratitude to Kinoka Feo, Robert Atiyafa, and local leaders and the Okiufa community who assisted in bringing normalcy to the University. We also appreciate the police minister and Commissioner for arranging mobile squad members to provide security on campus. We also thank the Defense Force from Igam Barracks who dispersed the crowd and took control of the situation. We also thank the Governors and elected leaders for funding transportation of students to their various destination," stated the VC.

Title: Police Reservist charged in shooting of surrendering suspect
Content:
A 35-year-old police reservist attached to Lorengau police has been arrested and charged with shooting an eighteen-year-old boy after he surrendered to him on June 2, 2025.
Assistant Commissioner of Police for Crimes, Hodges Ette confirmed that the reservist, who was formally charged with one count of murder on October 27, is now waiting for his court date.
ACP Ette stated he was arrested and charged by the Criminal Investigation Unit police officers from Port Moresby, who flew to Manus after his office was notified of the crime committed.
According to the police brief, it was alleged that between 5 and 6pm on that date, the deceased identified as 18-year-old Mausen Popress, was with his two friends at Ward 6, Lorengau Urban LLG, Manus Province. He stated that the deceased, according to police was a person of interest who had committed several crimes in Manus and was on the run, hiding from police.
ACP Ette said the police officers, including the reservist, were informed that afternoon that he was at Ward 6 when they went there to apprehend him. He said when the police officers surrounded him and his two friends, the three were told to sleep on the floor and surrender to the police. He said they all complied.
"After the three surrendered, he was shot by the reservist, who was then transported to the hospital. He was pronounced dead the next day, June 3, 2025. A formal complaint was sent to my office, and I assigned officers who traveled to Manus to make the arrest. We must be careful when we do our job as police officers. You cannot shoot people when they surrender. This is wrong," ACP Ette said.
The police reservist is detained in a cell and will appear in court when his court dates are set.

Title: Remembering PNG’s Role in WWI and Beyond
Content:
On Tuesday 11th of November, an Armistice Day commemoration ceremony was held at Bomana War Cemetery in Port Moresby.
Armistice Day, also known as Remembrance Day, commemorates the end of the Great War (World War I), the signing of the Armistice. The ceremony included a minute's silence at 11am, marking the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month of 1918, the moment when guns fell silent across the Western Front and the war ended.
Armistice Day pays respect to those who lost their lives in all wars and conflicts.
In his Armistice address, Australian High Commissioner to Papua New Guinea and Special Envoy to the Pacific, Ewen McDonald, spoke to the significance of Papua New Guinea in WWI for Australian soldiers.
He said “perhaps the most familiar names linking war and Papua New Guinea (PNG) to Australians are the Kokoda trail and the Coral Sea from the Second World War. However, New Guinea was the site of the first Australian battles and deaths in the Great War.”
New Guinea was the site of Australia’s first successful combat action in WWI, resulting in the taking of an enemy occupied radio station in Rabaul, East New Britain.
Visiting Australian Defence Force Chaplain Lieutenant Colonel Michael Folland recited 'In Flanders fields', a poem which speaks of the red poppies, the first plants that sprouted from the devastation of the battlefields of northern France and Belgium. The Flanders poppy has become the flower of remembrance worn on Armistice Day.
The commemoration ceremony was attended by visiting Commander of the 1st (Australian) Division, Major General Ashley Collingburn, Australian Defence Adviser Colonel Nicholas Trotter, and several diplomatic and Defence representatives.

Title: Lone woman Councilor in Kutubu LLG
Content:
Susan Mike has become the only female to be elected as councilor representing the Dikei Ward in the Kutubu LLG.
Originally from Nipa, Susan is married to a Kutubu man and has retained her seat, earning her second term in office.
She expressed gratitude for the support from her community, attributing her successful re-election to her leadership and the positive impact she has made during her first term.
“People have voted me again because of my leadership. Although am not from Kutubu area, I have committed to serve the people and they have spoken through their votes and gave me this mandate for another term,” she told TVWAN News.
Mrs. Mike also acknowledged the contributions of John Pipi Kila, the President of Kutubu LLG, over the past five years.
“President John Pipi Kila’s leadership has changed Kutubu for the past five years. No presidents has implemented impact projects in Kutubu until president Kila got elected as the president. I will support him in his leadership and pledge to work with him going forward.”
She further expressed her commitment to working collaboratively with him and the newly elected councilors to continue advancing the needs and aspirations of her constituents.

Title: 29 arrested in Erima fight
Content:
About 29 men have been arrested and are now detained at the Six Mile Police Station in relation to a fight that broke out between two groups of men, alleged to be from Tari, under the Erima Flyover Bridge today.
National Capital District Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab said the men will be interrogated and charged accordingly. He thanked the police units for their quick response in arriving at the scene to stop the armed men who were destroying the market under the flyover.
According to information provided to the police, it was a retaliatory fight between a group of men from Tari, Hela province, who fought among themselves at Nine Mile on Tuesday, November 11.
"The group from Nine Mile retaliated because one of their members was injured in the fight yesterday. When they reached Erima, they started destroying markets, prompting the police to be alerted. The police responded and arrested about 31 individuals, including two community leaders, who were released to return and identify those who are still on the run. The suspects will be profiled, interrogated, and charged accordingly," Metsupt Simatab said.
He said the police will work as a team to address such issues to ensure order in the city.
Metsupt. Simatab stated that retaliatory fights must not occur because there are avenues to resolve conflicts. He emphasised that police stations, village courts, community leaders, and parents are available to help solve issues.
NCD Police has urged the public not to take the law into their own hands and instill fear among city residents.

Title: Perpetrators in UOG unrest to be held accountable: DPM
Content:
Those responsible for instigating or participating in the University of Goroka unrest will be dealt with and will face the full brunt of PNG’s criminal laws.
Lae MP and Deputy Prime Minister Rosso, John Rosso, made this clear after busloads of students were evacuated from the UOG campus yesterday following the violent confrontation between students and locals over the weekend.
“Investigations are currently underway to ascertain the cause of the disturbances and to ensure that those involved are held accountable,” said DPM Rosso.
“I have been assured by the police and the university administration that investigations are progressing, and the full force of our criminal laws will be applied to those responsible, once the facts are established.
“The University of Goroka is a Government institution and the National Government will take all necessary measures to protect the institution, its infrastructure, its staff and students.”
Deputy Prime Minister Rosso has further assured the nation, particularly parents, students, and staff of UOG, that the Government is taking all necessary measures to maintain safety and restore order following recent unrest on campus.
Additional security personnel have been deployed and are now stationed at the university to ensure the safety and wellbeing of all students and staff.
“The safety of our students is paramount. The Government, through the Minister for Higher Education, Kinoka Feo, the Eastern Highlands Provincial Administration, police, and the university’s leadership, are working together to stabilise the situation and ensure all students return home safely.”
Meantime, the UOG Senate and Council have made the difficult decision to send students home before the closure of the 2025 academic year. They are working closely with the Department of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (DHERST) to manage the situation responsibly and transparently.
Under the current arrangements:
•	All classes have been suspended as of November 11.
•	Students may begin travelling back to their home provinces.
•	Approximately 75 percent of examinations have already been completed, with the remaining 25 percent to be conducted online in two weeks for Years 1 to 3 students.
•	Final year students will return in two weeks to submit their final-year projects.

Title: Gov’t and Civil Society Unite in Brazil to push for Climate Justice at COP30
Content:
Papua New Guinea is making its presence felt at COP30 in Brazil, with both government leaders and civil society groups calling for urgent, community-driven climate action rooted in Indigenous leadership and rainforest protection.
The main COP30 negotiations run from 10 to 21 November, with PNG’s team actively participating in high-level talks and side events.
“Our forests are not just carbon sinks - they are homes, heritage, and hope for our people,” said Environment Minister Simo Kilepa, who joined the delegation alongside Forest Minister Salio Waipo, Northern Governor Gary Juffa, and senior officials from CCDA and CEPA.
At the same time, PNG’s leading civil society organizations - under the Papua New Guinea Environment Alliance (PNGEA) - issued a powerful joint statement demanding climate justice that centers Indigenous rights, ethical finance, and transparent governance.
“This is a collective voice for the people of PNG,” said PNGEA Coordinator Pamela Avusi. “We are calling for climate justice that is rooted in the practical realities of our local communities.”
Key Demands and Diplomatic Priorities include,
- Indigenous Peoples as equal decision-makers in climate finance, not just beneficiaries
- Full operationalization of the Loss and Damage Fund, with grant-based, accessible support for frontline communities
- Stricter safeguards against corporate greenwashing in carbon markets
- Transparent governance of climate funds through PNG’s Biodiversity & Climate Fund
- Increased benefit-sharing for rural forest stewards
- Alignment with Brazil’s bottom-up model of community-led energy and forest transitions
With 97% of PNG’s land under customary ownership, both government and civil society are emphasizing the role of ancestral knowledge in shaping climate solutions.
The government allocated K2 million for travel and logistics, part of a K3 million COP30 budget, with support from development partners.
As COP30 enters its second week, PNG’s unified front - across state and civil society - underscores a growing demand for inclusive, rights-based, and locally led climate action on the world .

Title: Basic Emergency Care training in ENB
Content:
The East New Britain Provincial Health Authority (ENB PHA) is hosting a series of Basic Emergency Care (BEC) courses from the 5th to the 13th November 2025 for emergency care clinicians and frontline clinicians at St Mary’s Vunapope Hospital in Kokopo.
This training comprises two BEC provider courses and one training-of-trainers (ToT) course.
The BEC course was developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) in collaboration with the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and the International Federation for Emergency Medicine (IFEM). It is designed for first contact providers of emergency care in resource constrained settings and provides a safe and structured approach to managing acutely ill and injured patients.
PNG facilitators from Rabaul, Mendi and Port Moresby, are leading the BEC courses involving over 30 participants and facilitators from three different provinces.
There will be more new master trainers and registered facilitators following the completion of this training. They will be certified to deliver BEC training to first responders and clinicians throughout East New Britain.
The ENB PHA will receive two Laerdal Emergency Learning Laboratory equipment packs, which has been kindly donated by Laerdal Global Health with each containing enough equipment to deliver a 10-person BEC course to continue to train and upskill local first contact clinicians and responders.
These courses are being delivered as part of the Regional Emergency and Critical Care Systems Strengthening Initiative (RECSI), which is supported by the Australian Government through Partnerships for a Healthy Region (PHR). It has also been actively supported by RECSI’s implementing partner for Papua New Guinea – National St John Ambulance PNG – along with the ENB PHA.
This training program is contributing to the World Health Organization’s 25 x 25 Basic Emergency Care Saves Lives campaign, which was launched by the World Health Organization in 2023.
Dr Ignatius Bolokon from the Emergency Department of Rabaul Provincial Hospital, said it is a great opportunity to host BEC course training in East New Britain Province, an opportunity to train their own staff.
“It is such an important course to improve the quality of emergency care services from the Emergency Department at the Provincial Hospital to the local health centres out in the peripheries. Most of the participants are coming from the peripheral health facilities and this course provides the training necessary for them to deliver better emergency care where they are in the rural remote places.
The BEC course is sustainable for us as we will have 10 new BEC trainers trained and we will continue to run this course to build the capacity of emergency care services in the province,” Dr. Bolokon said.

Title: Busloads of UOG students reach Lae
Content:
Hundreds of students traveled to Lae yesterday evening from the University of Goroka, in Eastern Highlands Province.
This follows the violent clash over the weekend between UOG students and locals, resulting in over 50 injuries and extensive damages to properties and vehicles.
Around five vehicles left Lae in the early hours of Tuesday (November 11th) morning, and met up with an additional number of buses in Goroka after the suspension of classes was announced on the evening of Monday, November 10th.
Morobe had 26 25-seater buses that reached Lae, while East Sepik students, who were estimated to be over 300, used four 25-seater buses, 13 Toyota Hiace 15-seaters, and two Hino trucks.
The students were warmly welcomed into Lae by the Morobe Provincial Administration, Lae City Authority and staff from the Lae and Bugandi secondary schools.
Additional buses were made available, free of charge, to assist students from other provinces transiting through Lae on their way home.
Among the group were four students from the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, nine from Manus, two from West New Britain and a few from the Southern region as well.
Arrangements were also made in consultation with the principals of Bugandi Secondary School and Lae Secondary School to provide free accommodation and meals for transiting students from other provinces.
“I sincerely thank Mr. Dennis Miall of Bugandi and Mr. Christopher Raymond of Lae Secondary for their leadership and compassion in assisting our young people during this difficult time,” said Lae MP and Deputy Prime Minister, John Rosso.
Students from other provinces who may be transiting through Lae will be supported through the same arrangements until their respective provincial governments or parents organise onward transport home.
Deputy Prime Minister Rosso also thanked Lae City residents who have already reached out to offer support to the affected students.

Title: No Alcohol Policy in tertiary institutions imminent
Content:
Following the clash between students and locals at the University of Goroka that has now led to the suspension of classes, Prime Minister James Marape has directed the Minister for Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology to explore a “No Alcohol Policy” for students in tertiary institutions across the country.
He appealed for discipline, responsibility, and respect for education in the nation’s tertiary institutions, following recent incidents of student unrest and alcohol-related disturbances at several Campuses.
“Students must focus on their studies. There is time for social life after graduation,” he said. “We want our universities to produce disciplined, ethical graduates who can lead our nation.”
The Prime Minister said the behaviour of a few should not compromise the future of many.
“I apologise to the innocent students, parents, and sponsors affected by these incidents,” Prime Minister Marape said.
“Our universities are places for learning and leadership — not disorder.”
He confirmed that the Government is investing over K100 million in Infrastructure at the University of Goroka, with plans to fence and secure the Campus in next year’s Budget to enhance safety and discipline.
Prime Minister Marape appealed to local communities surrounding universities to cooperate with authorities in maintaining peace and security.
“The University of Goroka has been a pillar of education for over 50 years,” he said.
“I call on local tribes and residents to continue supporting the institution and its students. The local community around the University was very hospitable in the past for so long. Lately it is being noted that there are settlements growing around the north Goroka area. I call on those who have settled into Goroka to live like the way Eastern Highlanders or Goroka people do.”
He added that the government will work with  university councils to strengthen student welfare, safety, and discipline, including online learning alternatives where necessary to ensure continuity of study.
“We are proud of our education system and will protect it,” Marape said. “Education is the key to nation-building, and our youth must take this privilege seriously.”
The Prime Minister concluded by reminding all students and citizens that discipline and moral responsibility are the foundations of national progress.
“Papua New Guinea’s future depends on the character of its young people,” he said. “Let us raise a generation that values respect, hard work, and purpose.”

Title: Government bans round log export
Content:
No new round log export licences will be issued after 2025. Prime Minister James Marape revealed this yesterday upon arrival from the COP30 Climate Conference in Brazil.
He reaffirmed his government’s policy to end the export of round logs by 2025 and promote sustainable downstream processing to add value to Papua New Guinea’s forestry sector.
“Our commitment to phase out the issuance of Round Log Export Licences by 2025 remains firm,” Prime Minister Marape said.
“We are now moving towards processing Timber within the country to generate more local employment, stimulate manufacturing, and promote conservation.”
In order to implement this, cabinet has already approved the establishment of PNG Diwai Limited, a state entity mandated to take up to 30 percent of all logs harvested in Papua New Guinea.
This agency will ensure that logs are retained and processed domestically or marketed responsibly under the Forestry Act.
“This policy is not about chasing away investors,” Marape explained. “It is about ensuring that logging operations are conducted sustainably, are environmentally compliant, and that Papua New Guineans share equitably in the benefits.”
This move is consistent with PNG’s climate commitments made at COP30, where the country advocated for the protection of 70 percent of its forests and the establishment of a global financial mechanism to reward forest conservation.
“If we have not shut down fossil fuels, then we must plant or conserve a tree,” he reiterated. “The conservation and sustainable management of forests is the lifeline for our planet.”
Prime Minister Marape called on all forestry companies and industry stakeholders to cooperate with the government in this transition.
He will convene a National Forestry Forum before the end of the year to engage all industry participants on the implementation roadmap for downstream processing.
“The forestry sector has harvested enough over the years,” he said. “Now we must move forward together—industry, government, and landowners—to ensure our forest resources generate wealth for the people while preserving the environment for generations to come.”
Future permits for round logs will require in-country processing or participation in forest conservation and Carbon Credit initiatives.
“This Policy is a moral, environmental, and economic obligation,” Marape said. “Papua New Guinea will lead by example as a responsible Rainforest Nation that values both its trees and its people.”

Title: Police work in AROB boosted
Content:
Law and order in Bougainville has been strengthened following the launch of the Bougainville Police Infrastructure Project (BPIP).
New police stations in Arawa and Buin, as well as upgrades to Buka Police Station will be done under BPIP.
The works, originally valued at PGK 27.5 million and funded under the Australia-Papua New Guinea Bilateral Security Agreement or BSA, align with ABG’s plans to rehabilitate and develop public infrastructure for the delivery of more effective law and justice services.
At the launch, Australian High Commission Minister Counsellor Madeleine Moss said that the funding and resulting infrastructure will lead to better policing outcomes in ABG.
“Australia is pleased to provide this funding to significantly upgrade police station infrastructure in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville. Australia’s funding is part of our long-standing commitment to work with the Government of PNG and the ABG to strengthen security and law and order,” she said.
Australia’s investment in police infrastructure complements investments by Papua New Guinea and New Zealand.
Chief Secretary to the Government of Papua New Guinea, Ivan Pomaleu, announced that the Government of PNG will provide an additional PGK 5 million to police housing.
Pomaleu said that this additional investment was putting more police on the beat in Bougainville.
“The project is timely and aligns with the ABG's plans to rehabilitate and develop public infrastructure for the delivery of more effective law and justice services,” he said.
He also acknowledged the important role of the Minister for Police and Regional Member for Bougainville,  Peter Tsiamalili Jnr. as a key member of the PNG negotiating team for the Bilateral Security Agreement and supporting funding for this project.
New Zealand Deputy High Commissioner Charlie Gillard also announced New Zealand’s intention to refurbish the Police Training Centre in Buka.
The launch was officiated by Chief Secretary to the Autonomous Bougainville Government Kearnneth Nanei and Francis Tokura, Deputy Commissioner and Chief of Bougainville Police.
This investment in modern, purpose-built facilities will enable the Bougainville Police Service to deliver more effective, responsive, and community-focused policing; contributing to better law and justice outcomes for the people of Bougainville.

Title: Lae extends hospitality to transiting UOG students
Content:
A convoy of PMV buses and police escorts from Lae are in Goroka, Eastern Highlands Province, to transport not just Morobe students but also those who will be transiting through Lae.
The Morobe Provincial Administration, in collaboration with Lae MP and Deputy Prime Minister, John Rosso, have provided additional buses to assist students from other provinces as well.
Around five vehicles left Lae in the early hours of this morning, and met up with an additional number of buses in Goroka.
The decision was finalised after the University of Goroka (UOG) announced the suspension of classes yesterday evening (November 10th, 2025), following the brutal confrontation between students and locals over the weekend.
“All other students from other provinces who need to travel to Lae to leave for their provinces, we will provide land transport and security to Lae,” assured Rosso.
“You are all welcome to join Morobe students.”
The transiting students will be accomodated and catered to, free of charge, at the Lae and Bugandi secondary schools.
Lae residents have been encouraged to extend the hospitality to the students as well.

Title: EU funds local scholars in Environment Conservation
Content:
The European Union through the France Expertise Groupe AFD is sponsoring Papua New Guinean scholars to study different species and aspects of the Environment and its inhabitants for a Masters Degree after two years. The project is funding 21 scholars who are at different stages of their Masters Degree studies.
The programme which started last year is funded under the EU-Forestry Climate Change & Bio-Diversity (EU-FCCB). Each scholar is granted a total of K100,000 per student to study for two years. This funding covers everything from tuition to travels, research and stipend. It is awarded according to a set of criteria including eligibility to study in one of the selected local universities in the country.
The advantage of this scholarship programme is that the scholars don’t need to go far to do their research for the thesis. They do it right here at home because everything they need to study is here including the universities that they are to affiliate to.
During the week of celebrating the green Diplomacy, we had the opportunity to meet three of the students who won scholarship under this programme and they were able to share with us their unique and interesting background. All three were at different stages of the journey into their Masters studies.
Morison Garth who hails from Markham in Morobe and Manus is doing his first year in Master of Philosophy at the Pacific Adventist University.
“The scholarship came out early this year, we all applied for it. I was actually working for some years in the field, I saw this scholarship coming out on Facebook so I told myself that I’ll give it a try, so I applied and then I got selected, out of 130 applicants they only selected 21 of us,  and I was one of them.”
The requirement was to submit a proposal addressing the criteria for the application. Absalom submitted a proposal on micro-plastics along the Motuan Coastline with a plan to study the micro-plastics contaminants in mussels, clamshells, and oysters. He won the scholarship with his prospect changed when he went into the jungles in Madang and encountered the deep and untouched virgin forest.
“We went to Madang for one-month tropical ecology training. All of us went there, it was an exciting, interesting programme. So, we spent a whole one month there. First week we were at Nagada Binatang Research Centre doing a statistics course for Masters students. Statistics is tools to analyze data,” said Absalom.
After that the scholars spent two weeks right in the jungle in the Usino-Bundi district where there is no mobile coverage and no roads – only the sound of birds and insects chirping.
“I think we were lost in the jungle but we were really deep in training, doing ecological studies. In groups the scholars studied different animals, birds and insects like beetles and butterflies and plants.” He added.
Absalom drew inspiration for his final topic for research from comparing the untouched virgin forest to a logging site. Going up in a 45 metres canopy crane, a rare type of machine in the country, they were able to see the whole canopy of the jungle where he could see the gaps left behind by logging.
“When I was up there, I was looking down on the forest and I saw so many beautiful things but then I realized one thing, that there were so many gaps.”
There were nine local landowners who decided to put their forest into conservation in the Usino-Bundi district to preserve their forest. They decided not to allow logging on their land.
“Literally you cannot destroy any trees or plants there because all the trees are numbered. After going in there and observing two different scenarios; logging and conservation and this really made my mind. I must do something on the forest health, so I changed my research. So, I am now studying ‘Forest Conservation’ and I’m studying butterfly as bio-indictors for forest disturbances,” said Absalom.
Absalom is enrolled at the Pacific Adventist University and is looking forward to tackling the second year of master studies.
Plans are in place by EU to introduce this program in the field of Forestry and Environment Conservation because there are none in the country yet.

Title: Police contain Kupiano conflict
Content:
Quick response by police officers from the Central Provincial Police Command has helped contain the fight at Kupiano station in Abau, Central Province today, following a LLG election counting dispute at the station.
Central Provincial Police Commander Chief Inspector Joseph Salle confirmed that the situation at Kupiano station is now under control, and police are currently obtaining information regarding how the fight started, which led to an old man being seriously injured.
PPC Salle stated that Kupiano police officers were quick to respond and despite limited manpower, they managed to contain the situation.
"Two police units from the Central Provincial Police Headquarters and a unit from Kwikila were deployed to contain the situation. The counting for the LLG president that was supposed to commence at Kupiano yesterday was put on hold, awaiting the arrival of police officers from Port Moresby to Kupiano station. We had received information about armed men traveling from Port Moresby to Kupiano station in support of the fight, hence, we are looking into that. Police are communicating with the community to ensure that those who want to take the law into their own hands be arrested and charged," PPC Salle said.
He said counting for the LLG president will commence tomorrow, as per information provided by the election officials.
PPC Salle also thanked the Central Police Rural Commander and his team for their efforts.

Title: Reckless driving causing accidents, says Manning
Content:
Police Commissioner David Manning has attributed the tragic incident at Konedobu freeway that took the lives of three people to reckless driving.
He said many people have died in traffic accidents due to drivers operating irresponsibly without considering the lives of the people they transport and other pedestrians.
“My assessment of that incident after watching the CCTV footage shows that this is reckless driving. If you want to do that, go and do it somewhere else.
“The more reckless you are on the public road, the greater tragedy you pose to yourselves and innocent road users as well,” Manning said.
According to police and media reports, more than ten people have died in less than a month in traffic accidents throughout the country. It all comes back to how each driver drives.
National Capital District Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab also confirmed that the traffic police are working on the fatal accident that happened yesterday.
He said from the Statistics that about four traffic accidents were reported to the police this week.
He stated that this confirms that people are still driving recklessly around the city.
"Our traffic officers are making arrests; people are being convicted, but we still have ignorant individuals who do not think about other road users and the people they carry. We are trying our best to ensure that some accidents are avoided by conducting random police stop-and-search operations, setting up roadblocks, and doing motorist patrols to show police presence. When drivers see police, they tend to drive with care. Police will not always be at locations where you are involved in an accident; look after yourself, the person you are in the vehicle with, and the others on the road. Also, think about the car you are driving; it costs money," Met Supt Simatab said.
Simatab further called on the relatives of the people who died in the accident to work closely with the police to speed up the investigation process.

Title: UOG classes suspended for two weeks
Content:
Following the Special Senate Meeting yesterday afternoon, the Vice Chancellor of the University of Goroka verbally addressed the students last night, announcing the suspension of classes for two weeks.
Year 1–3 and first year In-Service Students will take a two-week break and complete their exams online through Google Classroom, WhatsApp, etc., whichever is viable and appropriate.
Year 4 and second year In-Service Students will also go on a two-week break but will return later to complete the semester.
A formal announcement is expected later today where these arrangements and dates will be confirmed.
Following this announcement, the Madang Provincial Government dispatched police and six 25-seater buses for its students, together with two buses from Raicoast DDA and one from Middle Ramu DDA. The buses arrived this morning in Goroka.
However, concerns have been raised that these may not be enough for students and their cargoes, and more busses need to be sent.
Acting Provincial Education Advisor Alphonse Igag indicated that he has been in close contact with student leaders, the Sumkar DDA office, and other appropriate authorities to send more buses for students' evacuation.
"With the six buses going up, I believe there will be some students left behind as it's not enough to cater for students and all their cargoes to come back. I am also appealing to student leaders to make a final list so we know exactly how many students we need to repatriate," Mr. Igag stated.
In the meantime, Mr. Igag emphasized the need for university students to be more responsible. He said locals and student clashes are not new and most times occurs at the end of the year and advised students to take responsibility for their own safety.
"Students need to remember that having a good time is not necessary. They need to be responsible and just go back home to their families. This is not a new scenario, and look what it has done? Just because of an outing, millions of Kina costs have been accrued, tarnishing the university's reputation, endangering lives, and causing chaos," Igag stressed.

Title: Power outage did not cause deaths, inquiry finds
People: Lohia Boe Samuel, Ricky Morris, Robert Naguri
Content:
The five deaths at the ANGAU Memorial Provincial Hospital, in Lae, were not directly related to the over 20 hours of power outage.
This was the response from members of the ANGAU hospital senior management team during an inquiry that was conducted recently by the Special Parliamentary Committee on Health Matters.
Seven deaths were reported on Sunday, October 19, 2025, when Lae was going through the usual series of blackouts, and the standby generator at the ANGAU Memorial Provincial Hospital failed to kick in.
Of the seven deaths, the Special Parliamentary Committee on Health Matters was told on Thursday, November 6, that two were deaths on arrival.
“In-patient deaths, we had four,” explained the director of curative services, Dr Steven James, to the three-man panel, chaired by Member for Bogia and Chairman of the Special Parliamentary Committee on Health Matters, Robert Naguri.
“The fifth one was someone who came into the emergency department during that time and succumbed to their illness so it was a cubicle death.”
One of the five deaths was described as “cubicle death”, meaning the patient was not admitted but had died whilst at the hospital facility, for example, the accident and emergency bay.
Hence, from the four in-patient deaths, Dr James outlined that the first one was a 73-year-old former public servant who had hypertension, haemorrhagic stroke, and was bleeding within his brain.
“He was admitted on the 16th of October and passed on on the 19th. He was someone who had a stroke and was progressively deteriorating. That was non-preventable,” he explained.
“The second case was a female of 28, who was initially admitted through our labour ward or obstetrics and gynaecology. The next day, she was transferred to the intensive care unit.
“She presented with TB meningitis; TB in the brain. She was also 26-28 weeks pregnant. She was admitted on October 11 into the ICU, and on the 16th, she was diagnosed as already having brain stem death. Prognosis serving team discussed with the family, and it was a case that was slowly succumbing.”
Dr James said the third case was that of a 49-year-old male who was admitted on October 4th with a longstanding history of abdominal pains and headaches. He had disseminated TB, which is a severe form of the illness where the TB bacteria have spread through the bloodstream. He also had other liver issues that were slowly progressing. He was a case of “non-preventable death”.
The fourth case involved a female who was admitted to the mental ward but also had advanced breast cancer that had spread to her brain. She was admitted on September 29 and sadly succumbed to the disease in the early hours of October 19.
The Special Parliamentary Committee on Health Matters, chaired by Naguri, also had Moresby North West MP, Lohia Boe Samuel, and Alotau MP, Ricky Morris, on the panel.
After listening to the ANGAU management and board, Naguri said the committee can confidently report to Parliament that the deaths on October 19 were not caused by the 20-hour blackout.

Title: Police officers injured in Goroka clash
Content:
Two police officers have been injured, while two police vehicles were damaged during fighting in Goroka, Eastern Highlands, which started on Saturday November 8, 2025.
During a press briefing today, Eastern Highlands provincial police commander, Chief Superintendent John Kale, confirmed that the conflict escalated after a student from the University of Goroka was attacked by locals from the nearby Apo Market.
“Police were outnumbered when fighting between students from the University of Goroka and locals started on Saturday,” said PPC Kale.
“Fortunately, there was heavy rain that night and that assisted in halting the fight.
“On Sunday, we were all thinking that it was a short fight and it will not happen again but the villagers decided to go into the university and started damaging properties. As a result, students retaliated. Local police were also there.
“Three police officers were stoned, with one of them being admitted currently with a chest injury. The other was hit on the head with a stone and was discharged yesterday. Two of my police vehicles were smashed.”
PPC Kale explained that there was low police manpower in Goroka due to the 2025 Local Level Government elections, where polling was conducted before last week while counting was last week.
“So, all my police officers were deployed to the eight districts. That was why we had low manpower in Goroka.”
The police commander has also refuted claims of locals attacking students who have been admitted to the hospital, saying they have increased security there.
Since yesterday (Sunday, November 9), police numbers have increased on the ground with the addition of Mobile Squad 14 from Kainantu Mine, Police from Simbu, who had arrived at 1pm yesterday, and Mt Hagen personnel, who arrived at 10pm.
Lae MP and Deputy Prime Minister, John Rosso, has assured his electorate that they are in contact with UOG leadership, with the Morobe Provincial Administration, Lae district and Lae police on standby.

Title: Capacity building for HV landowners
Content:
Despite many years of having mining companies operate in the country, landowner associations and their business entities continue to suffer from poor leadership, lack of proper management skills, lack of good governance and mismanagement of businesses.
Managing Director of Mineral Resource Authority, Jerry Garry said this has resulted in the unfulfillment of development aspirations of the mine-impacted communities.
With the aim to turn this situation around, the MRA introduced a program to build capacity for landowner associations and their business arms so they can competently manage and better serve their people’s interests.
Thirty project landowner leaders from Hidden Valley Mining successfully completed the two - week leadership, governance and management training from Oct 27-Nov 5 in Port Moresby. This is the second group of landowners, following the successful completion of the same training for Simberi landowners this year.
The program is geared towards enabling the landowners to:
• Gain knowledge and understanding of the roles and responsibilities of Directors
