• Develop positive, influential and effective leadership skills, essential for the successful management of NAKUWI, the Hidden Valley landowner umbrella company and equally valuable for Women and Youth groups.
• Enhance financial literacy, including understanding of financial markets and investment principles, relevant to Directors and community leaders.
• And collaboratively align and formulate a Sustainable Development Plan for Hidden Valley (2025–2030), to be developed in partnership with NAKUWI and broader project stakeholders
The program was the first for this group of landowners, was fully funded by the MRA, and delivered by three reputable organizations, namely the PNG Institute of Directors (PNGID), Center for Excellence in Financial Inclusion (CEFI), and the Institute of Banking & Business Management (IBBM). These three organizations delivered important and value-adding aspects and principles of leadership, good governance and business management training.
The program empowered the landowners to provide leadership with appropriate knowledge, mindset, promote and strengthen good governance, and ultimately minimize the potential for fraud, abuse, misuse, mismanagement, and poor governance practices.
The Hidden Valley’s Landowners Association Chairman Wayang Kawa, said most of his members were not adequately or formally educated in managing businesses or organizations. However, he said the training program had empowered them to be able to do better, adding that when they go back to their villages, they would put into practice what they had learnt.
President of the PNGID Clarence Hoot, thanked MRA for funding the program, adding that he hoped that the landowners had been empowered to clearly understand their roles and responsibilities as leaders.

Title: Kutubu LLG elections complete
Content:
A total of 17 councilors from the Kutubu Local Level Government officially signed their writs today in Mendi confirming their election as ward councilors.
The event marked a significant step in their political journey and the governance of their local communities.
Grace Wong, the Provincial Election Manager was present to formally accept the writs.
In her remarks, she congratulated the newly elected councilors on their victories and expressed her appreciation for the smooth conduct of the elections there.
“You are now officially recognised by the Government as ward councillors. Please continue to provide leadership in your communities and work with your team leaders to bring change to Kutubu.”
The successful completion of these elections showcases the commitment of both the election officials and the candidates to upholding democratic processes within the Kutubu Local Level Government area.
The newly elected councilors are expected to take on their responsibilities with vigor as they work towards addressing community needs and foster local development initiatives.

Title: Tournament regulations bind ahead of kick-off
Content:
The 2025 edition of the Melanesian Spearhead Group Prime Minister’s Cup is set to kick off on Tuesday, November 11, 2025, at the PNG National Football Stadium in Port Moresby.
Ahead of the start of the first game, the Host Organising Committee signed off on legal documents on Sunday, November 9, officially releasing the tournament regulations of the MSG PM’s Cup. The tournament runs from November 11 to 22.
The limelight will be on the women’s category; the women’s debut adds fresh energy and a new dimension to the regional rivalry with Fiji, Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, and PNG, having made solid preparations and are ready for the challenge. PNG will feel the weight of expectations as hosts.
The Host Organising Committee emphasised that the inclusion of the women’s event reflects a commitment to gender equity and football development across the region. The tournament will also count toward FIFA ranking points for both men’s and women’s sides. The women’s matches kick off on Thursday, November 13.
The men’s competition remains highly anticipated, and PNG is out to defend its title, with strong challenges expected from Solomon Islands and Fiji. The men’s game kick starts the tournament on Tuesday; PNG Red takes on Fiji, and in the second match on the same day, PNG Gold plays Vanuatu.

Title: Apprehend culprits, minister urges police
Content:
Police are being called on to make an example out of those who were involved in the wounding of University of Goroka students and damages to school assets.
Minister for Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology, Kinoka Hotune Feo, expressed his frustration and anger at the incident, which allegedly stemmed from an attack on a student on Saturday November 8, by locals at Apo Market.
Students retaliated on Saturday, then the next day, locals entered the campus and continued their assault on students and school properties, at a time when the university was into its second week of examinations.
“I call on the police to do your job,” Minister Feo said in a press briefing in Goroka today.
“Get the culprits apprehended. They must face the full brunt of the law.
“Many a time, students from the University of Goroka face problems after problems.
“A strong message must be sent to those around that cause problems. Enough is enough. We must protect the university; we must protect our students. They are the future of this country; they are the ones that will educate the future generation so we must look after them.
“I appeal to the nearby villages; Okiufa, Asariufa. The school is in our area. You are good people. This bad behaviour has just started. Youths who consume alcohol must be able to control themselves. If you don’t know how to control yourselves then don’t drink alcohol at all.
“I appeal to the governor of Eastern Highlands; we don’t need alcohol in this province. Completely put a ban on alcohol. We can still survive without alcohol. Nothing good comes out of alcohol.
“According to the report we received, an innocent young man was going to school when he was attacked by a drunkard. Alcohol continues to give us problems because our people don’t know how to consume alcohol.
“Same situation happened in Sonoma in Rabaul. Same weekend. Again, alcohol related. I appeal to our leaders who make decisions in our province. Governor Simon Sia has already talked about it; he has made the decision. We just need to support our police and they will enforce no alcohol in this province.
“In terms of what’s going to happen going forward, we have several options. Decisions will be made today.”

Title: Eastern Highlands Police Commanders Suspended After UOG Clashes
Content:
The Provincial Police Commander for Eastern Highlands Province and the Police Station Commander for Goroka have been suspended from their duties following the weekend incident involving University of Goroka students and the local community, Police Commissioner David Manning said.
Manning said in a statement that "The manner in which this matter escalated is of serious concern. The effectiveness of these policing units is unacceptable. I expect better and more effective policing from provincial commands.
"I have directed an immediate review of the operational preparations and the policing response to this matter, overseen by Deputy Commissioner of Police (Regional Operations).
"Internal Affairs investigators have been deployed to examine the actions of police on the ground, and determine why a swifter and more professional policing outcome was not delivered.
"Until such time as satisfactory answers are provided, Mobile Squad members will continue to maintain a presence in Goroka,” he said.
Commissioner Manning called on the University of Goroka and student bodies to examine the behavior of students.
"This sort of alcohol fueled behavior is unacceptable. Students and surrounding communities have suffered as a result of alcohol-fueled stupidity.
"It is disappointing to see the escalation of a dispute that could have been quickly resolved if reported to the police.
"We need to put a stop to this culture of violence. Our educated youth must break from such practices.
"During the evening of Saturday, 8th November, a fight broke out between students attending the University of Goroka and locals from a neighboring village," Commissioner Manning confirmed.
"Early on, the number of people involved in the fighting far outnumbered the police, who called in reinforcements and calmed the situation.
"The Goroka General Hospital has confirmed that over 40 students were admitted with injuries, and a number of vehicles and houses were damaged.
"Three police officers were also injured by intoxicated individuals throwing stones,” Manning said.
Commissioner Manning confirmed the deployment of additional police from Mobile Squads and surrounding provincial commands had brought normality back to Goroka township.

Title: NCD Police Warns Parents After Boy Drowns in Fast-Flowing Drain
Content:
National Capital District Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab has urged parents and guardians to stop their children from washing in the rain or in fast-flowing drains around the city.
Met Supt. Simatab made this call after a 14-year-old boy drowned in fast-flowing water at Bush Wara, Goroka Block, yesterday evening.
"According to information provided to police, the boy was in the company of four other boys who were washing in the creek when he was washed away by the fast-flowing water. We are experiencing heavy rain this week, and I am calling on parents to make sure their children are indoors to avoid such incidents. Earlier this year, we also received a similar report of a boy drowning at Five Mile, whose body was later found at Eight Mile First Block," Met Supt. Simatab said.
He further added that police are currently at the scene conducting an investigation and compiling reports on the cause of death. He also noted that the death toll in the city is increasing, with people dying in accidents, from illnesses, or during fights.
Met Supt. Simatab called on the public to help raise awareness to prevent children from losing their lives in such tragic circumstances.
The body of the young boy from Eastern Highlands was discovered by residents of Goroka Block after they realized he had gone washing in the drain but did not return with the other three boys.

Title: Over 50 casualties treated by Goroka hospital
Content:
Over 50 casualties from the violent confrontation between students and locals, have been treated by the Goroka Provincial Specialist Hospital (GPSH).
In a statement, Acting Hospital Manager, Dr. Shirley ToMangana, said the hospital received 51 casualties as of 9.45pm on Sunday, November 9th, 2025.
Of the 51 casualties, 47 were students, three were locals and one was a police officer.
“Four were surgical admissions, at which it is broken down that includes one needing an emergency craniotomy (head operation),” outlined Dr ToMangana. “Patient remains stable under post-operative care.
“One was an ophthalmology (eye) admission, three were under observation in the Emergency Department while 43 were discharged home with soft tissue injuries.
“No deaths were recorded.
“The hospital activated its ‘mass casualty protocol’ at 11am on the 9th of November, 2025.”
Dr ToMangana said this meant that more than 46 staff across medical, surgical, nursing, pathology, radiology, pharmacy and security units were mobilised.
“Additional bed spaces were created in wards to accommodate patient flow,” she continued.
“The situation remains tense, and the hospital continues to operate under MCI standby mode while maintaining normal services for non-incident patients.
“Security has been heightened around the Emergency Department in coordination with local police.
“We sincerely acknowledge the dedication of all hospital staff, support from the Senior Executive Management Team, and the assistance from the police, New Channel Inn, and community partners during this emergency response.
“Further updates will be provided as the situation develops.”

Title: Madang Students at UOG Fear for Safety After Violent Clashes
Content:
More than 200 students from Madang Province attending the University of Goroka (UOG) are living in fear following a violent confrontation over the weekend that left several students injured and campus property damaged.
Students are now calling on authorities to organize immediate repatriation assistance as tensions remain high on campus.
Sources at the university say the Top Management Team (TMT) is meeting to decide whether to allow students to leave or remain to complete their examinations.
Provincial Police Commander (PPC) Robert Baim said officers are working closely with the Provincial Administration to ensure the students’ safety.
“We are coordinating between the Provincial Administrator’s office, and once it is clear that the students are to leave, we will escort vehicles to ensure their safe return,” stated PPC Baim.
According to student representatives, discussions are underway with the Madang Provincial Administration to send six buses with police escorts to assist with possible repatriation.
While the cause of the unrest remains unclear, students said the violence began after an altercation between a student and local youths on Saturday evening around 7 p.m. The following day, locals launched an attack on campus, injuring several students and damaging property.
The standoff lasted several hours, from 7 a.m. to 3 p.m., before police and community leaders intervened to restore order.
Police are currently maintaining security around the campus with assistance from local elders, while other provincial student groups have begun organizing transport to return home if the university suspends classes.

Title: Baim warns Madang public to remain neutral in UOG clash
Content:
The Madang Provincial Police Command is fully aware of the ongoing clashes between students of the University of Goroka in the Eastern Highlands Province and surrounding villagers.
“I want to make it very clear to everyone in Madang Province that these incidents must not be used as a reason to retaliate, provoke, or harm any Eastern Highlanders residing, working, or studying in Madang.
“Anyone who attempts to intimidate, threaten, or harm any person of Eastern Highlands origin will be dealt with severely by Madang Police. Lawbreakers will face immediate arrest and prosecution under the laws of Papua New Guinea.
“Madang is known for its peace and unity, let us uphold that reputation. I urge all communities, students, and residents to remain calm and let the law take its course. Police will be maintaining regular patrols to ensure the safety and security of everyone,” said PPC Baim.
The situation in Madang remains under control, but tensions are high.

Title: ICAC Officers Sworn In to Strengthen Fight Against Corruption
Content:
Seventy-five officers from the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) officially took their Oath of Office and Oath of Secrecy last week, marking a major milestone in the Commission’s operational rollout.
The ceremony, administered by Principal Magistrate His Worship Billy Pidu, was witnessed by Acting Commissioner Thomas Eluh and Acting Deputy Commissioners, Retired Judges Don Sawong and Ellenas Batari.
Commissioner Eluh commended the officers for their commitment to uphold integrity and accountability.
“By taking these oaths today, you demonstrate your firm commitment as Commission officers and as ambassadors of the ICAC to lead the fight against corruption,” he said.
The Oath of Office binds officers to uphold the Constitution and perform their duties with impartiality, while the Oath of Secrecy ensures the confidentiality of sensitive information handled by the Commission.
Deputy Commissioners Sawong and Batari reminded officers that integrity and professionalism must guide their work.
“Live by the meaning of the words you have used,” Sawong urged.
The event marks another step forward in strengthening ICAC’s internal systems as it advances its constitutional mandate to prevent, investigate, and prosecute corruption in Papua New Guinea.

Title: Pepes finish 3rd at Singapore tournament
Content:
Papua New Guinea came out tops in the battle for third place, outperforming Malaysia to claim a comfortable 69-54 win on Saturday at the Singlife Nations Cup in Singapore.
Kenya maintained their perfect streak to retain the crown, beating Singapore Vandas (2nd) 55-42, PNG (3rd), Malaysia (4th), while development side Singapore A closed in on 5th place, ending their campaign on a high note with a 53-39 win over tournament debutantes the Isle of Man (6th).
It was pleasing news for the PNG side as its co-captain Chloe Litherland was named the Player of the Tournament.
While Malaysia took a while to settle down, PNG were focused from the starting whistle. PNG raced to a 20-12 lead after the first quarter and carried its momentum into the second. World No. 28 Malaysia struggled to penetrate PNG’s staunch defence and could not keep up with their quick counterattacks, allowing PNG to surge further to take a 34-25 lead at half-time.
However, it was the Malaysians who were on the front foot in the third quarter as they found their rhythm to reduce the deficit to just five. They also did well to capitalise on PNG’s mistakes. However, they were unable to replicate their inspired performance in the final quarter.
The reintroduction of PNG shooter Kala Ali was also significant as her work on and off the ball paid off. Ali converted 19 of her 21 attempts in the second half to help her side clinch the win and third place in what was their second time stunning Malaysia this week.
PNG Pepe’s co-captain, Michaela Kadlecek, was proud of the progress her side has made in the past week, especially with just Ali left from the side that reached the 2023 final.
She said: “It was definitely a grind. Malaysia came out firing, but I’m glad we got away with that one. I’m grateful because we really came together today (Saturday). Over the last few days, we’ve played and talked about what we need to work on, and today we’ve pulled it together.
“Our mental fatigue kicked in in the third quarter, and we got a bit tired. But we came off, talked about what we needed to do in that fourth quarter, and we got it together. We're a brand new team, so we're still learning combinations, but we've definitely progressed. We've got some debutantes coming in at 16 years old, and it's really good to see what they can do on the court,” said Kadlecek.

Title: Bereina police get 10 new houses
Content:
Bereina police in Kairuku district of Central Province are proud recipients of 10 new houses. The assistance was made possible under the Government’s Special Police Assistance Program (SPAP) funding of K3.9 million.
Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr. on Friday, November 7, 2025, commissioned the new houses.
While acknowledging the government’s assistance, Minister Tsiamalili Jr stated that Kairuku District is close to Port Moresby but still lacks government services, which he said is a reality around the country.
He said through the SPAP, the government, right across the country, is making a difference in regard to policing infrastructure, particularly in most rural areas, as the program supports the police officers.
"I want to appreciate my police officers. Continue to serve your country; this is your country. This is a job where you made a decision to join the police force, and you believe in the uniform. We can have many people criticising us, but no one fits into our shoes,” Minister Tsiamili said.
He added that he knows the challenges, and that is why the ministry is trying its best to make sure police infrastructure is looked into. Minister Tsiamalili said police cars are given to increase police presence, and police officers are trained to increase police manpower throughout the country.
Tsiamalili said getting the simple things right, like repatriating the retired officers back home and getting the uniforms for the police officers, are some of the things that are being looked into.
While outlining the things that the government is doing, he also challenged serving police officers to look after the new officers who will graduate and join them in the future, teaching them the good habits that they were taught at Bomana Police College.
Minister Tsiamalili, while commissioning the new infrastructure, thanked the landowners for providing land for the police houses. He also thanked Kairuku MP and Energy Minister Peter Isoaimo, who donated two vehicles to the Bereina police, who are currently using them to do policing in the area.

Title: Food Festival serves up support for PMGH wards
Content:
The Hamamas Food Festival 2025, themed “Cuisine Beyond Borders,” wrapped up a flavorful weekend at Dynasty Seafood Restaurant, Vision City Megamall, with more than just satisfied appetites — it delivered hope.
Over two days, on November 8 and 9, about 14 restaurants around Port Moresby showcased diverse global cuisines, drawing crowds eager to explore culinary traditions and support a meaningful cause. The restaurants included Asia Aroma Restaurant, Thahera Indian Cuisine, The Point Cakes and Pastries, Dynasty Seafood Restaurant, and others.
A portion of the festival’s proceeds will benefit the Pediatric and Cancer Ward (1E) at Port Moresby General Hospital, helping improve care for children battling serious illnesses.
Organisers say the event was designed to celebrate cultural diversity while strengthening community bonds through food and philanthropy.
With strong turnout and support from the public, the festival highlighted the power of hospitality and promoted local engagement. Plans are already underway to expand the initiative in future editions.
When ending the festival this afternoon, participants were rewarded for their support, tireless efforts, and tasty dishes.

Title: Female body found along Hiritano highway
Content:
Police in the National Capital District and Central Province are investigating the death of a female whose body was discovered at Ruburoko along Hiritano Highway, in Central Province, on Sunday, November 9.
Central Provincial Police Commander Chief Inspector Joseph Salle confirmed that the deceased's body was discovered by a man in a garden, who reported the incident to local leaders, who then reported the matter to the police.
Chief Insp. Salle said officers from Forensic, Central Criminal Investigation, and the Laloki police have retrieved the body and brought it to the Port Moresby General Hospital morgue.
PPC Salle added that the female has a tattoo on her right abdomen, coloured in yellow, red, and black. He further mentioned that she has short hair and is about 140 centimeters tall.
"Police, community leaders, and village representatives from the Ruburoko area raised awareness in the surrounding villages, and confirmed that all females are present. We are extending our call to the general public to check each house, and if any female members who fit the description of the deceased female can call Central Police headquarters, and police officers will assist," PPC Salle said.
Police investigations continue.

Title: Masere clarifies social media claims on Biometric voting contract
Content:
Minister of Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on Constitutional Matters, Richard Masere, has refuted and clarified misleading information recently circulated on social media regarding contract awards for the implementation of biometric electronic voting technology for the 2027 National General Election.
Contrary to the claims made online, Masere, in a statement, said no such discussions were agreed upon regarding any tender or contract for biometric electronic voting during any recent official engagements.
“The meeting in question focused solely on biometric registration technology to strengthen and expand the current National Identification (NID) system for nationwide coverage.
“At no point did the Minister or any Government representative discuss, approve, or endorse any tender related to the conduct of the 2027 National General Election, nor was any contract awarded to any private company for that purpose.
“All procurement processes for any future projects, including those potentially relating to biometric NID technology and election technology, will be strictly governed by the National Procurement Commission (NPC) under the Public Finance Management Act and relevant tendering requirements.”
He said any claims suggesting otherwise are false, misleading, and irresponsible.
“The public is therefore advised to disregard these unfounded statements. The Government remains committed to ensuring transparency, accountability, and proper due process in all procurement and administrative matters.
“The Ministry will continue its collaboration with the PNG Civil and Identity Registry (PNGCIR), PNG Electoral Commission (PNGEC), and other relevant agencies to strengthen biometric registration for citizens, an essential foundation for service delivery, planning, and good governance.”
Masere reiterated that any individuals or organisations disseminating false or misleading information will be subject to investigation under applicable laws governing misinformation and public communication.

Title: Papua New Guinean appointed to US Scientific Advisory Board
Content:
Dr Yalinu Poya Gow, a distinguished scientist from Papua New Guinea, has been appointed to the Scientific Advisory Board (SAB) for the Association for Environmental Health and Sciences (AEHS) Foundation, a leading organization based in the United States.
Dr Gow, in her LinkedIn status, commented: “ I am excited to share that I have been appointed to the Scientific Advisory Board (SAB) for the Association for Environmental Health and Sciences Foundation.
“This board ensures a balance of scientific, regulatory, and geographical perspectives, contributing to impactful discussions and advancing environmental health and science on the East Coast of the United States.
“Looking forward to collaborating with this brilliant and dedicated team to support the continued growth of Environmental Health and Sciences on the East Coast of the United States.”
The Scientific Advisory Board comprises a team of highly accomplished and dedicated professionals who provide a balanced blend of scientific, regulatory, and geographical perspectives.
Together, they guide the Foundation’s mission to advance environmental health and science through research, policy, and education.

Title: Parliamentary Committee prepares for inquiry into ICA
People: Allan Marat, Lohia Boe Samuel, Ricky Morris
Content:
The Permanent Parliamentary Committee on Citizenship Matters is stepping up preparations for an inquiry next year into Papua New Guinea’s immigration and citizenship challenges, following a recent engagement with the Immigration and Citizenship Authority (ICA).
Led by Chairman and Member for Alotau, Ricky Morris, the Committee recently met with ICA representatives to gain insights into the Authority’s ongoing initiatives, major projects, and the pressing challenges in managing immigration and citizenship across the country.
Morris said the briefing provided valuable information to guide the Committee’s upcoming inquiry, which will focus on strengthening national systems to safeguard PNG’s borders, uphold immigration laws, and protect citizens’ opportunities.
“Our engagement with the ICA has provided us with critical insight into the real issues on the ground,” Morris said.
“As we prepare for the inquiry next year, we are committed to identifying practical and effective measures to ensure PNG’s immigration and citizenship processes are fair, secure, and beneficial to our people.
“The committee will come down on illegal foreigners engaged in indigenous and reserved business. All line agencies like the Customs, Labour Department, IRC, and others will be summoned to appear before the Committee.”
During the meeting, ICA officials outlined several strategic measures already underway to address illegal entry, unlawful residence, and compliance monitoring of foreign nationals.
The Committee also expressed concern over reports of illegal immigrants engaging in business activities that are reserved for Papua New Guineans.
Committee Members Lohia Boe Samuel and Dr. Allan Marat joined the discussions, contributing to the Committee’s assessment and planning for the inquiry.
The inquiry, scheduled for early next year, will examine policy frameworks, enforcement mechanisms, and inter-agency coordination to ensure the effective management of PNG’s immigration and citizenship affairs.

Title: PM Marape calls for action on climate financing at COP30
Content:
Prime Minister James Marape’s call for financing to support forest and ocean nations like Papua New Guinea continued at the COP30 summit in Brazil during the Thematic Session 3: of the Leaders’ Segment.
He called on developed nations and multilateral partners to channel more financing into nature-based solutions that value the preservation of forests rather than their exploitation.
“Our forests deserve proper conservation financing,” he said.
“Nature-based technologies must begin by valuing standing forests — not just harvested timber. One hectare of conserved forest can save the world far more than any industrial offset.”
He urged the international community to deliver a new era of equitable climate finance that recognises the contributions of forest nations to global mitigation, through mechanisms such as jurisdictional REDD+ and carbon market systems under Articles 5 and 6 of the Paris Agreement.
He highlighted the role forest and ocean nations play in “carrying the weight of the planet’s survival” in their fight to preserve the world’s last great carbon sinks.
Prime Minister Marape said the world’s forests and oceans are humanity’s most powerful allies in limiting global warming to 1.5°C.
“Forests and ocean nations are carrying the burden of the entire planet’s atmospheric balance,” Prime Minister Marape said. “The Amazon Basin, the Congo Basin, and the tropical forests of Papua New Guinea and Southeast Asia together form the lungs of the Earth. Conserving them is the greatest mitigation effort we can make to save humanity itself.”
PM Marape reminded delegates that there is no substitute for the Earth’s natural systems, urging them not to look to other planets for survival but to preserve the one they already inhabit.
“There is no planet like Earth,” he said. “Mars and Mercury are unlivable. Here, rivers, trees, mountains, and oceans sustain life. That is worth fighting for.”
PM Marape reaffirmed Papua New Guinea’s commitment to halting large-scale deforestation, restoring degraded lands, and supporting sustainable development for local communities. He also highlighted PNG’s readiness to work with global partners to advance forest-nation diplomacy and operationalise long-term climate financing solutions.
“For six years as Prime Minister, I have been saying: stop deforestation. Bring real conservation that sustains livelihoods and protects humanity,” he said. “If this generation of leaders fails to find real financing solutions for forest nations, history will judge us harshly.”
The Thematic Session on “10 Years of the Paris Agreement: NDCs and Financing” brought together world leaders to reflect on a decade of progress and challenges in implementing Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and mobilising climate finance.

Title: Kumuls Duo Land Contracts with London Broncos
Content:
Just 24 hours after securing the signature of promising PNG Kumuls utility halfback, Finley Glare, the London Broncos in the Super League, recruited Kumuls fullback Morea Morea Junior.
Morea Junior and Glare will now join fellow PNG Kumuls and former Hunters forward, Emmanuel Waine, at the club under the mentorship of Brisbane Broncos great, Darren Lockyer.
Both Morea Junior and Finley Glare have inspirational stories for young aspiring Papua New Guinean Rugby League players.
Glare, came through the Junior Kumuls system. He starred in their outing against Australian School boys’ team in 2023 where he caught the attention of PNG Hunters coach, Paul Aiton. He was then scouted into the Hunters team in 2024.
Although he made the team, Glare was stuck behind Jamie Mavoko and Joshua Lau, who were regular picks for Aiton. The Hunters went onto making the preliminary finals. Despite not getting many games that season, Glare was sharping his craft in the Digicel ExxonMobil cup with the Lae Tigers waiting for his turn.
The long wait was over when Lau was ruled out for the majority of 2025 season through injury and Mavoko out of form and dropped to Digicel ExxonMobil cup with Port Moresby Vipers. Glare took over the responsibility and never looked back since.
After the Hunters 2025 campaign, he was called into the Pacific Championship camp. He did his job, helped PNG Kumuls retain the Pacific Bowl Title, and won himself a contract with London Broncos – a well-deserved reward for the hardworking young man.
Morea Junior’s story, on the other hand, is a testament of resilience and self-confidence. The electric fullback stayed in the Hunters system much longer than Glare and earned himself a deserving contract with Broncos.
Morea burst into the scene a serious rugby league talent and quickly gain recognition from fans and rugby league community.
He was named best player of the Intrust Super Cup in his debut season (2023). He went on to secure a train and trial deal with The Dolphins the same year. He later signed a similar deal with North Queensland Cowboys in 2025.
What is even more intriguing is that, midway through last year, Morea Junior lost his fullback position to Sanny Wabo after he sustained a serious leg injury that ruled him out for a year. He couldn’t reclaim the spot after recovering from the injury as Wabo locked in the spot.
During the year, Morea Junior transferred to Queensland Capras, after having a stint with Port Moresby Vipers. He was impressive playing for the Capras, hence, PNG Kumuls coach Jason Demetriou entrusted him with the number jumper 1 for PNG Kumuls in the 2025 Pacific Championship. He did his best, showed his potential, and impressed the selectors to secure a contract with the Broncos in the Super League.
All the best to the young men.

Title: Work on Yangoru-Saussia hydro project begins.
Content:
The desire by Yangoru-Saussia District to have its own hydro to permanently solve its chronic power issues will soon be over.
The Yangoru-Saussia District Development Authority (DDA) presented a cheque of K353, 200.04 to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Company (SMEC) PNG Limited in Port Moresby on Friday, to commence the prefeasibility study for the proposed Sikau Hydro Project.
Member for Yangoru-Saussia Richard Maru said the payment signals the start of a landmark project and that the DDA is taking action because the district has been without power for up to four months due to continuous power blackouts in the Wewak grid and failing power poles not attended to by PNG Power Limited (PPL).
The estimated project time frame for the entire project will take about 2 years, inclusive of prefeasibility study.

Title: Ramu NiCo Welcomes 28 New Graduates
Content:
28 graduates from various disciplines and institutions both in PNG and overseas joined the Ramu Nickel & Cobalt Mine this month under its Graduate Development Scheme (GDS) program.
The 28 were picked through a rigorous selection process from more than 2,000 applications.
This year’s selection saw an increase of female intakes numbering 10, the inclusion of Don Bosco Technological Institute to the program for the first time and the recruitment of four international students.
Emphasizing its motto of being a "Mine to Grow Minds" for the country, Ramu Nico in a statement said this motto has been the corner stone for a lot of programs aimed at developing the Human Resource of Papua New Guinea.
The mine has employed and trained numerous Papua New Guineans, including local residents from the project impact areas, which accounts for about 70% of PNG national employees. With the introduction of the GDS in 2024, the mine is now set to continue to recruit, train and develop young Papua New Guineans to be skilful and competent professionals to contribute to the nation building.
Ramu NiCo's Deputy General Manager for HR, Jeffers Heptol Teargun said the mine is now becoming an avenue for Papua New Guineans to work, train and gain skills that’s vital for our country.
"One of our successful candidates from the first batch in 2024 was accepted to work overseas (Australia) and he was a fruit of our Graduate Development Program. We also have another 10 candidates from our first batch that were recommended by their supervisors for internal positions and are currently working permanently at our mine and our refinery sites," the HR deputy general manager said.
This year, Ramu NiCo increased the total number to 28 candidates as the industry demand in the field of Mining Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Chemistry, Environmental Health, Information Communication Technology (ICT) grew.
The 2025 Ramu NiCo GDS commissioning program was held on November 01st and witnessed by representatives from Divine Word University's Faculty of Environmental Health and the University's Partnership Director, Ramu NiCo's Vice President and other employees of Ramu NiCo.

Title: Police Condemn Killings on Karkar Island
Content:
Police in Madang have condemned the brutal killings on Karkar Island early Friday morning, describing the attack as “barbaric and inhumane”.
A police task force from Madang was deployed immediately yesterday to stabilize the situation and prevent further violence between Gial and Urugen communities.
PPC Baim states that reinforcements are on the ground to contain the situation and restore order.
He is now appealing to the leaders from both communities cooperate with police, and allow the law to take its course.
Suspects in the killings have also been urged to surrender to authorities as police will not tolerate individuals taking the law into their own hands.
Investigations are ongoing and police are appealing to witnesses and local residents to come forward with any information that could assist in identifying those responsible. Community leaders and residents are encouraged to cooperate with law enforcement agencies and participate in de-escalation efforts to maintain peace.
“We will not tolerate such unlawful and inhumane acts in Madang Province. The individuals involved must surrender immediately or face the full force of the law. The police will pursue all leads with impartiality and diligence.”
Baim briefly linked the killings to the consumption of illicit substances such as homebrew and marijuana by youths in the area.

Title: BPNG, AFI Lead Program to Strengthen Climate-Resilient Financial Systems
Content:
The Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG) and the Alliance for Financial Inclusion (AFI) have charted a path toward climate-resilient and inclusive financial systems through a four-day Joint Learning Program on Inclusive Green Finance Policy Implementation, held from 28–31 October in Port Moresby.
The program brought together global policymakers and central bankers to advance inclusive green finance (IGF) strategies, focusing on climate adaptation, gender-responsive policies, and digital financial services.
Key discussions centred around Papua New Guinea’s climate priorities, the national Inclusive Green Finance Policy, and the Green Finance Centre.
“Climate change is not a distant risk but a lived reality for everyone in the Pacific,” said BPNG Deputy Governor Jeffery Yabom, stressing that women and vulnerable groups face the greatest barriers in accessing finance when they need it most.
AFI’s Director of Strategy, Aban Haq, praised BPNG’s leadership, noting the urgency of financial inclusion responses for smallholder farmers and rural populations. Assistant Governor George Awap highlighted PNG’s progress, including the Green Finance Policy (2023), Green Finance Centre (2024), and mobilisation of over two billion kina in climate-related finance.
The event featured insights from AFI member institutions and partners such as UNDP, IFC, and the Green Climate Fund.
AFI Pacific Regional Manager Mereseni Tuivuniwai urged participants to translate policy into action, stressing collaboration and gender-responsive frameworks.

Title: Three beheaded on Karkar Island
Content:
Karkar Island in the Sumkar District of Madang has been marred with multiple murders overnight with at least three people reportedly beheaded.
Initial reports reaching Madang from sources on the ground indicate that the killings came about following a surprise attack on three youths of Urugen village by youths from another village. The Urugen youths were returning to their village via a bush track when they were attacked. One was reported to have been beheaded, one severely injured and the third escaped.
The incident was swiftly reported to Kinim police who responded and arrested four suspects and locked them up at Kinim police station. Two suspects were from Dimer village while the other two from nearby Gial village.
In retaliation, a pressure group from Urugen raided Kinim police station at about 4 this morning and beheaded two of the four suspects while the other two escaped.
The bodies of the beheaded suspects at Kinim police station remain unclaimed while their heads were taken to Gial village.
The same group from Urugen also allegedly burnt down sections of Gial village. It’s been reported that Dimer villagers have fled their homes in fear of the pressure groups from Urugen.
With Kinim police personnel outnumbered at this stage, Madang Provincial Police Commander (PPC) Superintendent Robert Baim has deployed police troops to Karkar Island with the support of the Sumkar District Development Authority, to contain the situation and restore law and order.
"We are calling on all Karkar people, community leaders, and youth groups to cooperate fully with police in maintaining peace and protecting lives and property,” PPC Baim said. “Let us work together to bring calm, unity, and safety back to our island.”
“Violence and destruction will only harm our families and future," he stressed.
Further updates to follow as police work continues.

Title: PM Marape welcomes UN Secretary-General’s COP30 message
Content:
Prime Minister James Marape has commended the United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres for his powerful and uncompromising address at the opening of the World Leaders Climate Action Summit during COP30 in Belém, describing it as “a moral compass for world leaders to act decisively in this decade of truth.”
Prime Minister Marape said the Secretary-General’s remarks resonated deeply with the Pacific and forest nations, especially those like Papua New Guinea that are on the frontline of the climate crisis but least responsible for it.
“Secretary-General Guterres spoke the truth that the world must hear,” Prime Minister Marape said. “When he declared that ‘the 1.5°C limit is a red line for humanity’, he spoke for every vulnerable island and forest nation fighting for survival. Papua New Guinea fully aligns with his call for courageous, collective, and urgent action.”
He welcomed the Secretary-General’s call for a “paradigm shift” to limit the magnitude and duration of global temperature overshoot, accelerate the phase-out of fossil fuels, and protect critical ecosystems such as tropical forests and oceans — the planet’s natural carbon sinks.
“Papua New Guinea stands shoulder to shoulder with the United Nations and forest nations like Brazil in protecting the lungs of the Earth,” he said. “We are committed to conserving our 13 per cent share of the world’s tropical rainforest, sustaining 97 per cent of land under customary ownership, and ensuring our people benefit equitably from global carbon markets.”
He further applauded the Secretary-General’s strong emphasis on climate justice and equitable financing, which remains a central challenge for developing nations.
“Mr Guterres was right to call out the injustice of the current system — where developing nations continue to suffer the worst effects of a crisis they did not cause,” the Prime Minister said. “We join his call for developed nations to mobilise the agreed US$1.3 trillion annually by 2035 and ensure that funds for adaptation and resilience reach those most affected.”
He said Papua New Guinea was already advancing clean energy, forest conservation, and sustainable agriculture initiatives — but that such efforts needed genuine international partnership and investment.
Prime Minister Marape echoed the Secretary-General’s plea to make COP30 in Belém “the turning point” for global climate action and justice.
“As the Secretary-General said, ‘no one can bargain with physics, but we can choose to lead – or be led to ruin.’ This is the decisive decade for humanity,” Prime Minister Marape said. “Papua New Guinea stands with the United Nations and Brazil in turning pledges into real action — through courage, solidarity, and science-based leadership.”
He added that Papua New Guinea, as a leading Pacific democracy and a custodian of rich forests and oceans, would continue to advance South–South cooperation, build partnerships with fellow forest nations, and champion the Pacific voice for climate justice.
“Belém is not only the host city of COP30 — it is a symbol of the world’s conscience,” he said. “Papua New Guinea is honoured to stand here in solidarity with global leaders who are ready to act for our planet and future generations.”

Title: UN chief urges world leaders to drive down global warming
Content:
As world leaders gather in Brazil for the COP30 climate summit, UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Thursday called for urgent action to drive down global temperatures and keep the 1.5°C goal within reach.
“Every fraction of a degree means more hunger, displacement, and loss – especially for those least responsible. It could push ecosystems past irreversible tipping points, expose billions to unlivable conditions, and amplify threats to peace and security,” Guterres told leaders in Belém.
Failure to contain global heating amounts to “moral failure and deadly negligence,” he added.
Each year that is warmer, he said, “will hammer economies, deepen inequalities and impact developing countries hardest — even though they did least to cause it.”
“After decades of denial and delay, science now tells us that a temporary overshoot beyond the 1.5°C limit – starting at the latest in the early 2030s – is inevitable,” Guterres continued.
“We need a fundamental paradigm shift to limit this overshoot’s magnitude and duration and quickly drive it down. Even a temporary overshoot will unleash far greater destruction and costs for every nation.”
Echoing his remarks, World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) chief Celeste Saulo said that greenhouse gas emissions are now at their highest level in 800,000 years.
“From January to August this year, the Earth’s average temperature was about 1.42°C above pre-industrial levels, with oceans also reaching record highs, which is inflicting lasting damage on marine ecosystems and economies,” she said.
The planet’s relentless warming trend has shown no sign of slowing, with 2025 projected to be either the second or third warmest year on record, according to the State of the Global Climate Update 2025 issued by the WMO on Thursday.
It warns that the 11-year stretch from 2015 to 2025 will be the hottest period since records began 176 years ago.
“This unprecedented streak of high temperatures, combined with last year’s record increase in greenhouse gas levels, makes it clear that it will be virtually impossible to limit global warming to 1.5°C in the next few years without temporarily overshooting this target,” said WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo.
She stressed that science still shows it is possible to bring temperatures back below that threshold by the end of the century.
The report paints a stark picture of compounding climate impacts.
Arctic sea ice reached its lowest winter maximum on record, while Antarctic Sea ice remained well below average.
Global sea level rise, nearly twice as fast as in the 1990s, continued to accelerate due to ocean warming and ice melt.
Extreme weather events – from devastating floods and storms to prolonged heatwaves and wildfires – have disrupted food systems, displaced communities and hindered economic development across multiple regions.
The Secretary-General told COP30 that the 1.5°C limit remains “a red line for humanity”, calling for rapid emissions cuts, an accelerated phase-out of fossil fuels, and stronger protection of forests and oceans.
Guterres highlighted the growing momentum of the clean energy revolution, noting that investments in renewables now exceed those in fossil fuels by $800 billion. “Clean energy is winning in price, performance, and potential,” he said, “but what is still missing is political courage.”
Also addressing delegates, Marinez Scherer, COP30’s Special Envoy for the Ocean, urged nations to unite efforts for both forests and oceans, calling them “one living system” that shapes the planet’s climate.
“Science is clear – we cannot solve the climate crisis unless we act together for the ocean,” she said, pointing to the Amazon and the Atlantic as symbols of this connection.
Dr Scherer, a marine biologist and coastal management expert at Brazil’s Federal University of Santa Catarina, noted that the ocean produces over half of the world’s oxygen, absorbs 90 per cent of excess heat, and sustains billions of livelihoods — yet receives less than one per cent of global climate finance.
“Protecting the ocean and the Amazon is not just an environmental imperative, but a collective act of survival,” she said. “The ocean cannot wait, and neither can we,” said Dr Scherer.

Title: Why PNG’s Highest Leaders Must Lead the Charge Against the National HIV Crisis
Content:
With the recent declaration of a national HIV crisis, the United Nations Resident Coordinator in Papua New Guinea, Richard Stephen Howard, Jr., and Manoela Manova,UNAIDS Country Director for Papua New Guinea provide their opinion through this Editorial on the subject, highlighting the importance of leadership in addressing the epidermic.
Papua New Guinea stands at a perilous crossroads in its efforts against HIV. With the recent declaration of a National HIV Crisis, the time for fragmented efforts is over. The magnitude of this emergency demands absolute unity, decisive action, and sustained investment from every sector of society.
This is why the PNG Christian Leaders HIV Media Conference, held on 29 October 2025 was a critical turning point and a beacon of hope. This event witnessed the powerful public unity of His Eminence John Cardinal Ribat, Chair of the PNG Christian Leaders Alliance on HIV and AIDS (PNGCLA), and Prime Minister Hon. James Marape, who jointly addressed the nation’s growing epidemic.
The Media Conference brought together key partners including the United Nations in Papua New Guinea through UNAIDS, the Australian Government, the National Department of Health, the National AIDS Council Secretariat, and Church and Community Leaders, including representatives of People Living with HIV in PNG.
The Urgent State of the Epidemic
The urgency cannot be overstated. While the world has reduced new HIV infections by 39% since 2010, new infections in PNG have significantly increased by 84% in the same period. Currently, it is estimated that 30 people are newly acquiring HIV in PNG every single day. This resulted in an estimated 11,000 new infections in 2024, bringing the total estimated number of people living with HIV (PLHIV) to 120,000, representing a national HIV prevalence of 1.5%.
This crisis devastates lives, impacting vulnerable individuals, primarily women and children. The majority of infections are sexually transmitted, and critically, 60% of people living with HIV in PNG are women. This includes the wives and female partners of male clients of Female Sex Workers (FSW) or Men who have Sex with Men (MSM).
Despite investments in anti-retroviral therapy (ART) that have averted a significant number of AIDS-related deaths, major gaps remain in reaching national targets:
•	Only 59% of PLHIV are estimated to know their status.
•	Only 46% of all PLHIV have achieved viral suppression.
•	The rate of HIV testing during antenatal care visits dropped drastically from above 80% prior to 2020 to just 47% in 2024. Only three out of ten pregnant women (30%) know their HIV status, resulting in only 36% of an estimated 2,039 pregnant women living with HIV receiving necessary treatment.
The Indispensable Role of Faith and Community
Addressing this crisis requires not just medical facilities, but spiritual and community mobilization. Church leaders and faith-based organizations (FBOs) are critical partners in this response.
The sources confirm that of the nation’s 834 health facilities, 368 (45%) are faith-based health clinics, providing an essential and central partner network.
As Prime Minister Marape noted, the churches are "ever present, serving humanity through healing, education, and care" in every village. They reach people in ways no government agency can easily achieve.
The PNGCLA, under Cardinal Ribat's leadership, has rightly recognized that awareness and testing alone are insufficient. We must heed their call to invest time and resources in addressing the root causes and underlying contributing factors fueling HIV transmission, including poverty, unemployment, gender-based violence, stigma, and discrimination. The PNGCLA’s strategy includes establishing Integrated SME Trainings to alleviate poverty and unemployment for vulnerable populations.
A Whole-of-Society Partnership
The joint presence of the Prime Minister and the Cardinal at the Media Conference highlights the unwavering commitment to a full partnership. The government’s provision of budget allocation for the purchase of antiretroviral drugs is vital for sustaining the health of People living with HIV and prolonging life expectancy. The Government will continue to support the churches’ work on HIV and work closely with the United Nations, and other development partners - while actively engaging community groups and populations most affected by HIV, including people living with HIV - to leverage collective expertise, technical advice, and on-the-ground experience.
This whole-of-society response must involve strong coordination across all sectors. We acknowledge the national commitment to making free HIV testing and treatment available. Services are delivered through a network including more than 400 HIV Testing Sites and 165 HIV Treatment Sites.
Aggressive Prevention and Scale-Up
To halt the crisis, PNG needs to transition to aggressive, proactive prevention actions. The National STI and HIV Strategy 2024-2028 requires an investment of PGK 218 million annually to see PNG back on track to ending the AIDS epidemic as a public health threat.
This investment needs to prioritize comprehensive prevention, focusing on:
1.	Widespread Condom Distribution.
2.	Community-Led HIV Screening (essential to reach the 41% of PLHIV who do not know their status).
3.	Scale-up of Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) (part of the Comprehensive STI & HIV Prevention strategy).
By focusing on early diagnosis, effective treatment, tailored care, and, crucially, tackling the social and economic drivers of vulnerability, we can protect the more than five million young people in PNG who are especially vulnerable.
The unity shown by Prime Minister Marape and Cardinal Ribat is the galvanizing force needed to mobilize the necessary resources and compassion to confront the stigma that isolates and marginalizes people living with HIV.
Together, we can safeguard the future of Papua New Guinea.

Title: Sepik Cocoa Wins Hearts
Content:
Papua New Guinea’s cocoa from the Sepik region has captured the attention of British chocolatiers and specialty buyers, following a two-day cocoa tasting event held in Baimuru Village, Yangoru-Saussia District.
The mini-Cocoa Cupping competition brought together nine UK chocolatiers and importers who sampled chocolates made from 39 cocoa producer submissions from the Greater Sepik region. The visitors praised the beans’ consistent processing and high export-grade quality, signalling a promising future for PNG cocoa in European markets.
Judges from the Cocoa Board of PNG, Rubio Cocoa Plantation and Queen Emma Chocolate Company led the evaluation. Chairperson Kenny Francis said the samples were of impressive quality. “There were no major defects in all the samples,” Francis said. “You should be proud because nearly all cocoa beans are of A-grade export quality.”
British chocolatiers shared similar sentiments. Sophie Jewett from York Cocoa House said she was “very grateful to the people of Sepik” and would gladly use PNG cocoa in her UK factory. Alex O’Connor from Nutricraft House noted that the beans were “smokeless and clean,” reflecting improved post-harvest practices.
The event, hosted by Yekere Cooperative Society with support from the Cocoa Board, FAO’s EU-STREIT PNG Programme, and the International Trade Centre’s UK Trade Partnership (UKTP) Programme, aimed to link local producers directly with international buyers.
UKTP Project Manager for the Pacific, Candice Webb Ungerer, said the goal was to build sustainable partnerships. “The welcome we received was incredible, and this event gave buyers a rare chance to experience so many quality cocoa products in one place,” she said.
The success follows last month’s market-readiness training for 68 Sepik cocoa producers, preparing them for European export standards. The event also sets the stage for the National Cocoa of Excellence and Agri Trade Show planned for 2026 in the Sepik region.

Title: Australia Boosts Workplace Inclusion
Content:
Australia, through the PNGAus Partnership, is helping Papua New Guinean businesses create more inclusive workplaces for people living with disabilities. The initiative, known as EmployAbility, expanded this week with the launch of the EmployAbility Toolkit and Employer Grant Scheme in Port Moresby and Lae.
The Toolkit provides easy-to-use guides to help employers make simple workplace changes that promote accessibility and inclusion. Businesses that adopt the Toolkit can also apply for grants to make practical adjustments and receive expert advice on employing and retaining people with disabilities.
Implemented with the PNG Assembly of Disabled Persons, Business Council of PNG, and Lae Chamber of Commerce, the initiative highlights Australia’s ongoing support for economic empowerment and diversity.
Program participant Samuel Rei said the training boosted his confidence and skills, while BCPNG’s Carmella Gabina and LCCI’s John Byrne praised the Toolkit’s practical benefits for local businesses.

Title: NFA Defends Active Role in Surveillance
Content:
The National Fisheries Authority (NFA), under the Ministry of Fisheries & Marine Resources, has reaffirmed its firm commitment to safeguarding Papua New Guinea’s vast maritime fisheries resources — especially amid recent public commentary about surveillance operations in Manus Province.
In a media statement released today, the NFA clarified that it has not been absent from surveillance operations, contrary to suggestions linked to activities at the Lombrum Naval Base.
The Authority underscored that it has actively taken part in multiple joint surveillance exercises under regional frameworks such as the Pacific Islands Forum Fisheries Agency (FFA) and the Pacific Maritime Security Program (PMSP).
Facing one of the Pacific’s largest Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ), Papua New Guinea’s marine domain spans millions of square kilometres, making the fight against illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing both urgent and complex. The NFA says IUU fishing threatens the country’s food security, economic sovereignty and fisheries sustainability.
The Authority detailed a multi-pronged strategy to strengthen surveillance and enforcement:
- Improved inter-agency coordination and intelligence-sharing via regional partners.
- Investment in advanced monitoring tools, including satellite tracking and real-time catch verification systems.
- Establishment of two forward command bases: one in Daru (Western Province) by Nov 2025 and another in Vanimo   (West Sepik) by the third quarter of 2026.
- Deployment of four new dedicated fisheries patrol vessels, arriving this month, under the command of NFA’s Monitoring, Control and Surveillance (MCS) Unit — a first for PNG’s own national fisheries fleet.
Chartering of offshore patrol vessels for long-range patrols and introduction of new ICT systems for real-time data transmission and vessel reporting.
Community-based fisheries management, public awareness campaigns, and ongoing training for provincial fisheries officers to ensure coastal communities become active stewards of their marine resources.
The NFA emphasised records of inspections, patrols and prosecutions—not just regionally, but nationally—refuting any suggestion of inactivity. The statement urged all agencies and leaders to move forward guided by facts, in genuine collaboration.
The protection of Papua New Guinea’s fisheries, it noted, is a shared responsibility.

Title: Unite Against Digital Violence
Content:
The Department of Personnel Management (DPM) will launch the annual 20 Days of Human Rights Activism Campaign (20 DHRAC) from 20 November to 10 December 2025.
The campaign kicks off in Mt Hagen with the Western Highlands Provincial Government and will involve government agencies, civil society groups, NGOs, faith groups, and individuals.
This year’s theme, “UNITE TO END DIGITAL VIOLENCE AGAINST ALL WOMEN AND GIRLS,” focuses on preventing online harassment and promoting safe digital spaces through stronger laws and accountability.
The national theme, “It’s My Responsibility – Let’s Work Together to Prevent All Forms of Violence,” urges citizens to take personal responsibility to eliminate violence against women and girls, both online and offline.
Key observances during the campaign include International Children’s Day (20 Nov), International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women (25 Nov), World AIDS Day (1 Dec), and International Human Rights Day (9 Dec).
DPM Secretary Taies Sansan said public servants must lead by example in promoting respect, equality, and accountability in workplaces and communities.

Title: Cadet officers arrest serving officer
Content:
Police Commissioner, David Manning has commended two RPNGC Cadet Officers for arresting a serving police officer for soliciting a bribe.
The arrest took place after an off-duty officer was observed attempting to extort money from the family of a man who was in custody in relation to a vehicle accident.
"These two young Police Cadet Officers are exactly the kind of police that Papua New Guineans want on the frontline as we rebuild the RPCNG to the level it was founded upon," Commissioner Manning said.
"Their action in standing up to corruption is a testament to their training and their character.
"The strength of character of our police cadets, and the professional education they receive through our training program ensures that these young leaders are not tempted by corruption or unprofessional behaviour,” he said.
Commissioner Manning said the police cadets made the arrest and detained the accused at the Badili police cells on the 3rd of November.
"The accused member, who was off-duty at the time, was observed demanding money from the family of a man who had been detained.
"When the money was handed to and accepted by the member, two cadet officers acted quickly to arrest and lock the officer in cell.
"That was a job well done by these young policemen, and it bodes well for a bright future in the RPNGC for them both."
The Internal Affairs Division responded and obtained evidence and witness statements.
The accused member has been suspended from the RPNGC, will be charged and taken through both disciplinary and criminal channels, pending the outcome of the Internal Affairs report.

Title: Man arrested for possessing unlicensed firearm
Content:
Police in North Fly, Western province arrested a 34-year-old man for illegally buying eagle wood and for being in possession of unlicensed firearms. The suspect is from Merauke in the Muting District of Indonesia.
North Fly Acting Provincial Police Commander (PPC), Inspector Anjap Minata said the named suspect was arrested at Nomand station in Middle Fly District on Tuesday, November 4, 2025, following a tip-off that the suspect was buying eagle wood.
PPC Minata said the suspect was arrested by the police personnel who were providing security during the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections.
The PPC said police further questioned the suspect and found out he had been in the country for almost six months buying eagle wood.
PPC Minata confirmed that the suspect had no business permit to operate and buy eagle wood in PNG and was illegally operating his businesses.
He added that the suspect, in the pretext of buying eagle wood, also brought five rifles (cease gun) into the country and sold four to the locals. During the arrest, police discovered one rifle in his possession.
The suspect was brought into the Kiunga police station to effect his arrest under the PNG appropriate laws. It was further alleged that the suspect got entry from the border, especially Fly Zebo LLG area.
Police are currently investigating how many rifles were brought into the country and to establish facts into any other deals in place. The suspect will be charged with being in possession of unlicensed firearms.
“The police are now appealing to the locals who bought those rifles from him to immediately surrender to the police,” PPC Minata said. “You are illegally in possession of them.”
“We have good law-abiding (citizens) in the province and with their support, the police will come to you,” PPC Minata said.
PPC also warned locals living along border villages to be mindful of who they are doing business with, either domestically or internationally.

Title: Eight rescued, ring leader arrested
Content:
Lae police rescued eight passengers, including a baby, off the coast of Busu River on November 4 following an alleged attack by sea pirates.
Lae Water Police promptly rescued the victims and arrested the criminal ringleader, who is now in custody, after being shot. Seven co-offenders have been identified and are being pursued by police.
"Police allege that the suspects chased and shot at the victim's boat, injuring the skipper and forcing the boat to stop. The suspects assaulted three male passengers with bush knives and stole cash from the victims before fleeing,” says Police Commissioner David Manning.
"It is further alleged that the suspects returned, deliberately ramming into the victims' boat, causing it to capsize and sink.
"Eight passengers, including a baby, were abandoned and left struggling in the sea by these opportunist criminals.
"Witnesses alerted Water Police, who immediately responded and rescued all passengers," he said.
The Commissioner said following the rescue, police took swift action to identify the suspects and begin to track them down.
"From initial investigations, it was expected that the prime suspect would return to sea, so police conducted a stakeout operation and the ringleader was captured and arrested.
"The suspect attempted to escape, during which he was shot in the leg, and was transported to the ANGAU Hospital Emergency Ward for medical attention.
"An operation is underway to arrest and charge the remaining seven accomplices now that the leader of their group has been locked up.
"I warn anyone trying to help the suspects that they will be treated just the same by police.
"It makes everyone so furious to hear such deplorable and violent actions, and I thank the Lae Water Police for their swift action to save lives and track down the criminals," the Commissioner said.

Title: Minister directs for digital registration of health workers
Content:
Minister for Health Elias Kapavore, has directed the National Department of Health (NDoH) to move to digital registration of health workers in the country, by June 2026.
Speaking at a recent workshop on Digital Health Workers’ Registration, this week, Minister Kapavore said that digital registration of all cadres of health workers is a matter of critical concern which is long overdue.
“We can't continue the manual registration of health workers,” the minister said.
The minister said he wants the manual registration of health workers to cease immediately and the department to establish efficient human resource (HR) data to reflect the changing digital age.
“The country celebrated 50 years of independence this year. Hence, we must remain relevant with human resources information system to complement the National Health information data base”, he stated.
He related to the PNG University of Medicine and Health Sciences Bill recently passed in Parliament, to be aimed at increasing enrolment to meet the health workforce gap.
“This arrangement will complement the recently approved Health Services Commission arrangement,” he stated.
“These are key revolutionary and milestone strategies must now pave the way and set the scene for a modernised health sector workforce in Papua New Guinea for the next fifty years.
“Everyone coming out of the health training institutions must be posted to a position that is waiting for them. No more advertisement, no more going to DPM,” said Kapavore.
He acknowledged development partners including Australia government, World Health Organisation and others that continue to provide capacity building support for the country’s health work force.
“My aim now is to establish a Health Service Commission – just like the Teaching Service Commission, where all health workers, upon graduation, are directly deployed to all Provincial Health Authorities (PHAs} in the country, rather than having to wait for Department of Personnel Management to give approvals.
“The Marape-led government is committed to supporting health.
“It is now up to us to create the agenda and come up with the priorities with specifications and seek support.

Title: RPNGC inks deal with New Ireland
Content:
The New Ireland Provincial Government (NIPG) and the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) have entered into a partnership that will see the Police Reservist Training Program conducted New Ireland Province.
A Memorandum of Agreement (MoA) formalizing the partnership was signed on November 5, 2025 at the RPNGC Headquarters in Konedobu, Port Moresby, by Commissioner of Police David Manning, New Ireland Governor Walter Schnaubelt, Provincial Administrator Richard Andia, and the Deputy Commissioner of Administration.
The agreement marks a major milestone in strengthening collaboration between the RPNGC and NIPG to improve law and order, enhance community safety, and build local policing capacity in the province.
Under the MoA, the RPNGC will deliver a comprehensive reservist training program to equip selected participants with essential policing knowledge, skills, and ethical standards. Once trained, the reservists will operate as an extension of the RPNGC, particularly in rural and remote areas where regular police presence is limited.
Schnaubelt expressed his appreciation to Commissioner Manning and the Minister for Police, Peter Tsiamalili Jr. for their continued leadership in strengthening community policing initiatives nationwide.
“This is a timely and strategic move to empower our communities to take ownership of their safety and work hand in hand with law enforcement authorities,” Schnaubelt said.
“As provincial leaders, we are always seeking ways to engage our youth in positive and meaningful activities. Partnering with the RPNGC allows us to address manpower challenges in policing while creating opportunities for young people to contribute to their communities.”
Schnaubelt further noted that the program will serve as a potential pathway for capable reservists to transition into full-time police careers, further strengthening the province’s policing capacity.
Commissioner of Police David Manning commended the New Ireland Provincial Government for its leadership and proactive approach to supporting community policing.
“This program will not only expand our operational reach but also strengthen trust and cooperation between the police and the people,” Commissioner Manning said during the MoA signing.
“Our greatest challenge continues to be manpower shortages. Through this initiative, we aim to establish 200 reservists in each province to enhance our visibility and presence within communities. This MoA with New Ireland brings that vision closer to reality.”
Manning added that following the initial training phase, a tripartite MoA will be signed with the training service provider to ensure reservists are effectively trained, managed, and utilised.
Recruitment and selection of the first 200 reservists in New Ireland Province which will be sourced from the two districts of Kavieng and Namatanai will begin shortly, with training expected to commence next year. The program will be conducted annually to build and maintain a strong reserve force that supports the RPNGC’s community policing objectives.
This initiative forms part of a broader national and provincial government commitment to restore law and order, promote peace, and foster social and economic development across the country.
Meanwhile, a further recruitment and training of Community Auxiliary Police (CAP) has also been mooted recently by the Provincial Law and Order Committee chaired by Schnaubelt, for 142 council wards in the 10 LLGs of New Ireland, which the provincial government and the two district DDAs will consider appropriating funding for the CAP at the ward level.

Title: Nomane raises concerns over delayed Wafi-Golpu mine
Content:
Member for Chuave, James Nomane has voiced significant concerns about Prime Minister James Marape's handling of the Wafi-Golpu deal, suggesting that the delays highlight a lack of strategic leadership.
Nomane criticized the Marape government for being "long on rhetoric but short on delivery," arguing that this approach is having detrimental effects on investor confidence and creating unrest among landowners.
He emphasized that these issues could lead Papua New Guinea (PNG) to miss out on billions in potential revenue.
“This protracted delay is a disgrace, and a betrayal of the people of Morobe, who were promised jobs, royalties, and infrastructure.
“The Wafi-Golpu project is projected to produce 266,000 ounces of gold and 161,000 tonnes of copper annually, with a 17 million tonne per annum processing capacity. Yet under Marape’s watch, this economic engine remains idle.
“The Prime Minister must own up and resign for being unable to deliver Wafi-Golpu.”
Nomane also pointed to the potential grey listing of PNG as a serious warning sign, suggesting that the country is facing increased scrutiny and risks to its economic stability.
He argued that under Marape's leadership, conditions are likely to deteriorate further, which could have serious implications for the nation's economic future.

Title: SHTC graduates 14th batch of 111 teachers
Content:
One hundred and eleven new teachers are job-ready following the completion of their diploma program at the Sacred Heart Teacher’s College in Bomana, Port Moresby. The young men and women joyfully received their teaching diplomas at the 14th graduation ceremony today.
While the initial purpose of establishing the Sacred Heart Teachers College was to train young men and women from the remote Goilala District of Central Province to go and teach there, it had opened its doors to the rest of the country as time went by and today’ graduation saw students from all parts of PNG graduating as qualified teachers.
Significant on this occasion where the awarding of special prices including the Australia Awards to those students who where sponsored directly by PNG-Australia Awards. President of the School and the co-valedictorian, Ronson Lasia was awarded for his leadership Bridgette Efi, also for her leadership representing females.
There were 19 students who were sponsored under the PNG-Australia Awards, 13 of whom were female.

Title: MPs urged to make decisions that best serve the country
Content:
Members of Parliament must make their decisions based on who they believe would best serve the country’s interests.
Prime Minister James Marape made these remarks in the wake of another unsuccessful attempt by the Opposition to file a motion of no confidence against his leadership during the last session of Parliament.
“You have seen me run government for six years. Mr O’Neill has run government for eight years. Our MPs are not naïve — they see the character, leadership style, and performance of both leaders up close. They will decide what is good for the country,” he said.
Marape emphasized that Members of Parliament should prioritize the country’s interests when making their decisions, especially in the context of ongoing political challenges.
“I told my Members of Parliament — you decide for yourself. If you believe Mr. O’Neill is the better leader, you can vote for him. If you believe I should continue, then stand with me. That is democracy.”
The Prime Minister’s statement reflects a call for unity and focus on governance despite political rivalries, urging MPs to consider the broader implications of their actions on the nation.
He said his commitment to navigating the political landscape while advocating for policies that serve the welfare of the people of Papua New Guinea remains paramount.
Marape also called on aspiring leaders to prepare for the 2027 National Elections, which are only 14 months away.
“Start building your parties, prepare your campaign, and earn the people’s trust,” he said.
“If you are trusted by the people, you will receive a Section 63 invitation to form government after the elections. That is the safest and most legitimate path to leadership — not through shortcuts, disruptions, or political hypnosis that disturbs the nation’s progress.”

Title: Future Doctors Receive High Tech Support
Content:
Future doctors in Papua New Guinea are set to receive a major boost in their training, thanks to a generous donation from Ok Tedi Mining Limited. On October 13th, the company presented K419,939.77 to the University of Papua New Guinea’s School of Medicine and Health Sciences.
The funds will be used to purchase High-Definition Virtual Anatomy Tables—state-of-the-art, interactive platforms that allow students to explore the human body in 3D. This technology offers a dynamic, immersive alternative to traditional cadaver-based learning.
Ok Tedi’s Manager of Government and External Relations, Martin Paining Junior, said the donation reflects the company’s long-term commitment to education and healthcare in PNG. “By supporting our future doctors, we are helping improve healthcare for every Papua New Guinean, including the 98 per cent of Ok Tedi’s workforce,” he said.
Dean of the medical school, Professor Nakapi Tefuarani, welcomed the support, noting that the new tables will also help the school advance toward digital surgery training. The equipment is expected to be installed in 2026, benefiting hundreds of students in years to come.
