This donation forms part of Ok Tedi’s broader community investment strategy, which focuses on education, health, infrastructure, and sustainable development across Western Province and Papua New Guinea.

Title: PNG’s Orchid Wonderland Opens
Content:
Port Moresby Nature Park has unveiled a breathtaking new orchid garden, offering visitors a journey through Papua New Guinea’s rich natural and cultural heritage.
The garden officially opened to the public on Saturday, November 1, 2025, after months of renovation and careful planning.
Designed to showcase the country’s diverse regions, the garden features unique orchids and cultural artefacts from the Highlands, Islands, Southern, and Momase regions. Highlights include striking totem poles, highland ornaments, and the famous lakatoi from Rea Rea village.
Park members enjoyed an exclusive guided tour by Conservation Manager Francis Gundu, who shared the history and cultural significance of each display.
Visitors also explored a permaculture section, offering practical lessons in sustainable gardening, and a serene pond area, perfect for relaxation.
The project was made possible through sponsorship from Santos, with support from TotalEnergies, Rotary International, Paga Hill Estate, Royal Papua Yacht Club, OM Holdings Ltd, and the Government of Ireland International Development Programme.
The garden is now open daily from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., welcoming both locals and tourists to experience PNG’s beauty.

Title: Early Childhood Teachers Monitored & Assessed
Content:
For the first time this year, trainers from ‘Skelim Save’ visited early childhood centres across the country to monitor and assess teachers who recently completed their training under the Early Childhood Education (ECE) program supported by the NCD Governor, Powes Parkop.
Head trainer Gibson Daniels, who leads the Highlands Zone team, said the visit to Tutu Beach Early Childhood Learning Centre aimed to observe how teachers applied what they learned in the classroom. He explained that training and implementation are different stages and both need to be checked to improve quality learning for children.
“We monitor and check how our teachers are performing and how students are learning. This helps us see what is working and what needs improvement,” Daniels said.
He said Skelim Save has established over 110 early childhood schools across eight provinces, including East New Britain, Bougainville, and the Highlands, and is now expanding into the Momase region.
Mr. Daniels was pleased with the teachers’ classroom management, behaviour handling, and the children’s English-speaking ability. Despite some minor challenges due to timing, he praised the teachers’ dedication and creativity.
He said all evaluation results will be sent to their Australian coordinator, to help improve future programs.
“If we have better brains, we’ll have a better future,” Daniels said. “That starts with strong early childhood education.”

Title: Dr Billy blames SHPG for polling delay
Content:
Member for Nipa Kutubu and Minister for Defence Dr. Billy Joseph has clarified that the delay in polling for the current LLG elections and related problems happening in Nipa is not a result of the alleged discrepancies in the common roll as claimed by the Governor of Southern Highlands Province (SHP), William Powi.
“It is a pity the constitutional rights of the people of the newly created Upper Nipa LLG and certain wards of the Nipa Basin LLG to vote and elect their ward councilors in the current LLG elections continue to be denied and held at hostage by certain individuals with vested political interests,” Dr. Billy said.
He said the breakdown of law and order in Nipa District is due to the lack of support by the provincial administration and police to the PNG Electoral Commission (PNGEC), accusing them of compromising on their constitutional responsibilities.
“It’s serious a constitutional process set into motion by law is allowed to be sabotaged by mobs and thugs under the watchful eyes of the agencies who should be protecting the process to complete,” Dr. Billy said.
The minister further claimed that provincial administration officials and police in Mendi were operating at the behest of someone and driving the political agendas of certain individuals.
Provincial Administrator David Kelma denied these claims, saying the SHP government and a few district development authorities supported the national government through the PNGEC by making funds available to conduct the LLG election in the province.
“My office in consultation with PNGEC has strongly recommended for LLG managers to assist the commission as ARO and they did a fantastic job and almost 85% of polling in the 5 districts were peacefully done followed by counting and declaration.
“We get such results when public servants are involved to take the lead as ROs and AROs.
“Thus, our politicians must have respect for public servants who are the core group of people who always stand ready to deliver government programs and policy,” the administrator said.
Kelma also defended the work of SHP police, commending them for ensuring elections ran smoothly.
“Mendi police personnel did exceptionally well in providing security for smooth polling in the province. Polling cannot be conducted in some places in my province without police. Their presence in a ward plays a significant role,” Kelma added.
Meantime, Dr Billy said he has reached out to the Commissioner of Police and other relevant authorities to ensure the conduct of individuals in this mayhem come under scrutiny.
“A formal police complaint has been laid with the Commissioner of Police at the police HQ in Konedobu and this requires police to call up the perpetrators and ring leaders to be arrested,” Minister Joseph said.
He said the problems in Nipa now are caused by ingenuine people who are hellbent on defying the lawful instruction of the PNG Electoral Commission to fail the LLG election.
He urged the PPC Southern Highlands to act on the reports submitted to his office and do his job by arresting the thugs and their ring leaders to ensure the 2025 LLG elections come to a successful conclusion.
He concluded that the 2025 rolls update was a constitutional process fulfilled by the PNGEC and any matters arising out of this process must be addressed and corrected through the same process or the courts.

Title: Joint Naval Exercise Strengthens Partnership
Content:
The Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) and the Australian Defence Force (ADF) have completed a major joint maritime exercise aimed at strengthening regional security and defence cooperation.
Exercise Paradise 2025, held from 21–24 October in Papua New Guinea, saw the PNGDF’s HMPNGS Ted Diro and ADF’s HMAS Albany carry out combined maritime surveillance, coordinated patrols, and seamanship training. The joint operation also included safety of life at sea drills and search and rescue exercises.
Australia’s Chief of Navy, Vice Admiral Mark Hammond, said the exercise is part of the long-standing Defence Cooperation Program between both nations, the largest in the Pacific.
“Bilateral defence training like Exercise Paradise strengthens our strategic partnership with Papua New Guinea and enhances our shared maritime security,” said VADM Hammond. “It helps us respond together to challenges such as illegal fishing and transnational crime.”
Commanding Officer of HMAS Albany, Lieutenant Commander Phil Wager, said the training featured realistic scenarios that tested both crews’ readiness and teamwork.
“We always enjoy training alongside our PNG friends in areas like border security, fisheries protection, and search and rescue,” he said.
HMPNGS Ted Diro, one of four Guardian-class patrol boats delivered to PNG under Australia’s Pacific Maritime Security Program, continues to play a key role in these exercises.
Future collaborations, including Exercise Paradise 2026, will further strengthen the partnership between PNGDF and ADF, improving interoperability and joint capability in the Pacific region.

Title: Presiding Officer arrested for election fraud
Content:
A Presiding Officer in Madang has been arrested for keeping in his possession unused ballot papers and other election materials during the Madang Urban Local Level Government (MULLG) election counting yesterday.
The Presiding Officer was part of Team 63 during the polling period.
After countless suspicious acts over the few days, he was reported and picked up by police personnel at the counting centre at the Marape Hall of Tusbab Secondary School.
Police after searching him, found in his possession ballot paper butts, ballot papers, and polling journals in his bag.
Provincial Police Commander Superintendent Robert Baim said scrutineers at the counting venue became suspicious about his behavior after monitoring him for the past four days at the counting venue.
He also had a heated argument with another polling official after the polling official accused him of being on the phone the whole day when he was not supposed to and also for continuously checking figures of counted mayor seat votes from the tally booth.
His suspicious behavior led members of the National Criminal Intelligence and Transnational Crime Unit in the province to conduct a search on him.
Superintendent Baim confirmed the arrest overnight stating that the officer is detained at Jomba Police station and will be charged under the Election-Related Offenses Act.
Baim added this case serves as a warning to polling officials to carry out their duties diligently and honestly.
“Every eye is on them and that police will not tolerate any attempt to cheat or interfere with the democratic process,” he warned.
Superintendent Baim also noted that the presiding officer was allegedly working with certain candidates to influence the counting process for the Madang Urban Mayor seat and that investigations are continuing to identify others who may be involved.
“Counting for the MULLG election is continuing under tight police security to ensure transparency and fairness, and public officials should stay vigilant as police investigate further,” PPC Baim added.
Meanwhile, no additional details will be revealed at this stage to protect the integrity of the investigation and the electoral process.
However, for further updates, candidates are advised to contact the public relations office of the Madang Police Command.
“Madang police are operating within the constraints of our available resources. We are committed to using every resource at our disposal to support the democratic process and public safety. It is important to note that all election-related matters remain the responsibility of the Electoral Commission. Our role as police is to provide security for polling officials and materials, in accordance with the funds and resources allocated to us,” PPC Baim added.
Superintendent Baim also expressed his appreciation to the officers across the province fr their efforts in ensuring elections are conducted peacefully in Madang.
“We are here to serve – with or without resources. Our commitment to safeguarding the public, ensuring the safety of polling officials, and protecting election materials remains unwavering,” Baim stressed.

Title: LLG elections near completion
Content:
The LLG elections around the country are in the final stage of polling and counting. Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai said his office is committed to fulfilling its constitutional mandate by delivering free, fair and credible LLG elections for the country.
“I want to assure all citizens, and our key stakeholders which includes: Department of Provincial and Local Government Affairs, Inter-Department Election Committee, and Provincial Administrations that the election is progressing smoothly despite challenges, with polling nearing completion in every district and province in the country,” he said.
Mr Sinai said those districts that have completed polling have gone into counting with declarations of winners made so far in some Wards and LLGs as counting progresses.
He said LLG elections have been always challenging because of the local settings as it involves family members and tribesmen, resulting in family conflicts and disagreements.
“This is where LLG elections are always challenging. Sometimes our polling teams will have to walk miles down the valleys, climb the mountains and cross the rivers to reach the most isolated villages and hamlets in the country with the ballot papers, to give our people the opportunity to vote. The story is the same for people living on the coast, where polling officials have to hop on canoes and dinghies to reach the remote islands villages to conduct polling,” said Mr Sinai.
For the Highlands Region and Morobe Province, Mr Sinai said the LLG president seat will be contested by Ward members in the council chamber through normal lobbying process and whoever has the majority support will get elected as the LLG president. For the coastal provinces, the ward councilors and LLG president will be elected directly by the people through the normal LPV counting process.
The Electoral Commissioner assured the people and especially the Minister for Provincial and Local Government Affairs and Minister responsible for the LLG Elections Soroi Eoe MP that the election remains on schedule and the writs would be returned on time.
The writs are set to be returned on or before November 21, 2025.

Title: Jiwaka LLG elections conducted peacefully
Content:
Local Level Government elections in Jiwaka were conducted peacefully despite minor issues that were managed by the police and election officials including an illegal road block.
Jiwaka Provincial Police Commander (PPC), Acting Superintendent Laimo Asi said voters behaved well from day one till the end of the polling and elected their leaders through the democratic process.
He said polling in Minj and Banz started on Tuesday, 28 October 2025 and continued to the next day, whilst other LLGs went to the polls on Thursday and Friday.
PPC Asi said Jimmy District had theirs on Friday, October 31 and completed on Saturday, 01st November. He said all ballot boxes were brought into Minj town for counting.
“We are now complete and ready for counting, except Anglimp and Kona Komuz, as these are two new LLGs within Anglimp South Waghi District that are still under dispute,” he said.
PPC Asi said so far so good as they have not received reports of any deaths or serious incident except a few ballot boxes reported destroyed.

Title: Teachers gain counselling skills
Content:
In Northern Province, 24 teachers have completed the region’s first-ever counselling training under the ‘Sanap Strong’ initiative, a partnership between Kokoda Track Foundation (KTF) and the National Department of Education (NDoE) Guidance and Counselling Division.
The two-week training equipped teachers with vital counselling skills, knowledge, and strategies to support over 13,000 students across districts in the province. The initiative aims to strengthen child protection and gender-based violence prevention in schools and communities.
Facilitated by the First Assistant Secretary for the Guidance and Counselling Division Philip So’on, alongside experienced trainers, the course focused on crisis response, emotional support, and referral pathways for those experiencing distress or violence.
Assistant Secretary Allan Jim commended the initiative, saying the training empowered teachers to identify student problems, apply counselling methods, and guide students toward safe solutions through proper referral pathways.
KTF CEO Dr. Genevieve Nelson said the program connects schools—home to some of PNG’s most vulnerable populations—with social welfare and protection services, empowering teachers as “frontline professionals to better prevent and respond to violence.”
The closing ceremony was attended by the Northern Governor Gary Juffa, who reaffirmed the government’s support to integrate counselling into the education system and praised the teachers’ dedication.
Surveys showed 85% of participants strongly agreed the course improved their understanding of trauma, communication, and student care.
Through this landmark partnership, Northern Province has set a national precedent for bridging education and social welfare to build safer and more supportive school environments.

Title: Juha LOs oppose DPE gazettal notice
Content:
Land owning groups in the Juha Petroleum Development License 09 in the Hela Province have a submitted a letter of objection to the Department of Petroleum and Energy over a published Gazette #1086.
The objection letter pointed out that the Ministerial Determination that allocates Juha PDL 9 benefits to Western Province is unlawful.
The Juha landowners highlighted three grounds in the objection letter.
First, the PDL 9 landowners claim they are the 100% legitimate resource owners of the project impact area in the PNG LNG Project under the Topi and Umimi Council Wards in the Koroba LLG, Koroba District of Hela Province.
They believe this area concerns them and there is no customary claim by landowners in Western Province over this area.
The PDL 9 landowners also highlighted that there are false beneficiary allocation in the gazette notice which 80% of benefits diverted to Western Province.
The Juha clans from Hela brushed aside claims by Chief John Wabi Sala which they describe as false, misleading and incorrect.
Furthermore, the PDL9 faction believe the project area is within their land boundary under the stewardship of the Sinali tribe of Hela.
The last point in the objection letter is compromised coordination.
The landowners claimed that the Juha PDL 09 Coordinator compromised the integrity of the Landowner Identification process.
They believe this has resulted in misrepresentation of landownership and unjust allocation of benefits.
The Juha PDL 09 faction say the Gazette was published without proper consultation between the concern stakeholders, verification of land titles and acknowledgment of legitimate landowners.
They are now calling on the Department of Petroleum and Energy to consider their submission and retract the Gazette Notice and work with them for the good of the impacted communities.

Title: Ela Motors employee arrested for theft
Content:
An ongoing investigation by the Hohola Minor Crimes Division has led to the arrest of an Ela Motors employee and the recovery of nine outboard motors.
Metropolitan Superintendent of National Capital District, Warrick Simatab confirmed that the investigators from Hohola Minor Crimes had recovered a total of nine outboard motors at Fishermen Island and are now being kept as exhibits.
Police claim that the offense was committed between October 2024 and August 2025, when the employee allegedly conspired with villagers from Fishermen Island and sold the outboard motors to them.
After the arrest of the suspect in September, police officers worked diligently to locate the stolen outboard motors, which included eight 40-horsepower engines and two 15-horsepower engines. Eight of them were recovered at Fishermen Island today and are now stored as exhibits to be presented in court.
"I want to thank the police officers from Hohola and the Water Police team who worked together to recover the outboard motors and brought them in for further police investigation. I also want to thank the community leaders who assisted in providing information about the whereabouts of the stolen items that led to their recovery. I want to encourage the community to work closely with the police by providing information about stolen items, information on criminals, and other community awareness programs. This will lead to making communities safer for everyone," Simatab said.
Simatab says investigations into how these outboard motors were stolen is progressing well.

Title: NGO Provides Free Legal Support to GBV Survivors
Content:
A gender-based violence (GBV) initiative in Papua New Guinea is making strides by training communities and providing free legal services to victims, combining awareness with access to justice in a country where violence remains a pressing issue.
GBV continues to affect thousands of families across PNG, but Regina Sagu Foundation, a community-based, non-government organisation, is working to change that narrative. Through targeted workshops and legal support, the initiative reached more than 700 individuals in 2024, empowering communities to recognize abuse and seek justice.
The workshops engaged diverse groups, including secondary school teachers, market vendors, and youth organisations. In Enga Province, 384 participants attended GBV awareness sessions, while 75 people joined similar programs in Port Moresby. Partnerships with businesses such as Trans Wonderland and plans to involve Digicel Cup sports teams aim to extend advocacy into workplaces and sporting communities—spaces where exposure to violence is often high.
“We believe sports teams are key influencers,” said Legal Program Officer Tommy Aiyok. “Many players and fans have either experienced or witnessed violence. Bringing GBV education into these circles can create ripple effects.”
Beyond education, the initiative offers free legal assistance to GBV survivors—a critical service in a country where access to justice can be slow and costly. Supported by three full-time lawyers, the program helps victims obtain interim and permanent protection orders, ensuring immediate safety and long-term security.
“Violence can only be stopped when an order is in place,” said Mr. Aiyok. “Our goal is to make justice swift and accessible.”
Currently, the team is developing a case management system to streamline support for walk-in clients and referrals, aiming to reduce turnaround time for court orders to five days, a significant improvement compared to typical delays.
The program works closely with the Enga Provincial Administration and civil society organizations, responding to invitations for community workshops and school talks.
Plans for 2025 include expanding outreach to sports communities and strengthening collaboration with NGOs to scale legal services nationwide.
Mr. Aiyok stressed that their mission goes beyond advocacy.
“We’re not just raising awareness; we’re providing solutions. Safety and justice must go hand in hand.”
The initiative was showcased under the theme “Safe Spaces, Strong Voices” during the Australian Broadcasting Corporation International Development Papua New Guinea Media Development Initiative (ABCID PNG-MDI) event on 24 October at Lamana Hotel, Port Moresby.
The event brought together media professionals and civil society organizations working to address violence, reintegration, and community healing—underscoring the Foundation’s commitment to Justice Sagu’s legacy of empowering communities through literacy, safety, and legal support.

Title: Indigenous Values Vital to Guide PNG’s Fight Against Corruption
Content:
Papua New Guinea’s anti-corruption drive has faced a major setback after its flagship agency, the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC), faced challenges amid internal scandals — a crisis that governance expert Yuambari Haihuie says highlights the need for culturally grounded solutions, not just technology.
The ICAC, launched in 2023 under Prime Minister James Marape’s reform agenda, was intended to restore public trust. But less than two years later, its three inaugural commissioners — all expatriates — were suspended following allegations of misconduct, including unilateral decision-making and unauthorized expenses.
Haihuie, a former deputy director at Transparency International PNG and now a public policy scholar at ANU, argues that PNG’s fight against corruption cannot succeed by isolating cultural norms such as the wantok system and “big man” leadership. Instead, he says, these traditions should be harnessed to build alliances and strengthen accountability.
He is concerned that the lack of performance by this newly established constitutional office has frustrated taxpayers, with 51.4 million kina (US$12.2 million) allocated to ICAC in the 2025 budget. It also threatens PNG’s IMF-backed economic reforms and anti-money-laundering commitments, raising fears of grey-listing by the Financial Action Task Force — a move that could cripple foreign investment and increase borrowing costs.
Marape has announced plans to use artificial intelligence in governance, including public appointments and procurement. But Haihuie warns that technology alone cannot resolve issues rooted in PNG’s political and cultural fabric. “AI can support transparency, but real reform must draw on cultural values of reciprocity and obligation,” he says.
As investigations continue, Papua New Guineans are demanding results. With the nation marking 50 years of independence, the ICAC saga has become a defining test of whether PNG can overcome entrenched corruption and deliver on its promise of good governance.

Title: PNG Forest Governance Questioned ahead of COP30 Summit
Content:
Act Now campaign manager, Eddie Tanago Paine is appalled at how the Prime Minister will go advocate at COP30 in Brazil to protect forests when it’s a different story back in the country.
Eddie has been vocal about the abuse of Forest Clearing Authorities (FCAs) by logging companies in PNG where 1.68 million hectares of forests are currently under threat from FCAs.
He says despite a moratorium on new FCA licenses, the National Forest Board has not publicly made available the promised audit reports on existing FCA projects and logs are still being exported.
He is accusing the National Forest Board and the PNG Forest Authority’s lack of effectiveness back home, contradicting the Prime Minister’s commitments to protect forests at the COP 30 meeting in Brazil.
In stating facts, he said in 2024, there were 18 operational FCA logging projects that produced over 500,000 cubic metres of timber for export to China. The logs were valued at over K200 million (US$50 million). Five of the FCA projects operating in 2024 only started operations after the NFB imposed its moratorium.
He is concerned that there is a breakdown in governance in the forest sector because of a failure in leadership.
Further compounding evidences underlines the lack of governance in the sector. The Bank of PNG’s national risk assessment places the logging sector as ‘high risk’ for money laundering yet the lack of enforcement action by the authorities will largely contribute to PNGs’ grey listing come 2026.

Title: New Honey Processing Plant for EHP Farmers
Content:
Honey production in Papua New Guinea has received a major boost following the launch of a new state-of-the-art honey processing plant in the Eastern Highlands Province — the country’s leading honey-producing region.
Founder and owner of Helping Hand Honey Producers (HHHP) Kelly Inaie, expressed deep appreciation for the K181,504 funding assistance his company received from the World Bank through the National Government, under the PNG Agriculture Commercialization and Diversification (PACD) Program managed by the Coffee Industry Corporation (CIC).
The total funding package worth K1.7 million was distributed among 10 selected honey bee farmers across the Highlands region — including four from Eastern Highlands, three from Simbu, two from Jiwaka, and one from Western Highlands.
Mr. Inaie said the new processing facility will not only improve honey quality and production but will also include storage space, a training venue, and conference facilities to train and empower local beekeepers.
“This is a milestone achievement for my company and for all local honey farmers. With this funding, we can produce quality honey and also train others to do the same,” Inaie said.
The Department of Agriculture and Livestock recognized HHHP’s contribution to PNG’s honey industry and commended Inaie’s ongoing commitment to empowering smallholder farmers.
Mr. Inaie has also represented Papua New Guinea at international honey conferences in Fiji and the Philippines, and his contributions to agriculture and entrepreneurship have earned him several awards — including the 2019 Digicel Man of Honor Award, 2020 PNG SME Award (Runner-up), and the 2021 United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) Award for the East Asia Pacific Young Entrepreneur.
He successfully met 10 of the 17 UN SDGs, making him one of the few Papua New Guineans recognized internationally for sustainable business practices.
Mr. Inaie thanked the CIC PACD, World Bank, and the PNG Government for their continued support in strengthening honey production and improving livelihoods for rural farmers.

Title: Sungi outlines positive impact from COP29 boycott
Content:
Acting Managing Director for Climate Change Development Adaptation (CCDA), Debra Sungi says the action of Prime Minister James Marape in not attending COP meetings in the past in protest over the lack of action by the big players in the Climate Change space has indeed made positive difference in getting the attention of developed countries.
Sungi said when PNG did not participate at the COP29 last year, it sent a very strong message to the global community that PNG is tired of just going there and sitting in negotiations yet not seeing any benefit for the country.
She said this action has resulted in a positive outcome with the Green Climate Fund board meeting hosted Port Moresby this year and fundings endorsed for the REDD+ program.
“Green Climate fund is the biggest financial mechanism established under the UN Convention on Climate Change and that’s where the COP process is. And they have, for the first time, endorsed and given to Papua New Guinea USD63.4million for REDD+ after so many years of discussions and that political message is strong, as we’ve seen,” she said.
Sungi explained that the significance of hosting this year’s COP meeting in Belem, Brazil is because that is where the Amazon Forest is, and given that PNG is also the third largest tropical rain forest country in the world, Prime Minister will be taking the delegation to the COP30 to make a very strong statement in terms of ensuring that PNG must be paid for preserving forests.
She added that with this COP, all forest nations have rallied together, led by the Brazilian government to with the aim to good outcomes from the leaders’ summit that would be hosted on the 6th and 7th November, 12025.
She said given that Papua New Guinea has almost 35 million hectares of forest cover intact, this is a good opportunity for PNG with the Prime Minister taking the lead to give a very clear message to the leaders of the developed countries to really see the importance of forest and make very strong commitments.
Apart from the forest, PNG also has the NDCs (Nationally Determined Contributions) commitment and the global stock take that will be be done.
To contribute to these discussions, PNG will talk about is blue carbon solutions. The PM had already announced at the margins of the UN General Assembly, where there was a climate summit for the leaders and PNG’s commitment in terms of blue carbon solutions.
“So with that commitment there’s a strong message we will deliver as well in terms of scaling up finance for implementation of NDCs,” said Sungi.
Sungi re-iterated that the key message which the Prime Minister and his team together with the leaders from the smaller Pacific Island nations will be emphasizing at the COP, is the climate funding commitment set at the Paris agreement which has not been achieved.
“The call to have the USD1.3 trillion as of last year is a commitment and we need action.” She said.

Title: PNG hosts PILON meeting successfully
Content:
Papua New Guinea successfully hosted the 44th Pacific Islands Law Officers’ Network (PILON) meeting from the 27–31 October 2025 at APEC Haus in Port Moresby, drawing more than 90 delegates from across the Pacific, including Australia and New Zealand.
PILON is a regional network of senior law officers committed to strengthening legal cooperation, sharing best practices, and advancing law and justice priorities. This year’s theme, “Yumi Wok Wantaim: A Safe, Secure & Peaceful Pacific,” focused on gender-based violence, anti-corruption, and cybercrime, with expert presentations and collaborative dialogues.
Incoming Chair and Secretary for Justice Dr. Eric Kwa, PhD, praised the record turnout.
“This is the biggest number of delegations I have seen compared to other PILON meetings. The discussions were productive and informative.”
The event featured a handover–takeover ceremony, where Dr. Kwa assumed the PILON Chair from Fiji Solicitor General, Ropate Green Lomavatu, marked by a cultural presentation from the Hiri Hanenamo Queen 2025, Luisa Margarete Udia, honoring Motu Koitabu traditions.
Dr. Kwa will pass the chairmanship to Tuvalu at the 45th PILON meeting in 2026.

Title: DJAG supports work of PACLII
Content:
Papua New Guinea, through the Department of Justice & Attorney General, signed an agreement with Pacific Islands Legal Information Institute (PACLII) and presented a cheque of Aus$50,000.00 (K150,000.00) during the 44th Pacific Islands Law Officers Network (PILON) meeting in Port Moresby last week to support its work.
Speaking during the signing, Justice Secretary, Dr. Eric Kwa, PhD said this payment is the first instalment and there will be annual payments in the next five years.
“We feel compelled to support PACLII because this platform has been immensely helpful as it keeps us all alive with legal information no matter where you are in the world,” he said.
Dr Kwa also called on the participants from other Pacific Island nations to go back to their countries and ask their governments to support PACLII as well.
“This is a very important, crucial, and critical tool for all of us as lawyers,” he said.
PACLII is an initiative of the University of South Pacific (USP), which collects and publishes legal materials from 20 Pacific Island Countries. The material consists of primary materials such as court decisions and legislation. It also includes decisions of various tribunals, panels, and secondary information such as court rules or bench books.
The Prime Minister has agreed to support USP so PNG can formally join USP.

Title: PMGH CEO explains why the twins remain in PMGH
Content:
The conjoined twins who were received by Port Moresby General Hospital (PMGH) last month as a referral case from ANGAU Memorial Hospital, have been diagnosed to have complex conginetal anomalies.
A statement released by the Chief Executive Office (CEO) of Port Moresby General Hospital stated that after extensive consultations, medical examinations and assessments by multi-disciplinary clinical team, both infants were found to have complex conginetal anomalies.
Taking the factors surrounding these anomalies into consideration, PMGH CEO, Dr Paki Molumi said they had agreed to continue to care for the twins at PMGH.
Dr. Paki Molumi stated that according to clinical findings, one of the twins has a single kidney, hypo plastic lungs, a severe conginetal heart defect; both share a liver, urinary bladder and proportions of gastrointestinal tract and spinal dysraphism noted on the CT scans of the twins.
“These anomalies are significant and even within a highly specialised surgical and intensive care setting, the outcome remains extemeley guarded, with a high likelihood of fatality for one or both of the infants,” Dr. Molumi stated.
He further expressed that even if the twin were to undergo surgery for separation it is likely that only one of the twin would survive. He added that the longterm care, interventions and rehabilitation required would be extensive for the family to sustain.
The parents who have two other children, 8 and 12 have been fully informed of these factors.
“Taking all these factors into account, our team collectively agreed that it is in the best interest of the twins and their family to continue  care here at the Port Moresby Geneal Hospital,” said Dr. Molumi.
Dr. Molumi assurred that the PMGH team remains committed to providing the specialised clinical and supportive care to both infants as well as psychological and social support to the parents and family during this difficult time.

Title: MULLG ward 4 councilor reclaims seat for the 4th time
Content:
This is a man who has stood up time and time again, attesting to his rivals that his loyalty lies with the people and his community, who have elected him for four consecutive terms.
When Bonny Simon contested in 2002, Ward Four area, comprising Redscar, Admin compound down to Kusbau and Madang Technical School, was a notorious zone known for petty crimes and theft. Fast forward to today, it is a place where mothers feel safe to do daily markets of fresh produce and cooked food.
C4, an alias for Council ward four, as he is commonly known in the area, made a mission to restore law and order and bring peace within the community. He has worked hard to achieve this, sometimes putting himself on the line. His door is open 24/7 for domestic issues within the community, most times, setting up weekends as the "bung" or 'wanbel' date to sort issues.
Simon’s win on Sunday, November 2, cements his deal as a leader in his community, as he thanked his family, community, and supporters for their unwavering trust.
"Though vote lo mi or nogat, mi kam bek. Mi no cheat na mi win, yupla mekim petition na salim ward recorder blo mi go lo ward three. I told you guys I'll prove you wrong, and I did. Now mi ready long work gen long servim community blong mi," Simon said.
Meantime, counting will continue for wards 5-10 at the Marape Hall in Tusbab Secondary School.
Councilors declared so far are:
Ward 1: Andrew Mocke (New)
Ward 2: Sammy Tindipu (Retained)
Ward 3: Desmond Mapai (Retained)
Ward 4: Bonny Simon (Retained)

Title: Marape to advocate for forest protection at COP30
Content:
Prime Minister James Marape will for the first time participate in the Conference of Parties (COP30) meeting in Brazil since becoming the Prime Minister in 2019.
Prime Minister Marape has never taken part in COP meetings since becoming the Prime Minister of PNG because of what he views as a lack of climate action from industrialised nations on the matter.
“I must admit I have not attended any COP meetings in the past because many industrialised nations talk but do not take real action to reduce emissions.
“That has been my strongest view with countries of the world, especially those with huge carbon blueprints. As a climate victim in our small island states and coastal communities, PNG must strongly advocate, especially as the biggest country in the Pacific Islands Forum family,” he said.
Before his departure early this morning, Marape highlighted the importance of Papua New Guinea having its presence at COP30 saying this particular summit, (COP30) is particularly significant as it provides a platform for forest nations – like PNG and Brazil – to advocate for stronger climate action, forest conservation, and ocean protection.
“This is an extraordinary COP for Papua New Guinea and Brazil. Brazil, the biggest forest nation, is hosting it. So, a large forest nation is hosting the conference for the first time. This aligns with Article 5 and Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, which focuses on forests and forest resource management,” said PM Marape.
PNG joins Brazil, Indonesia, and Malaysia as the world’s major tropical rainforest nations where PNG will advocate strongly with Brazil for global forest protection.
“PNG has high-integrity forests where around 70% of our landmass remains in its premium primary state, with minimal logging footprints. This means high car-bon sink capacity and extremely rich biodiversity,” he said.
“If the world wants us to save our forests for the benefit of humanity, then those with large carbon footprints must pay conservation dollars. These funds must go to our landowners, who have customary rights over the forests.”
The Conference of the Parties (COP) will take place from 10 to 21 November 2025 in Belém, northern Brazil, where the city will host tens of thousands of delegates, scientists, government representatives, journalists, and environmental activists from around the world.
The meeting is the main global forum under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), where world leaders negotiate and implement international climate agreements.

Title: RPNGC & AFP to share resources to fight international crime
Content:
The Royal PNG Constabulary (RPNGC) and the Australian Federal Police  (AFP) will work together to disrupt international criminal activities before they infiltrate the two countries.
This has been possible through the signing of a Joint Agency Agreement (JAA) between RPNGC and AFP recently.
Police Commissioner David Manning confirmed that the JAA, signed on November 2nd, is focused entirely on the sharp end of policing, deploying critical resources to identify and break apart criminal gangs before they can set up in PNG.
"International criminal networks are attempting to use PNG as a stepping stone for extending their illicit activities into Australia, but our police forces are working together to shut them down before they become active," the Commissioner said.
"This involves the mutual sharing of intelligence between our police forces. The sharing of AFP intelligence to support RPNGC operations in PNG, and the sharing of RPNGC intelligence with Australia on criminal activities developing in their country.
"International criminal networks are looking for ways into Australia through PNG, and together with the AFP, we are blocking them from getting a foothold in our country.
"We are stopping these gangs before they can try to transport drugs, money, and precious metals such as gold, as well as stopping the human trafficking of vulnerable people.
"The JAA is not about training, it is about aligning our policing operations to ensure we break apart these transnational criminal organisations, and arrest criminals and local facilitators who support them in both countries.
"This agreement gives us better access to intelligence products from our regional partners because these criminal groups do not respect borders," he said.
Commissioner Manning said the JAA is overseen by a steering committee made up of specialised police leadership from Papua New Guinea and Australia.
"The Joint Steering Committee facilitates the sharing of intelligence leading to the active detection of illegal movements and the interception and apprehension of criminals.
"The message is simple, for anyone in PNG, particularly foreign businesspeople seeking to make quick money by enabling illegal international activities, PNG and Australian police are coming for you,” Manning added.

Title: PNG Through the Lens
People: James Marape, Justin Tkatchenko, Michael Somare
Content:
Papua New Guinea’s remarkable journey of growth, culture, and resilience was celebrated through a photography exhibition titled FOCUS: 50 Years of PNG Through the Lens.
The exhibition brought together the extraordinary work of two of the nation’s most respected photographers, Rocky Roe and Dinah Halstead, whose images told the story of PNG’s transformation over the past five decades.
Through more than 200 striking photographs, the exhibition showcased the nation’s beauty, diversity, and endurance - from historic moments like the twin volcanic eruptions in Rabaul to everyday life in remote villages and the vibrant cultural expressions seen in traditional dress and festivals.
Presented across nine thematic collections, FOCUS highlighted PNG’s evolving identity - capturing everything from life beneath the sea to national milestones and the industries that have shaped its economy. Each image served as a reminder of the importance of preserving the country’s natural and cultural heritage for future generations.
Renowned photographer Roe took viewers on a journey through PNG’s rugged landscapes, including the peaks of Mt Wilhelm in Chimbu Province and the hidden fjords of Tufi in Northern Province, offering rare glimpses into rural life and untouched beauty.
Meanwhile, Dinah Halstead, a pioneering diver and conservationist, turned her lens beneath the surface to reveal PNG’s underwater wonders. Her internationally acclaimed marine photography captured the vibrant biodiversity of the Coral Triangle, inspiring awareness and action for marine conservation.
The FOCUS: 50 Years of PNG Through the Lens exhibition officially opened on Monday, November 3, 2025, at APEC Haus in Port Moresby, with public viewing held from Tuesday, November 4 to 6.
Following its debut, the exhibition will tour towns and centres across Papua New Guinea, bringing this visual celebration to communities nationwide.
Prime Minister James Marape, Member for Moresby South and Minister for Foreign Affairs Justin Tkatchenko, and Bertha Somare, daughter of the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare, were among the distinguished speakers at the launch.
Each reflected on the significance of photography in preserving national history and identity, praising Roe and Halstead for their lifelong dedication to capturing PNG’s story through powerful imagery.
For more information, visitors are encouraged to visit www.focus50years.com

Title: Bushwara community launch association
Content:
Settlers of Bushwara settlement in Nine Mile Port Moresby, affected by the recent eviction carried out on portions 2156, 2157, and 2159, have launched an association that will help drive their resettlement agenda.
Member for Moresby North East, John Kaupa, launched the association on Sunday, November 2.
The heavy downpour in the nation's capital did not stop the Bushwara community, who came in numbers to witness the launch of the Bushwara United Community Voice Inc.
MP Kaupa officiated at the event, marking the start of a strategic approach towards working together under the umbrella of resettlement.
“This association’s function is created through the interest of like-minded people, aimed at achieving goals and interests for the community. It is a not-for-profit organisation, but it has legal standing to work with developing partners to achieve the goals and aspirations of the community,” he said.
Kaupa said that since the eviction of those who settled in portions 2156, 2157, and 2159, about 937 houses were removed from this area, leaving almost 5,000 people displaced. The government has allocated K25 million for the resettlement exercise.
He said the government has allocated 62 hectares of land at Pari for the displaced settlers. They are currently working with relevant authorities to secure land titles.
Association chairman Dickson Sorariba said the association will work closely with the government to resettle the displaced population.

Title: Kila retains Kutubu LLG presidential seat
Content:
John Pipi Kila was declared unopposed as president of Kutubu Local Level Government on Sunday, November 2, 2025.
Kila's re-election was supported unanimously by all 18 council wards within the Kutubu LLG.
Kila's uncontested election reflects confidence among the council members and the local communities in him.
They highlighted his good leadership that didn't need change.
When accepting his position, Kila expressed gratitude for the support he has received from the wards. He emphasised commitment to working hard to foster development and address the needs of the Kutubu people.
Kila outlined his priorities, which include enhancing local infrastructure, improving service delivery, and fostering economic opportunities for communities.

Title: Fathers must lead the fight against DV
Content:
“Violence begins at home—and so does healing.” That was the message from Pastor Simon Kuman, who challenged fathers across Papua New Guinea to take the lead in ending domestic violence and restoring peace in their families.
Speaking under the theme Safe Spaces, Strong Voices, Ps Kuman urged men to stop the cycle of blame and begin the work of healing within their families. “Violence begins at home,” he said. “The family is the first institution God created—and it’s where restoration must begin.”
He highlighted the work of the Hope Behind Bars (HBB) Program, where young men use radio and school visits to raise awareness about murder, domestic violence, and the mistreatment of women. “We go to Gerehu Secondary School, Waigani Christian College, and many others,” he said. “We teach young boys how to treat their future wives and sisters with respect.”
Ps Kuman traced the roots of violence back to the Garden of Eden, arguing that anger and blame are embedded in human nature. “Nobody teaches you how to get angry—it’s already in us,” he said. “But fathers must lead with love, not blame.”
The event closed with a powerful testimony from Ellyn, a mother who served five years in prison for domestic violence. After finding faith behind bars, she graduated from Bible College and returned to prison—not as an inmate, but as a pastor. She now works to transform the lives of imprisoned mothers.
“Jesus is the solution,” Ps Kuman declared. “His blood cleanses the heart.”
“With peace, love, and mercy, we can rebuild our families and restore our country.”

Title: Boy,14, found dead at Koki market
Content:
The National Capital District Criminal Investigating Division police officers are investigating the death of a 14-year-old boy, who was found dead outside Koki Fish Market this morning.
The mother said the boy left the house on Sunday (November 2) during the day, telling her that he wanted to go to Koki and wash.
She said she insisted, but he escaped and went there. The mother said her son never returned in the afternoon, when they started looking for him.
The mother added that they searched every possible location they thought he would be, but never found him until they drove back to Two Mile when they heard the news that his body was found at the Fish Market.
"We now leave it to the police to investigate and find out how he died because, at this moment, we are not sure how he died. The police and the doctors will tell us how he died," the mother said.
National Capital District Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab confirmed that police units are collecting evidence from possible eyewitnesses to establish the cause of his death.
I am urging city residents to be cautious when moving around. With the rising death toll, some people show a lack of respect for others. Small issues can lead to people losing their lives, such as not keeping track of each family member’s whereabouts. Checking on your family members every day demonstrates that you care for them," Met. Supt. Simatab said.
He further added that no suspects have been arrested as investigations continue.

Title: Serve with purpose, recruits told
Content:
The Commissioner of Police, David Manning, has issued strict directions to police recruits to serve the nation with dedication, discipline, and honour.
Commissioner Manning told recruits at the opening of accommodation barracks and the groundbreaking for new training buildings at the Bomana College Regional Centre of Excellence on Saturday, November 1, 2025.
"Rebuilding the police force needs considerable infrastructure investment, and we are moving forward," Commissioner Manning highlighted.
“These 14 refurbished barracks provide an additional 408 beds for recruits studying to become Police Officers.
"This latest accommodation upgrade increases our recruit training capacity to 700 members for each intake.
"Impressively, this means that we will train and deploy up to 1,400 police recruits every year.
"With 1,400 of the best and brightest young Papua New Guineans being trained at Bomana each year, we are increasing policing services throughout our most remote regions."
Commissioner Manning said the refurbished barracks are on the original concrete and steel foundations that had been built decades ago.
"With the support of the Australian Government, each of these barracks has undergone a complete refurbishment.
"The original barracks were built on strong foundations that served the Constabulary through our proud history, but a lack of maintenance saw the buildings fall into disrepair.
"Just like these buildings, the RPNGC is built on a strong and proud history that we are restoring through the commitment of resources and dedication to renewal.
"Through the Special Police Assistance Program, our Police Force is being rebuilt through nationwide recruitment, vehicle re-fleeting, and building additional Police Stations across all provinces.
"These training facilities will complement the recently completed Regional Centre of Excellence for Investigations.
"Together, these classrooms and training buildings are ensuring RPNGC recruits and cadets are trained in modern facilities that are equipped with appropriate information technology,” he said.
Commissioner Manning commended the partnership between Papua New Guinea and Australia is delivering on the commitments made by the governments of both countries.
"Australia is our closest neighbour, and responsibility for security is a shared responsibility.
"I thank the PNG-Australia Policing Partnership and the Australian Government for our continuing co-operation that is strengthening the RPNGC, and contributing to security in both of our countries,” Manning added.

Title: New DFCDR officers inducted
Content:
A total of 124 new officers from the Department for Community Development and Religion (DFCDR) have completed the National Certificate II in Government (Public Service Induction) program.
The one-week training, held from October 27 to 31, was facilitated by the Somare Institute of Leadership and Governance (SILAG). It is designed to equip new public servants with the essential knowledge and skills to perform effectively in the public sector.
The officers, recruited under the Department’s current restructure, received training on public service systems, workplace ethics, values, codes of conduct, and their roles and responsibilities.
Human Resource Managing Director, John Limbou, speaking on behalf of Secretary Jerry Ubase, congratulated the new officers and encouraged them to apply their learning in their work. SILAG Program Manager, Jack Kwa, thanked DFCDR for the ongoing partnership in building public service capacity.
The training concluded with a certificate presentation and the signing of an Oath of Loyalty at the SILAG campus.

Title: PNG to participate at COP30
Content:
Papua New Guinea will participate in the 30th Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP30) to be held from November 10-21, 2025, in Belem, Brazil.
Minister for Environment Conservation and Climate Change, Simo Kilepa, announced today at a press conference.
He said the convention is a landmark for PNG since its adoption of the Paris Agreement, where nations will take stock of global progress and strengthen commitments toward limiting temperature rise and building resilience to climate impacts.
Minister Kilepa said the Prime Minister James Marape will be present at the World Leaders’ Summit from November 6 and 7, leading up to the main COP30 sessions.
Kilepa’s said the PM’s attendance highlights the government's commitment to global climate leadership and ensuring that Papua New Guinea’s priorities are reflected in international outcomes.
“As a country rich in biodiversity and natural ecosystems yet highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change, Papua New Guinea’s participation at COP30 is both strategic and essential.
“Our delegation will include representatives from government agencies, the private sector, civil society, academia, NGOs, and development partners, coordinated by the Climate Change and Development Authority (CCDA).
“It is important to clarify that the delegation registered under the Papua New Guinea badge does not imply that all participants are funded by the PNG government. Approximately 80 per cent of the delegation are self-funding, project-funded, or supported by the business community, associations, advocates, and private sector representatives.
“The participants will attend meetings running in parallel and on the margins of COP30 within the official COP venue.”

Title: THINKPINK Masquerade gala draws support
Content:
PNG Cancer Foundation ended its Breast Cancer Awareness Campaign with a Thinkpink Masquerade gala dinner held at the APEC Haus in Port Moresby on Friday, October 31, 2025.
Present at the gala were representatives of corporate houses, state agencies, cancer survivors, and friends of PNGCF, almost all in pink attire signifying the importance of pink October.
The PNG Cancer Foundation’s executive manager, Kimberley Kapigeno, while appreciating all who attended, especially sponsors and supporters, said it has been more than a decade since many have joined the foundation in pink ribbon luncheons and gatherings, which have become synonymous with breast cancer awareness advocacy and a cornerstone of the annual Think Pink campaign.
“This campaign has transitioned into another level,” she said.
“These luncheons have been instrumental in bringing together leaders, partners, and supporters to champion the cause of breast cancer awareness. There have been platforms for dialogue, education, and mobilization spaces where we shared stories, statistics, and solutions. Tonight (Friday night), we transition and evolve that tradition. We present to you the first-ever THINKPINK masquerade gala.”
Representing the Prime Minister and the government was Minister for Health, Elias Kapavore, who addressed the masquerade gala. Kapavore firstly appreciated the PNGCF, especially in connecting with the Provincial Health Authorities. He promised to support the good work.
“This year marks 10 years of the foundation’s tireless advocacy, a decade of service to our people through programmes that have reached thousands across schools, workplaces, and communities. Initiatives such as the healthy teens, cervical cancer education, community outreaches, and trupela man have transformed awareness into action and broken long-standing stigma around cancer. For that, on behalf of our government, I say thank you,” said Minister Kapavore.
Bertha Ngahan is a brave warrior and survivor of breast cancer who hails from West New Britain. Bertha graced the evening with her lifetime experience of living with and fighting cancer. She shared from her heart the importance of having a positive mindset to overcome formidable barriers such as cancer.
Her journey started four years ago when, in the shower, she discovered “something that shouldn’t be there,” she said. Bertha first reached out to a friend, then consulted her company doctor, who encouraged her to go to the hospital for a check-up, which eventually led her to undergo a biopsy. The results came out positive.
Bertha described the fight after the discovery of her condition as hard and long and sometimes lonely because, for her, it was discovered during COVID-19, so she was isolated as well from her family.
But one thing that gave her the courage to face the dilemma head-on was to accept the fact and follow the treatment, including chemotherapy.
Indeed, the fight is ongoing four years on, Bertha is still standing to declare, “I am a survivor!”.
“After my mastectomy, I was re-staged to stage-3 because it had spread to my lymph nodes, but I told myself, this is where it stops, not another centimeter. Now four years later, after four surgeries, countless scans, and hundreds of blood tests, I stand here as that woman in the chemo room. I am a survivor!
“But I also know survival should not be this hard. If we have proper facilities, a one-stop centre for testing, diagnosis, treatments, and psychological support, more of our sisters, our mothers, our daughters would still be here. And I’m happy to hear the new cancer facility is almost done.
“I lost a lot along the way. I lost several dear sisters, I lost my hair, I lost one breast, I lost both my ovaries, but I did not lose myself. The turning point for me came, I think, during my second chemotherapy when a woman walked into the chemo room, smiling, glowing, and said, ‘I am a survivor! That moment I cried and I promised myself that one day that would be me!” she added.
She lost her father and baby sister to cancer, but she declared that this will not go any further in her family. It will stop with her.

Title: PM congratulates Kumuls for Pacific Bowl victory
Content:
The Papua New Guinea Kumuls have been praised for retaining the Pacific Bowl title for the third consecutive year after they stormed to a 50-18 win over Fiji Bati at the National Football Stadium in Port Moresby on Saturday, November 1.
Prime Minister James Marape has extended his congratulations to the Kumuls for their commanding victory and third consecutive Pacific Bowl triumph.
“This is more than a sporting victory — it reflects our national character: bold, united, and world-class,” Prime Minister Marape said. “Our Kumuls delivered a performance of immense pride in front of our people.”
The Kumuls stunned Fiji with a blistering start, scoring the first five tries to surge to a 30–0 lead within the opening half of the match. Stand-out performances included second-rower Rhyse Martin, who converted all nine attempts (eight conversions and one penalty) and crossed for a try himself, finishing with 22 points.
Prime Minister Marape also praised the team’s depth of contributors:
“Eight different players crossed for tries — this shows the breadth of talent in our squad and why Papua New Guinea’s future in rugby league is so exciting.”
He acknowledged the visiting Fiji Bati for their competitive spirit and contribution to Pacific rugby league:
“In competition, we sharpen ourselves; in friendship, we strengthen the Pacific community. Congratulations to Fiji, and thank you for the contest.”
Reflecting on the broader significance of the victory, Prime Minister Marape said: “As we mark PNG@50, this win is symbolic of our nation’s journey — building strength from within, inspiring our youth, and projecting our presence on the world stage.”
He reaffirmed the Government’s continued support for rugby league, from grassroots development to elite performance: “Our commitment is to ensure our players, coaches, and administrators have the resources and environment to succeed. This win is a milestone — and the next milestone is even greater.”
Prime Minister Marape extended special commendation to Head Coach Jason Demetriou and the entire Kumuls squad.
“Coach Demetriou has instilled a disciplined and fearless style of play that our nation can rally behind. Congratulations to him and the entire coaching staff on this achievement.”
“To the Kumuls, the fans, the families, the coaches, the officials — you have all played your part in this historic moment. Well done, and may this be the first of many to come.”

Title: RPNGC raised over K26,000 for Pinktober
Content:
The Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) has raised K26,066 to support the fight against Breast Cancer in Papua New Guinea at their recent fundraiser held at the Boroko Police Station, Port Moresby last week.
As a show of support and solidarity towards Pinktober, Members of the RPNGC staged a short march from the Police Traffic Office at Four Mile to Boroko Police Station, where the fundraising was hosted.
This was an initiative taken by the Human Resource Division of RPNGC to host an annual awareness and fundraising event to mark Pinktober. For this year’s Pinktober, the Logistics Division of RPNGC took the lead in organising the event.
The Assistant Commissioner of Police (ACP) and Commander for National Capital District (NCD) and Central Province, Benjamin Turi, who took part in the march and fundraising, said breast cancer is everyone’s business, and showing support in the fight against it gives hope to those affected.
The Executive Officer for the Deputy Commissioner of Police Administration, Chief Inspector David Terry, said this is a very significant event for the Constabulary, given the statistics of policewomen who have been diagnosed with Breast Cancer. Some have passed on, while some are still in the fight.
Dr Aina Anota from the Cancer Clinic at the Port Moresby General Hospital, who was invited to the event, said breast cancer not only affects females but males as well. She said about 2-3 per cent of males can be affected with breast cancer; however, the majority are women.
“In our clinic, we see about 300 women per year being diagnosed with breast cancer and come to the clinic for treatment.
“Every year we are diagnosing 20 to 30 new patients of breast cancer, and it can go up to 50 too,” says Dr Anota.
Some signs and symptoms of breast cancer include lumps around the breast area or armpit; it is a painless lump. Other signs include bloody nipple discharge, a change in shape and size of the breast, and skin changes like redness or flaking of the skin on the breast or around the nipple.
Dr Anota said once you notice one of these signs, be quick to get checked. She said breast checks are done every Tuesday with an administration fee of K5 at the Cancer Clinic of Port Moresby General Hospital; however, the treatment is free of charge.
ACP Turi thanked the business houses, namely, King Kakaruk Limited, Okari Limited, Motorist Mart Limited, H.C & YH Leo Limited, the Australian Federal Police, the Executive Management of RPNGC, and everyone for their support towards the Pinktober fundraising.

Title: Fred Hollows Foundation hosts workshop on Climate Resilience
Content:
Papua New Guinea is one of the most Climate vulnerable countries in the world as we are looking at hotter temperatures, heavier rainfall during the wet season, longer dry seasons and sea level rise to name a few.
These changes pose serious risks to health infrastructure, especially facilities like the Madang Eye Clinic situated close to the coast.
As Madang and the rest of PNG continues to navigate complex health and environmental challenges, it is imperative to ensure that eye health is recognized as a key part of climate adaptation and resilient health systems.
The Fred Hollows Foundation recently held a one day dissemination workshop at the Madang Resort Hotel to share findings of a Climate Resilient and Environmentally Sustainable Healthcare Facilities Assessment conducted at the Madang Provincial Eye Clinic.
This work was led by a consultancy organization,  Edge Impact, which forms part of the “Building Community Level Climate Resilience in the Pacific” project supported by the Nes Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade through its Climate Finance for Community Resilience Programme.
According to Fred Hollows Foundation Country Manager Priscilla Sine Mal Peter, the Madang Eye Clinic is a standout example of what can be achieved through thoughtful climate adaptation.
“The facility operates on solar power, harvests rainwater and uses an integrated sewerage system. These measures reduce reliance on external resources, lower operational costs and most importantly, ensure continuity of care during climate related disruptions,” stated the Country Manager.
It was made known that the Climate Impact Assessment for the Madang Eye Clinic highlighted several key risks:
•	Heat impacts are affecting energy supply and placing stress on staff and patients. Micro blackouts and water shortages during the dry season are common.
•	Flooding and sea level rise remain concerns due to the clinics proximity to the coast, although the limestone dominant soil profile offers some natural protection.
•	Storms and high winds disrupts outreach services, limiting access to care in remote areas.
•	Cumulative climate impacts, including political instability and limited climate awareness among health workers, pose broader challenges to adaptation.
Fred Hollows Foundation Project Manager Lydia Seta whilst presenting the findings emphasized on more collaboration and positive mind-set in supporting communities as one of the recommendations. Communities were also advised to take ownership of facilities in their vicinity and also being inclusive in their approaches towards gender and disability.
Participants who attended were from the National Department of Health, Madang PHA, Christian Health Services, members from the district health services, partner FPCD, EBC health services in Goroka, other key stakeholders and community members.
“When sight is lost, so too are opportunities for learning, livelihoods and dignity. Embedding eye health in climate resilience discussions ensures Pacific people are not only surviving the climate crisis but living with clear vision and opportunity,” said Ms. Peter.
Chief Executive Officer for Madang Provincial Health Authority Dr. Martin Daimen added that it is imperative for engineers and even everybody to consider climate aspects in the planning of any activity, development or establishments to avoid mishaps in future.
The foundation is non profit dedicated to reducing avoidable blindness and vision impairment across the Pacific. It now operates eight eye clinics across seven countries including PNG, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Fiji, Tonga, Samoa and Kiribati.
In 2024, the Foundation secured funding  for this assessment conducted in its facilities in PNG, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu.

Title: One house – 21 deaths
Content:
It’s been revealed that all 21 people except one who died in the landslide in Kukas Village in Wapenamanda were from the Yabalikin tribe in the Lower Lai constituency and were in Kukas for just a night when they met their fate.
With search and rescue efforts called off at Kukas Village where the landslide occurred, the death toll remains at 21 and all bodies transported to the Paradise Funeral Home in Mt Hagen.
According to Joshua Mangalio from the Provincial Disaster Team, the deceased were in Kukas for a funeral on the 30th of October and were due to return home on the same day. But with the eruption of fresh violence in Mabisanda where the health centre was torched, the road was blocked and the group couldn’t return home as the violence was along their path of travel. They were then hosted by a pastor in a house there when the landslip hit them in the early hours of Friday (31 October, 2025) morning.
About 27 people were accommodated in that house on that fateful night with another 17 accommodated in the pastor’s house. Those 17, the five survivors and the pastor have all been traumatized and are receiving help from EPG.
From reports, 21 casualties were reported and includes one pregnant female, two children under the age of 10 and 18 males, all adults.
The EPG Disaster team has responded with relief supplies and people in the village living along the disaster site have been advised to move to higher grounds due to continuous rainfalls in the area. Police and defence personal continue to patrol the area.
Meantime the relatives of the deceased have agreed to leave the bodies with the EPG Disaster Team

Title: ENB LLG elections progress well
Content:
East New Britain Province’s (ENBP) four districts with 23 Local Level Governments (LLGs) from a total of 382 Wards, have gone into LLG elections.  Polling commenced on Monday October 27 2025 as scheduled nationwide.
A statement from the provincial electoral commission stated that LLG Elections are underway with 137 polling teams attending to voters at 534 polling venues.
ENB voters are voting for ward members and LLG presidents.
Throughout the week, polling was done, and then counting and declarations of newly elected ward members followed the next day.
Some of the wards had their ward members standing unopposed, therefore only took time to vote for LLG presidents.
The election process for ward members is expected to be concluded this Saturday November 1, 2025, and then counting and declarations for LLG presidents get underway on Monday November 3.
Some of the common challenges faced by the four districts during the current LLG Elections are;
1.	The increasing number of informal votes. Despite LPV awareness carried out at the election sites, eligible voters still made mistakes, due to them turning up late and missing out on the awareness.
2.	Names not found in the Common Roll.  Some people who travelled long distances to cast their vote, but found out that their names were not in the Common Roll, leaving them frustrated.
3.	Eligible voters not voting. Many eligible voters whose names were on the Common Roll did not turn up to exercise their voting rights resulting in less number of votes being casted.
4.	Geographical challenges. Areas like Pomio District expect late results due to treacherous conditions which polling officials have to endure.
5.
Police provided security for polling teams who had to travel to areas that are crime hotspots.
Moving forward, the provincial electoral office says more LPV awareness needs to be carried out before the next election, to minimise informal votes.

Title: PM Marape Calls For Responsible Family Planning
Content:
Following the official release of the country’ population figure, Prime Minister James Marape has called on Papua New Guineans to embrace responsible family planning, warning that rapid population growth could outpace the nation’s economic capacity if not properly managed.
With country’s population now at 10,185,363, the Prime Minister described the figure as both a milestone and a wake-up call for policy-makers and citizens alike.
In raising concerns about the economic burden of rapid population growth, he urged young couples to consider limiting their families to two or three children, warning that the cost of raising a child to adulthood in modern Papua New Guinea is “an expensive exercise.”
“From conception to adulthood, it can cost up to K5 million to give a child a decent, modern upbringing,” he said. “Parents must think carefully. It is not about how many children you have, but about the quality of life you can provide for them.”
The Prime Minister proposed a national conversation on population control, suggesting a potential policy link between family size and the Government’s Free Education program. Under the proposal, the first two or three children in a family could receive full education support, while additional children would be the responsibility of parents.
“This is a conversation we must have maturely — in churches, communities, and families. A sustainable country must have its economy growing faster than its Population,” PM Marape said.
He also announced plans to make population monitoring a continuous process, urging all provincial administrations to link with health facilities to ensure every birth and death is properly recorded. This, he said, would enable more accurate and efficient future censuses.
Reflecting on Papua New Guinea’s demographic and economic history, PM Marape noted that from Independence in 1975, the population has tripled while economic growth has lagged behind.
“For the first 27 years, our economy grew at less than 0.3 percent while our population rose at around 3 percent. That imbalance cannot continue,” he warned.
As the Prime Minister reaffirmed his government’s commitment to growing the Economy, he appealed for public cooperation in managing population growth.
He reminded citizens that the nation’s Population has expanded dramatically over the decades — from 2,184,991 in 1966, to 2,489,935 in 1971, 3,010,727 in 1980, 3,761,954 in 1990, 5,190,786 in 2000, and 7,275,324 in 2011, reaching 10,185,363 in 2024.
He further noted that the Population has grown by 2.6 percent annually, increasing by approximately 2.9 million people in the past 13 years, underscoring the urgency of managing population growth in line with the nation’s economic strength.

Title: VISA for PALM
Content:
In a major boost for Papua New Guineans seeking overseas employment, Pacific International Hospital (PIH) and the Papua New Guinea Labour Mobility Unit (PNG LMU) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to provide affordable and accessible visa medical services for workers under the Pacific Australia Labour Mobility (PALM) Scheme and New Zealand’s Recognised Seasonal Employer (RSE) Scheme.
The partnership, announced yesterday, aims to streamline the visa medical process by offering discounted packages, expanding service locations, and ensuring faster, high-quality medical assessments for candidates referred by PNG LMU. The initiative is expected to significantly reduce costs and logistical barriers for rural applicants.
“The government remains firmly committed to the labour mobility program. Our national target for mobilizing 8,000 workers by 2025 continues to guide our collective efforts,” said Andrew Oaeke, Secretary of the Department of Treasury. “This partnership represents a practical step towards empowering our citizens with the medical support they need to access job opportunities abroad.”
Visa medicals will be conducted at PIH branches in Port Moresby, Mt. Hagen, Lae, Kokopo, and Goroka. By decentralizing services, the arrangement will save candidates from costly travel to the capital, making the process more inclusive and regionally accessible.
PIH currently has the capacity to conduct over 60 visa medicals per day across its network and can rapidly scale up during peak recruitment periods. The hospital will also offer specialized pre-screening services, particularly for tuberculosis, to improve visa success rates.
In addition to medicals, the partnership supports the development of aged care worker certification and training programs, helping PNG workers upskill for higher-value roles under the PALM Scheme.
“PIH is proud to support PNG’s labour mobility initiatives by ensuring timely, affordable, and high-standard medical services,” said Col. Sandeep Shaligram, CEO of Pacific International Hospital. “Our nationwide presence allows us to reach more candidates, reduce travel-related costs, and help accelerate visa processing times.”
To further streamline the process, PNG LMU will establish an imprest account with PIH to facilitate partial or full payment of visa medical fees. This will simplify transactions for candidates, sponsors, and recruitment hubs, ensuring faster coordination between both institutions.
The agreement will remain in effect for two years, with joint reviews every six months to assess performance and adapt to evolving needs.

Title: Japan Ambassador Visits Tokua
Content:
Tokua airport was built in 1998 by the Japan International Cooperation Agency. It was built after the infamous volcano eruption had destroyed the old Rabaul Airport. Now, for 27 years, Tokua Airport has served the people of East New Britain Province and visitors alike.
The visit of His Excellency Hisanobu Mochizuki, Ambassador of Japan to Papua New Guinea was monumental. He was taken on a tour to the terminal, the runway and the control tower by Tokua Airport Terminal Manager Samson Kakai and staff.
After the airport visit, Ambassador Mochizuki had a meeting with the management of the PNG Cocoa Board. The PNG Cocoa Board took the opportunity to market East New Britain and PNG Cocoa to Japan and the wider Asian Market.
CEO Jesse Anjen, told Ambassador Mochizuki that last year, the national production of cocoa was around 42,000 tons or 80 percent, and it's classified as flavored or fine cocoa.
Anjen further said, about 98 percent of PNG cocoa is exported as raw beans while about 2 percent is produced locally. Most of the beans are sold in Asia and having a partnership with Japan will see them import some of the best cocoa beans from PNG.
Anjen said, “About 98 percent of PNG cocoa is exported as raw beans while about 2 percent is produced locally. Most of the beans are sold in Asia”.
“And having a partnership with Japan will see them importing some of the best cocoa beans from PNG,” he said.
