Ambassador Mochizuki later visited Eden Sanctuary Integrated Farm and met with cocoa board officers. They demonstrated how they make cocoa nurseries, budding, harvesting, and fermenting the beans.
Commenting on this experience, Ambassador Mochizuki said Japan would want to import cocoa from PNG among other products.

Title: Cheating law firm reported
Content:
Member for Bogia, Robert Naguri, today brought to the attention of the Minister for Justice and Attorney General, Pila Niningi, in Parliament that a series of false claims have been submitted for payment by a certain law firm in Madang Province.
MP Bogia Naguri said the law firm has falsely taken a court order against the Bogia district and has obtained a court decision to solicit money from the district’s bank accounts.
MP Naguri said this is not only happening in the district but also in Usino-Bundi, Middle Ramu, and Madang districts.
Naguri brought this to the attention of Minister Niningi and asked whether he was aware of what was happening. He called on the Minister to explain to the people of Bogia and the rest of the MPs whether this is legal.
In response, Minister Niningi said sometimes lawyers make agreements with the banks and solicit money for projects.
“When you are not watching, they can go to court and obtain orders to come out and get the money. This is one of those cases. He promised to ask the department to investigate the matter and will advise the MP on how to address this important issue.
Minister Niningi said the Madang situation is also happening in other districts, where false claims are used to solicit money

Title: Sepik Cocoa Wins European Hearts
Content:
Sepik cocoa is earning global attention as European markets, particularly in the United Kingdom, show strong interest in Papua New Guinea’s premium cocoa through initiatives led by the EU-STREIT PNG and UKTP programmes.
International cocoa expert Dr. Zoi Papalexandra from the United Kingdom Trade Partnerships (UKTP) Programme, under the International Trade Centre (ITC), visited Wewak to connect Sepik cocoa producers with niche overseas buyers. Her visit underscores the growing reputation of sustainably produced, high-quality cocoa from the Sepik region.
During her visit, Dr. Papalexandra conducted a hands-on training for 68 local cocoa farmers, agripreneurs, and government extension officers.
The workshop, themed “Cocoa Fermentation & Post-Harvest Practices, Deforestation Regulation Compliance,” was co-facilitated by the EU-STREIT PNG Programme, FAO, and the Cocoa Board of Papua New Guinea (CBPNG).
Participants learned advanced fermentation and drying techniques to improve bean quality and flavour, as well as methods to meet deforestation-free cocoa regulations demanded by European niche markets. They also explored cocoa bean genetics through bean-cutting tests and segregated 18 cocoa varieties to produce diverse chocolate flavours appealing to international buyers.
“I can see high-quality beans being produced here and I commend the cocoa development initiatives in the Sepik,” said Dr. Papalexandra. “ITC will come with between 10 and 15 potential buyers, and this is why we have to produce the kind of beans they want.”
EU-STREIT PNG Programme Coordinator Ali Said Yesuf praised the region’s progress, saying, “This region has made a significant visible leap in cocoa transformation, but the source of sustainability is these overseas buyers showing interest in our cocoas.”
Local agriculture officer Willie Nemani urged participants to use their new skills to produce market-ready cocoa, saying, “Your participation guarantees the sustainability of the programme.”
For many participants, the workshop brought renewed motivation. “Niche markets want specific flavours from specific cocoa varieties,” said Everlyn Sukuina, a female agripreneur from Ambunti-Drekikier District. “We mix cocoa beans during fermentation — this is what I’ve learned and will change.”
With European demand growing, Sepik cocoa producers are positioning themselves to capture international niche markets — a transformation that promises not only better livelihoods but a sustainable future for cocoa farming in Papua New Guinea.

Title: Women Want Water Representation
Content:
Women across Papua New Guinea are calling for stronger representation and inclusion in decisions around water management, according to new research by WaterAid, World Vision PNG, and the Australian National University’s Development Policy Centre.
The study, which surveyed 147 respondents from Wewak and South Fly districts, along with policymakers and civil society representatives, found that 37% of women identified access to clean water as their biggest challenge, compared to just 19% of men.
Researchers say women are primarily responsible for collecting and managing household water, yet their voices are often missing in governance structures that control this vital resource. One participant from Wewak said, “When water was connected, it made life for us, especially the mothers, easier… before, we used to find it extremely difficult to access water for our basic needs.”
The report highlights that while District WaSH Committees (DWCs) have been established in selected provinces to improve service delivery, women’s participation in these bodies remains limited.
Associate Professor Grant Walton from ANU’s Development Policy Centre noted that including women and community groups in decision-making would lead to more effective and sustainable outcomes. “Women want stronger community collaboration and recognition of their role in managing water resources,” he said.
The research also found that 40% of women preferred community-led approaches to water governance, compared to 20% of men, reflecting a broader desire for inclusivity and empowerment.
As PNG works to expand its DWCs, experts believe ensuring women’s active involvement will not only improve WaSH outcomes but also strengthen community resilience and wellbeing.
The research was supported by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research and published by the Development Policy Centre at ANU.

Title: Survivors help recover bodies
Content:
A massive tragic landslide occurred last night that claimed more than 10 lives at Kukas Village up in Wapenamanda District Enga Province.  Survivors assisted with recovering bodies since the early hours of this morning until day-break.
Kukas villager Danley Andai, stated after the devastration, he and others stayed until daybreak and managed to retrieve 11 bodies from the rubble.
Andai also said that many are still buried underneath all the rubble. Recovery operation continues with other surviving villagers lending a helping hand to clear out debris
He described the event as scary, urging Christians to pray for those not accounted for as search and rescue continue.
While the Provincial Disaster office has yet to release a statement, Acting Director of the National Disaster Centre, Laso Mana is deploying a response team to assist local authorities.

Title: Ialibu Urban LLG election
Content:
Counting for Ialibu Urban LLG in the Ialibu Pangia District started today at the town authority building in Ialibu.
Counting started in the morning with Topopul Two-Ward 6. Four males and one female contested in this ward. The incumbent councillor of Ward 6 is the Town Mayor, Peter Yamuna.
A total of 193 ballot papers were counted and the incumbent, Peter Yamuna led the race from the start to be declared the winner at 11am with 125 votes, passing the absolute majority mark. Three ballot papers were informal in Ward 6.
Counting for the rest of the wards in this LLG are continuing and are expected to be completed this afternoon.
Meanwhile counting for the wards in Kewabi LLG continued today. it started yesterday for this LLG.
Assistance Returning Officer (ARO), Paul Yakira arranged the counting and declarations into three categories.  The first category included the official declaration of unopposed candidates. Three wards in Kewabi LLG had their sitting councillors returned unopposed.  They include Kirene Ward 2 where the current president, Gibbs Siri is from, Paware Ward 1 and Pale Ward 1.
In category two, counting and declarations were made at the polling site. This was applied to wards where polling was peaceful and all candidates and supporters agreed to allow counting to proceed. These council wards include Kepik Ward 1, Pale Ward 2, Makura Ward 1 and Muli Ward 3.
In the last category, counting is being done at the district headquarters in Ialibu. Five wards have been declared so far under this category. They include Paipa Ward 1, Paipa Ward 2, Wangai Ward 2, Tiri and Muku Ward 3.
Mrantime counting in two LLG areas is progressing well.

Title: Continuous blackout damages ANGAU genset
Content:
Constant power outages damage electric goods, especially the power surges that occur when electricity is restored.
This was the case with the standby generators at the ANGAU Memorial Provincial Hospital, in Lae.
The ANGAU Memorial Provincial Hospital has come under scrutiny after the death of five patients on October 19, 2025, when the city experienced another blackout and the standby generator failed to kick in.
Chief Executive Officer of the Morobe Provincial Health Authority, Dr Kipas Binga, outlined that it was a “mechanical issue” that has proven to be a major challenge for the hospital’s operation due to the frequent blackouts that are being faced not only in Morobe, but nationwide.
He explained that ANGAU hospital currently has two systems of power; PNG Power Ltd as the main source of power and a standby generator, known as the central energy plant.
“Unlike in the past, in the old ANGAU, we used to have little generators that looked after different sections but as part of this redevelopment, the whole of the power – especially to the new buildings and most of ANGAU – is channelled through what we call the central energy plant,” Dr Binga explained to Lae media.
“The power for the hospital, when it takes on a full load, will take about 800-850 kilo-volt-ampere (kVA). We’ve got three big generators at the back. One generator is about 1,000kVA so with three gensets, we have about 3,000kVA that is available for the hospital.
“The idea is for one to kick in when the power goes off, and it’s synchronised. When one goes off, another one comes on.
“Our main problem was, because of the switch on, switch off – regular on and off of PNG Power – the breaker kept closing in and going out and eventually, it led to mechanical wear and tear.”
Dr Binga said because a component was fried, it failed to detect the power outage that occurred around 10pm on Saturday October 18, 2025.
A technical team that was on site identified the issue with the breaker and because it was a high-voltage area, contractors had to be called in. Dr Binga said work started on Sunday morning, and took approximately 20 hours to resolve the issue.
“What we are doing now is, we are running the hospital on generators and fuel is a big, big concern for us now,” he continued.
“The generators are chewing about 4,000-5,000 litres in 24 hours. That’s a lot of money and we are struggling to find money to sustain our services while we try to sort out the issue with the breaker.
“The breaker, unfortunately, cannot be sourced locally, according to our technical team. It has to be sourced outside. We are thankful to DFAT and our other partners who have come on board to try and see how we can get the parts in.”

Title: 22 Dead in Wapenamanda Landslide Tragedy
Content:
The Enga Provincial Administration has reported that at least 22 people have been confirmed dead following a massive landslide that struck near Kukas village in the Wapenamanda District, Enga Province, overnight after hours of torrential rain fall.
The deadly landslide occurred late last night, burying several homes and families under debris. Villagers have been tirelessly digging through the rubble since dawn in desperate attempts to recover the bodies of their loved ones. The discovery effort in ongoing.
Police personnel, members of the PNG Defense Force along with the Enga Provincial Disaster Office continue with rescue efforts and logistical and security support.
Officials from the Enga Provincial Disaster Office are at Kukas, coordinating search and rescue operations.
They described the situation as catastrophic, warning that the death toll may rise as search continues. Rescue teams are expected to remain on-site over the coming days to recover more victims and support displaced families.
Peter Sambe, Ward Councilor of neighboring Yakandis village, said the event was cruel and heartbreaking.
“We tried our best and managed to rescue two survivors during the early hours of the landslide,” Sambe said. “Our people are prepared to assist the government in the ongoing rescue operations and to help resettle the devastated families of Kukas village.”
Sambe appealed to the Enga Provincial Government for immediate medical assistance and relief supplies, noting that many survivors have lost their homes and belongings.

Title: BCFW Demands Wage Enforcement
Content:
The Business Coalition for Women (BCFW) is calling on the Department of Treasury to ensure that the newly announced K5.00 national minimum wage—set to take effect on January 1, 2026—is backed by strong enforcement mechanisms and adequate funding.
While the government’s decision to raise the minimum wage from K3.50 to K5.00 per hour has been praised as a bold step toward economic equity, the BCFW warns that without proper enforcement, the policy risks being ineffective.
BCFW Executive Director Evonne Kennedy stressed, “A law without enforcement is merely a suggestion.”
She said widespread reports reveal that some employers already fail to comply with the current rate, fueling a “grey economy” where workers remain underpaid.
In its 2026 National Budget submission, BCFW urged the Treasury to prioritise funding for the Department of Labour and Industrial Relations to develop and maintain a robust reporting and compliance mechanism for wage violations.
“This investment will not only safeguard workers from exploitation but will also ensure fair competition for law-abiding businesses,” Kennedy said, adding that a well-resourced enforcement system is crucial to maintaining the integrity of PNG’s labour market and supporting inclusive economic growth.
The coalition’s call serves as a reminder that raising wages must go hand-in-hand with accountability, ensuring that every Papua New Guinean worker benefits from fair and lawful pay.

Title: Grieving family petitions authorities
Content:
The relatives of the late 62-year-old Aiwa Ape from Bokapai village, Koinambe LLG of Jiwaka Province, have visited the Central Provincial Police headquarters and aired their grievances regarding why their father, who went missing on October 3 and was later found dead on October 14 at Brown River.
The family said they received little support from Central leaders. In a petition, the family of the deceased raised concerns that their father, who was conducting his normal business, was kidnapped, murdered, and had his vehicle taken away from him. They stated that the old man was unfortunate to lose his life and property, and that the vehicle driven to Brown River was not returned because some parts are missing.
"This shows how disrespectful these people are, and the family demands a good explanation from the community leaders, including the national leaders. The vehicle had been in the village for days, and no one bothered to report it to the police until the police, after seeing a Facebook post, went and recovered the vehicle. After that, they found the body of my father and arrested five suspects, which we are happy about with the police.
“We demand the leaders whose people did this to our father to come address us on how best we can deal with the body of our late father. We were not prepared for his death, and we cannot do much to take his body to Jiwaka," Hilary Aiwa, the son of the late Ape, said.
He added that the police, the Governor of Central, Kairuku, and Hiri Koiari MP must come forward and say something about what their people did to their father. He stated that the family now demands One Million Kina from the people who brutally murdered him and also requests that his car be returned to the family within five working days, starting yesterday, Wednesday, October 29.
Central Provincial Police Commander Superintendent Joseph Salle, when responding to the family’s grievances, accepted their petition. He said the police are doing their best to ensure justice is served.
Supt Salle further added that the family must work closely with the police and must not disturb the witnesses, who are assisting the police with the ongoing investigation.

Title: New CEO Promises Discipline Drive
Content:
In a decisive leadership change for the Sinasina-Yonggomugl District of Simbu Province, local MP Kerenga Kua officially installed Jack Atte Kerenga Kapa as the new Acting District Chief Executive Officer, replacing Obert Waura, who was terminated for breaching the Public Service Management Act.
The handover ceremony was held yesterday at the MP’s residence on Ega Street in Kundiawa, where Mr. Waura formally handed over the office keys and district vehicle keys to his successor. The change marks a new chapter for the district administration, emphasizing accountability and adherence to public service ethics.
According to the Simbu Provincial Administration’s Human Resource Division, Mr. Waura’s termination followed disciplinary offences under Section 15.19 of the Public Service Management Act, which outlines penalties for misconduct by public officers.
Speaking at the event, MP Kua urged public servants to maintain professionalism and unity for effective service delivery.
“Public service is about discipline and teamwork,” he said. “We must work together with honesty and respect for the law to deliver to our people.”
Deputy Provincial Administrator for Field Services, Chris Mondo, echoed the call, reminding all officers that their roles are bound by the law.
“We are servants of the people,” Mr. Mondo stated. “The Public Service Act covers us all, and it is our duty to uphold its standards.”
The appointment of Mr. Kapa, a former deputy principal of Muaina Secondary School, has been welcomed as a move toward stronger administration and improved service delivery in the district.
Residents expressed optimism that the new leadership would restore discipline, transparency, and community trust in the local government system.

Title: GBV Gaining Stronger Access to Justice
Content:
Survivors of gender-based violence (GBV) are gaining access to justice, thanks to the Regina Sagu Foundation’s expanding legal aid program.
The foundation reported securing 36 protection orders over the past two years, despite facing resistance from powerful perpetrators.
This was highlighted during the Australian Broadcasting Corporation International Development Papua New Guinea Media Development Initiative (ABCID PNG–MDI) Networking and Learning Engagement Event, held on October 24 in Port Moresby.
Themed Safe Spaces, Strong Voices, the event brought together media professionals and civil society organizations working to address violence, reintegration, and community healing.
Presenting on behalf of the Regina Sagu Foundation, Program Officer Tommy Aiyok shared that in 2024, the foundation secured 19 interim protection orders (IPOs), one permanent protection order (PPO), and supported five pending cases. In 2025, the team has so far obtained 11 IPOs and two PPOs, with five more cases underway. Six women have also received legal support through outreach.
“These are not just numbers,” Aiyok said. “Some perpetrators are very powerful. They try to overrun the victims, but our lawyers have stood firm.”
The foundation emphasized the need for stronger collaboration with community-based organizations (CBOs). While CBOs excel at case management, many lack the capacity to represent survivors in court. “We can go to court. They can manage cases. Together, we can prevent GBV,” Aiyok added.
Currently operating in Port Moresby, the Regina Sagu Foundation plans to expand its pro bono legal services to Enga Province and Telefomin in Sandaun. Key partners include Emunah Law Firm, Wantok Tok Radio Light, and Wabag Women’s SME Association, Mi Bank, and Centre for Excellence in Financial Inclusion.
Aiyok also stressed the importance of awareness-building, especially among educators. “Many teachers didn’t understand the purpose of protection orders until we ran workshops. Now they see the impact.”
Although the Department of Justice and Attorney General were not present at the event, the Regina Sagu Foundation’s message was clear: legal aid must be accessible, survivor-centered, and community-driven.
Judge Regina Sagu was a trailblazer in Papua New Guinea’s legal sector, known for her commitment to justice and protection for vulnerable groups. Her legacy lives on through the Regina Sagu Foundation, which provides pro bono legal services, community outreach, and advocacy for GBV survivors across the country.

Title: Parliament passes University of Medicine Bill
Content:
The National Parliament today passed the Papua New Guinea University of Medicine and Health Sciences Bill 2025 by an absolute majority of 76 votes to nil.
This legislation will establish the country’s first dedicated medical university, a major reform in PNG's national education and health system.
Prime Minister James Marape, when welcoming the absolute vote on the Bill by Members of Parliament, stated: “Today, we make history; We have now passed a law that secures our country’s medical future. This university will stand as a testament to our commitment to education, health, and service to our people.”
The Prime Minister has assured the nation that the government will ensure the standalone medical university is properly funded, equipped, and staffed to the highest standard.
The new university, which is expected to be fully operational by 2030, will take over the functions currently managed under the University of Papua New Guinea’s School of Medicine and Health Sciences.
It will focus on producing highly trained doctors, health specialists, and technical professionals to meet the growing health care needs of our country and the region.
Prime Minister James Marape commended the Minister for Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology, Kinoka Feo, and his predecessors for their effort in bringing the vision to fruition.
“There is no greater investment than investing in doctors, laboratory technicians, and the health infrastructure of our nation,” the Prime Minister stated.
“Papua New Guinea has faced many challenges in the health sector. At one point during the COVID-19 pandemic, our country of almost 10 million people had only 44 oxygen-ventilated beds and a doctor-to-patient ratio of roughly one to twenty thousand.
This new institution is a structural readjustment that will help bridge that gap.”
He thanked the University of Papua New Guinea’s leadership under Chancellor Sir Robert Igara for their support in the transition process.
Marape highlighted that the establishment of the medical university would link existing health training institutions, such as nursing colleges and community health worker schools, while creating a clear pathway for developing and nurturing medical professionals.
“Our country is known for producing some of the Pacific’s most qualified medical workers,” he said.
“This university will strengthen that reputation. It will train, equip, and skill more health workers to serve our people and reduce the need for citizens to seek costly medical treatment overseas.”
Marape noted that the country’s growing medical achievements, citing the nation’s first successful kidney transplant and heart bypass operations in recent years, have already saved over a thousand patients from travelling abroad for treatment.
He also commended the academic leadership and staff of the medical faculty for their dedication. The PM called on the Public Service and Higher Education ministry to ensure lecturers and trainers are well compensated.
Meantime, Prime Minister Marape announced that the new university is open for students from other Pacific Island nations, in promoting regional cooperation and solidarity.

Title: RPNGC hosts Pinktober
Content:
Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary Human Resource Division spearheaded the Pinktober fundraiser at the Boroko Police Station yesterday, in an effort to fight against cancer by raising funds for the PNG Cancer Foundation and the Cancer Ward of Port Moresby General Hospital.
Police women, from the NCD/Central command marched from the four-mile traffic office carpark to Boroko Police Station in a show of support and solidarity for the fight against cancer through the RPNGC Pinktober initiative. They hosted a barbeque at the station and all proceeds go towards supporting programs that are addressing cancer in the country.
Last year, the Constabulary raised over K90,000, mostly from donations coming from generous individuals and corporate entities in NCD and Central Province. This year, they aim to raise more than that.
Spokesperson, Chief Inspector David Terry said, the RPNGC is also leading the fight against cancer, which has also affected members of the police force, mainly police women.
“Pinktober is an international event hosted in various countries in the world to support the fight against breast cancer,” Terry said. “The RPNGC HR division hosted the event to commemorate and pay tribute to most of our police women who fight against breast cancer, including other forms of cancer as well.”
“We aim to raise more than we did last year, but it depends on the turnout of the people.”
In a statement, Deputy Commissioner and Chief of Police Administration, Dr. Philip Mitna, appealed to NCD residents and corporate entities to support this worthy cause.
He said anyone in society can one day fall victim to cancer and that the PinkTober initiative is uniting people in the fight against this killer disease.

Title: Three arrested for disturbing polling
Content:
Police in Central Province have arrested a male council candidate and two men for destroying ballot papers at a polling place at Vanapa Brown LLG in Hiri Koiari District of Central Province today.
Acting Assistant Commissioner of Police NCD/Central Benjamin Turi confirmed that their trio will be charged under the Election Offences Act.
The suspects are now detained at the 15 Mile Police Station and will appear in court when the files are ready.
ACP Turi, who witnessed the arrest, said the LLG Election 2025 in Central had been going well throughout the province, despite the arrest.
"We had received positive results from all the districts, with more than five ward councilors declared. Police officers are doing their normal policing duties and are observing the polling booths at their respective locations. I want to thank the people of Central for the past three days of peaceful polling," he said.
While acknowledging the good work of both the police and the public, ACP Turi also called on those who are traveling into the province to witness the polling and counting not to disturb the peaceful election process.
"Let the people elect their leaders independently, with the trust they have for the leaders to whom they will cast their vote."
He stated that police units from both NCD and Central are monitoring their communication mediums and will not hesitate to arrest those who disturb the LLG election.

Title: Visa medical services for scheme workers
Content:
Papua New Guineans participating in the Pacific Australia Labor Mobility Scheme and the Recognized Seasonal Employers Scheme in New Zealand can now access affordable Visa medical services.
This will be achieved under the Memorandum of Understanding signed on Tuesday, October 28, 2025, between the PNG Labor Mobility Unit and the Pacific International Hospital.
This MoU will be valid for two years, with joint review every six months to assess performance.
The PNG Labor Mobility Unit has partnered with Pacific International Hospital to improve the efficiency of Visa medical services for PNG workers. The partnership will improve PNG's labor mobility process and ensure that workers have access to Visa medicals at a lower cost.
Director of PNG Labor Mobility Unit Hakaua Harry said the partnership represents a practical step towards empowering PNG citizens with the medical support they need to access job opportunities abroad.
Pacific International Hospital chief executive officer, Sandeep Shaligram, when appreciating the partnership, emphasized the importance of the MoU.
“We are proud to support PNG’s Labor Mobility initiatives by offering timely, affordable medical services. This partnership,” Shalgiram said. “This partnership will reduce costs and improve service efficiency, helping more Papua New Guineans access overseas employment opportunities.”
Under the arrangement, PIH will provide a discount on Visa medical packages, offer services through multiple centers, and deliver dedicated medical support through accredited panel doctors.
These Visa medical services will be available at PIH branches in Port Moresby, Mt. Hagen, Lae, Kokopo, and Goroka. Those registered will have their medical checks in their region or province.
Through this collaboration, PIH will have the capacity to conduct over 60 visa medicals per day across its network and can scale up operations during peak recruitment drives or large deployment periods.
The PIH will also provide special prescreening services to help identify potential health issues early, supporting better Visa assessment rates and worker readiness.

Title: A grieving family’s search for answers
Content:
A 20-year-old young man, filled with hope and a sense of purpose, bid his family farewell as he excitedly packed his bags and travelled to another province to continue the next chapter of his education.
Being the eldest son, he was the first to leave the nest despite his mother’s anxious pleas for him to enrol in an institution near home, in Port Moresby.
The family’s celebration of a milestone soon turned to shock and horror when the body of their son and brother, Malachi Jude Kalupio, was found in his room at the Bulolo Forestry College, in Morobe Province.
“He attended La Salle Technical Secondary School last year,” said late Malachi’s mother, Victoria Kalupio. “He was one of the pioneer Grade 12 students there, taking all science courses.
“His interest was food technology but because of his Grade Point Average, he was offered space at the Bulolo Forestry College.
“I was really against it at first,” she shared. “I was not comfortable having him leave home, being away from me because he’s the first born and he’s never been away from me and the family.”
The late Malachi was initially offered a merit-based scholarship from the Datec Learning Centre. While he was in the process of registering there, he received another offer from the Bulolo-based college.
“Even though I was against it, I cannot stop him from achieving his dreams. So, I just let him go, hoping that he’d be safe,” shared his mother.
“That was in late January 2025. I took him to Lae with my parents to leave him on campus.”
Kalupio shared that while they all had arrived at the Nadzab Tomodachi International Airport, her son opted to get on the college bus instead of continuing the journey up the Bulolo Highway with his mother and grandparents.
They were sad but happy to see that he was looking forward to starting a new chapter in a new environment and with new friends.
Seven months into college and Ms. Kalupio received a call from an unregistered mobile number.
“It was on September 18th when I got the call at 8.46am. A female student called and said: ‘Oh, it’s about your son, Malachi. He was put on a mattress, covered up and they took him out’.
“I said ‘no no no, you have to check properly. How was he covered up?’ She said wait. When I hung up, I called my son’s phone but it kept ringing out. I called one of the students there but he did not pick up the call.
“Later at 8.53am, his female friend called again and said: ‘Malachi was covered from head to toe. They said it’s suicide.’”
The grief-stricken mother expressed disbelief that her fun-loving son, who had just performed during the school’s Independence celebrations, would take his own life.
She refused to believe her son’s friends.
While minutes ticked into hours, the Kalupio family’s world came to a standstill as they waited on the school administration to contact them.
“It wasn’t until 10am when the administration called and told me that my son had committed suicide,” she continued. “I just snapped at them and said, you don’t tell me my son is suicidal. He’s not! We have no reason to believe that he’s suicidal.”
Kalupio referred to her son’s dancing video that has since gone viral on social media, saying he had sent that to them on September 17, and it showed that he was clearly enjoying himself and having a good time.
“They told me that he had hung himself using an electric jug’s cord but I told them that I had bought his appliances myself and the cord was too small and was not long enough for someone to hang themselves with.”
Kalupio then insisted that they tell her where her son was.
“They told me that they took him to the funeral home so I thought there was a funeral home in Bulolo. I then refused to talk to anyone from the school because I was furious with the way they were handling things. So, my sister and dad were the ones who were in contact with the administration.
“So, on Thursday, September 18th, my sister flew to Lae and they met with the school representatives at the funeral home at 14-Mile. They handed my son’s body over.
“They had taken my son’s body from Bulolo to Lae at 1.30pm that day. However, when we were communicating in the morning, they told me that he was at the funeral home but that wasn’t true. They kept him on campus, washed him and dressed him up. Who gave them the authority to do that? They even had a private viewing of the body. Who authorised that? I did not give my consent.”
The Kalupio family even questioned the initial police report that was furnished by a police officer in Bulolo, believed to be a reservist.
“The manner in which they dealt with the scene was questionable. They tampered with evidence because they said they had to cut the cord.”
The family voiced their disappointment with how the school handled the late Malachi’s case.
While she thanked the school for assisting with her son’s repatriation from Lae to Port Moresby, she expressed concern that the school nurse handed them their late son’s death certificate with the cause of death as “suicide”.
However, after his post-mortem, it was established that the cause of death was “strangulation”.
“The doctor suggested that more than four people were involved in his death.”
Ms. Kalupio flew to Lae and handed a letter, dated October 9th, 2025, to the PNG University of Technology’s vice chancellor, calling for answers and accountability surrounding the death of the late Malachi.
While the university is yet to respond to the family, they have indicated to Lae media that a statement will be furnished soon.
The family has called for the case to be removed from Bulolo police and brought to main headquarters in Lae.
They have also called for a review of the campus’ safety and emergency response protocols, and the implementation of stronger safety and security measures, with Ms. Kalupio highlighting that there are big gaps in the fencing behind the students' dormitory.
“Our family needs closure,” she appealed.
“We need to know what happened to our son.”
The late Malachi is survived by his grandparents, parents, and two younger siblings.

Title: No polling, new wards disputed
Content:
The community of Anglimp Kuli electorate in Jiwaka Province did not conduct the local level government elections due to discrepancies with the establishment of 14 new wards.
Since the establishment of the new wards, the ward councils and leaders have written to the provincial and local level government, the Electoral Commission, and other relevant authorities to explain the last-minute additions (wards) ahead of the LLG elections.
According to Anglimp Kuli spokesman, Jonathan Wii, they have aired their grievances by writing to the concerned authorities, but have not received any good feedback since then. Now, with the LLG elections underway nationwide, the community in Anglimp Kuli is reluctant to vote, as their grievances have not been addressed.
On Tuesday, October 28, a petition was presented during a peaceful protest in Banz. Wii said the petition contained immediate action against the establishment of the wards. It demanded access to the electoral roll 2025 for the new wards created, to see if there are ‘ghost names’ on the electoral roll.
“We did follow due processes to air our grievances, but it was ignored. Now, the people cannot go into polling because of this issue,” he said.
Wii clarified that on March 31, 2025, they lodged a judicial review at the National Court but were denied their rights to a fair hearing, as their matter was not put before a judge to preside.
He said, “Should this issue be addressed, the people will conduct the elections; if not, those responsible must declare their LLG election as failed and conduct a new election next year.”

Title: Over 100 foreign nationals face deportation
Content:
Over 100 foreign nationals are facing deportation after they were apprehended in a joint immigration and police operation in Morobe’s mining districts of Bulolo and Wau-Waria.
Immigration Minister and Lae MP, John Rosso, confirmed that 103 foreign nationals were found working in the alluvial mining sector, a reserved activity for PNG citizens.
They were apprehended and taken to the Lae Top Town police station yesterday (Tuesday, October 28th).
“They were sent to Port Moresby today to be processed, assessed, deported and charged or fined, depending on the type of breaches and laws broken,” said Rosso.
“I continue to take a hard-line stance that foreign nationals in PNG should abide by our laws, and breaches will result in apprehension and deportation.
“Respect our country's laws and regulations.
“Investors and foreign nationals who abide by our laws are welcome and have nothing to worry about.”
Rosso further pointed out to critics that Immigration is working behind the scene to hold to account those in breach of their visa conditions and PNG’s immigration laws.
This is not the first case this year. In June, 11 Chinese nationals were arrested for unauthorised alluvial mining using machinery.
The Chinese nationals were allegedly conducting illegal operations in Wau, where the Wau Mineral Resources Authority branch is located.

Title: Critical failures at ANGAU hospital scrutinized in Parliament
Content:
ANGAU Hospital in Lae City is caring for more Papua New Guineans than expected, is experiencing a shortage of drugs and insufficient manpower to manage the vast medical demands, and also lacks a reliable power supply to perform procedures and treatments.
Kabwum MP, Patrick Basa, in today’s Parliament session raised a question to the Minister for Health, Elias Kapavore, if he was aware that two weeks ago, during a prolonged power blackout in Lae city, seven patients lost their lives at the ANGAU General Hospital.
He queried in Parliament, “If it is the power issue, then why is the standby generator not working to support the important life-saving equipment in operation during the critical moments?”
“If it is an issue of electricity failure, then the minister responsible for energy should also respond and explain why there is no adequate power supply to keep critical life-saving equipment operating in a very important hospital as ANGAU?
“Could it be that the Provincial Health Authority is not performing its role well?” If the deaths are related to insufficient medical supply for treatment, then you must tell us why seven people must die during the same period of blackout.”
MP Basa said it seems like the provincial health authority is not controlling the supply of medicine properly and directing it into the rural areas of Morobe. Therefore, he said many people are dying in the districts, but the exact numbers are not being revealed.
In response, Minister Kapavore said as of October 22, from the operational funds, K569 million was released to all PHAs this year, and today, releasing about K347 million, Morobe, the PHA received about 68 per cent out of all PHAs.
Kapavore stated that in terms of medical supplies, for Morobe province and ANGAU, all have been delivered to Area Medical Stores last week.
“Now the onus is on the primary health care health facilities to put their order for medical drugs to the Area Medical Stores. It should also be noted that the Area Medical Store in Lae was burnt down last year, but the government allocated K20 million this year to rebuild the AMS. To date, K15 million has been released, and the tender process is in progress.”

Title: Bulolo Highway critical for connectivity: Basil Jr
Content:
Member for Bulolo Sam Basil Jnr, presented a petition in Parliament today, Wednesday, October 29, 2025, on behalf of the Farmers and Settlers Association in his electorate and other adjoining districts on the critical condition of the Bulolo Highway.
Basil Jnr presented the petition in collaboration with other key industry bodies, including the Poultry Association, Lae Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and Papua New Guinea Mines and Petroleum, to seek urgent attention to the deteriorating condition of the Bulolo Highway.
He said the highway is a critical infrastructure treated as a lifeline for a major economic sector such as poultry, forestry, and mining that contribute to Papua New Guinea’s economic development.
The MP added that the highway is also good for the movement of goods and services, within the districts of Huon Gulf, Wau-Waria and Bulolo, and Menyamya, extending connections to remote communities such as Kaintiba, and neighbouring Kerema, Gulf Province and Marawaka in Eastern Highlands Province.
The highway also supports coffee growers, small businesses, and local communities whose livelihoods depend on reliable access to markets and services.
Basil Jnr stressed that the current state of disrepair and lack of consistent maintenance has raised serious concerns among the stakeholders, threatening economic activity and public safety, and regional development.
He requested for privatisation of the rehabilitation and maintenance of the Bulolo Highway to ensure continued growth and connectivity for the people and industries that rely on it.
The petition requests;
•	Immediate assessment of the current condition of the Bulolo Highway by the Department of Works and Highways
•	Allocation of emergency funding to ensure critical, safe, and reliable access
•	Development of a long-term maintenance strategy in consultation with industry stakeholders and affected communities, and
•	 Consider a public-private partnership to support infrastructure sustainability.
Basil Jnr said the Bulolo Highway is a strategic asset for Papua New Guinea’s economy and social development, so addressing its current state is not only a matter of infrastructure but of national interest; and prompt action will safeguard livelihood, support industry goals, and reinforce regional connectivity.

Title: Australia Backs PNG Dance
Content:
The Australian High Commission has proudly supported the PNG National Dance Championships, presenting the inaugural Faia Haus Moni Moves award to the best male and female performers.
The championships, held on October 26, were preceded by an international dance workshop featuring Australia’s Bloodline dance group and mentor JAH, who worked closely with local dancers in Port Moresby.
Australian High Commission Minister Counsellor, Liz Le Bas, said the initiative was part of the Yumi Stap Wantaim campaign, celebrating PNG’s 50th independence anniversary, and facilitated through the Australia now: PNG Edition cultural diplomacy program.
Liz Le Bas stated, “The Australian High Commission was pleased to support the International Dance Clinic and National Dance Championships through the Australia now: PNG Edition cultural diplomacy program. We were also thrilled to present the ‘Faia Haus Moni Moves’ Award which not only recognised the artistry of dance, but the deep cultural connection between Papua New Guinea and Australia.”
The event concluded with a collaborative performance between PNG’s Wan Squad and Bloodline, highlighting the cultural and creative links between the two nations.
Wan Squad’s Creative Director, Pyan Ng, expressed hope that the workshop and championship would inspire the next generation of hip-hop dancers in PNG, emphasising the vibrant cultural exchange between Australia and PNG.

Title: Review of the form and system of government report tabled
Content:
Prime Minister James Marape has presented the final report on the "Review of the Form and System of Government: Election of the Prime Minister by the People" in Parliament today.
This significant document, prepared by the Constitutional and Law Reform Commission (CLRC), examines the current governmental framework in Papua New Guinea and proposes potential reforms regarding the process of electing the Prime Minister.
The report aims to enhance democratic governance by exploring alternative systems for electing the Prime Minister that could lead to greater accountability and representation.
“As I present this Report, I want this House to note that whether you are sitting on the opposition side or the Government side, the Report speaks to all of us as it carries the voice of our people and their concerns and cries of the hardship and challenges they have been facing over the years under the current system of government.
“Papua New Guinea has gone through different phases in trialing various systems of government since Independence. After nearly 50 years of independence, we now have a comprehensive report that sets the direction for the future of this country,” said Marape.
The Prime Minister further emphasized the importance of this review in fostering a more responsive and transparent government to better serve the needs of the citizens.
“This report before the Parliament came about after my government tasked the CLRC to undertake a review or inquiry, to assess the form and system of government and propose necessary recommendations back to the Government.
The review had to be undertaken because important considerations and issues that lingered for nearly 50 years needed addressing, both systematically and structurally.
“Any government of a country will always continue to assess and feel the pulse of the society and see whether it is in fact meeting the goals to achieve its visions.”
As discussions unfold in Parliament, the report is expected to ignite debates about the future direction of the country’s political structure and electoral processes, marking a crucial step towards potential constitutional reforms.
Furthermore, Marape said as a responsible government, his government decided that the country must pause and reflect as it reaches 50 years of existence as a nation and see whether the country is on the right path and doing the right thing to achieve our goals under our national strategies, such as the Medium-Term Development Plans, the Vision 2050, the National Goals and Directive Principles and the Constitution.
The Government, through NEC Decision 395 of 2021, through the Head of State, directed CLRC to undertake this review, looking at the relevant laws such as the National Constitution, Organic Law on provincial and Local-level Government, as well as numerous Acts of Parliament.
The CLRC was to report back to the NEC within 18 months.
Specific and very relevant Terms of Reference were issued to CLRC to consider in this Review.
These TORs are:
1.	Is the form and system of Government suitable for a modern Papua New Guinea, as it moves into its 50th Anniversary? If not, what are the alternatives?
2.	Should the Prime Minister be elected by the people?
3.	Should we have a bicameral Parliament? Who should be elected to the lower and upper houses?
4.	Should we keep the three-tier system of Government? If not, what are the alternatives?
5.	How best should women be represented in Parliament?
6.	What areas of the electoral system (such as the qualifications for election, criteria for nomination, election period, and election disputes) should be improved for a modern Papua New Guinea? And
7.	How best can we improve the political party system?
The TORs were too broad, and therefore, to give a sharp focus, the broad Terms of Reference were rescoped to only four thematic areas, which are:
a)	System of Government - that covers the Three-tier system of Government in PNG;
b)	Parliamentary System — regarding the unicameral and bicameral design of the Legislature;
c)	Head of State —with reference to the British Monarch under Section 82 of the Constitution; and
d)	Election of the Prime Minister — which is about the way the Prime Minister is nominated and elected on the floor of Parliament.
Following the launch of the Review in February 2023, CLRC, together with representatives of sister government agency stakeholders, took the seven Terms of Reference out to the people to gauge their views during the nationwide consultation in all 21 provinces and the Autonomous Region of Bougainville between March and July 2023.
Following detailed analysis of all the information collected in the cause of the nationwide consultation, the literature reviews, comparison with government systems of other countries, and reference to relevant laws, polices, existing frameworks as well as CLRC's two previous reports on Constitutional Directive 1 and 2, CLRC, in its wisdom, was able to come up with a set of best possible recommendations that relate to the seven Terms of References.
The recommendations in CLRC's view are sound, practical and appropriate that best address the issues the Review was intended to address.
The Report provides a total of seven (7) key recommendations with their relevant sub recommendations on fundamental areas of the system of government, covering the Election of the Prime Minister, the three-tier system of government, the parliamentary system, Head of State, the women representation in Parliament, electoral system, and the political party system.
The recommendations are as follows:
I.	Change the current system of government from a Three-tier system to a Two-tier System.
II.	PNG should change its Head of State from a Constitutional Monarchy to a Non-Executive President;
III.	The People of Papua New Guinea must directly elect the Prime Minister through the political party with the greatest number of elected MPs endorsed by that party, and the Head of State must sanction the Leader of that political party as the Prime Minister, with a full term of Government;
IV.	Improving the electoral system and processes for a modern PNG;
V.	Creating more opportunities for women's representation in Parliament through special measures, including reserved seats, nominated seats, and a quota system;
VI.	Improve the political party system; and
VII.	PNG should adopt a bicameral parliamentary system.
Several Terms of References especially the TORs on women representation in Parliament, electoral system, and political party system repeated the TORs CLRC had addressed in the previous Constitutional Directives (Constitutional Directive No. 1 on the Review of the Organic Law on Provincial and Local- level Governments and Constitutional Directive No. 2 on the Review of the Organic Law on National and Local-level Government Elections).

Title: Kapavore clarifies shortage of medical drugs
Content:
Minister for Health Elias Kapavore has admitted that almost K150 million of the K295 million allocated to the National Department of Health in this year's budget has been disbursed, and while the balance is yet to be given, it is affecting the supply of medical drugs in the country.
Kapavore revealed this during today’s Parliament session’s question without notice.
Minister Kapavore was responding to questions raised by the Leader of Opposition and MP for Kiriwina-Goodenough, Douglas Tomuriesa, about the extreme shortage of drugs in the last few weeks across the country, leading to deaths in health facilities.
Tomuriesa referred to queries he received from chief executive officers of various provincial health authorities, stating the critical drug shortage in health care facilities throughout the country.
These concerns cover all provincial hospitals, as well as church agency-run health facilities. Tomuriesa said it is not right for people to be dying from curable diseases.
“Is it a lack of funds that’s causing this lack of drugs in the health facilities, or is it that money meant for health is being redirected to other areas that’s causing this?” Tomuriesa queried.
Kapavore responded that, firstly, it is not a lack of funding, but the delay in disbursing this money; and he commented further that this year the government has allocated K295 million towards medical supplies to the country.
He said that recent information he received, over K150 million of this allocation has been disbursed to the health sector. He also added that last week, another K50 million was released by the government to the health sector.
Kapavore admits that the government is fully aware of the critical situation regarding drug shortages and they are trying their best to ensure that medical supplies are being procured are sent to the provincial medical stores.
Kapavore said curative health directors from hospitals have been notifying the department, and the authorities are fully aware of updated information from CEOs and medical supplies directors.
He admits that five of the area medical stores there are only 60 per cent of what is required now in store, but 40 per cent is lacking; however, on a positive note, a procurement process is underway.
The health minister said there is a plan to reach about 70 per cent to 80 per cent of provincial medical supplies to provincial medical stores by the end of 2025 and the first part of 2026.
Minister Kapavore also noted the variety of challenges that the health sector is facing in the delivery of medical supplies to the area medical stores, such as roadblocks along the national highways, especially in the highlands region.
He appeals to the people on the ground to cooperate and let the trucks carrying medical supplies go through. These challenges include theft of medical supplies that is happening while drugs are on the road.
Kapavore said, despite various challenges, the health department is trying its best to secure medical supplies.

Title: NISIT, Customs sign strategic MoU
Content:
National Institute of Standards & Industrial Technology (NISIT) has signed a historical Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with PNG Customs services on Monday this week.
NISIT, established in 1993 by and ACT of Parliament as ‘NISIT Act 1993’ serves as the legal foundation for the institute, outlining its mandate to oversee technical standards, metrology, conformity assessment, productivity and technical barriers to trade in PNG.
“So far we have a wide network of partnerships with both government and industry to ensure that there is well represented from each sector regarding a standard,” Joe Panga explained.
With the MoU, the Chief Commissioner of Customs Services will now sit on the board of NISIT. This will bring value to their operations by giving them access to industries across the country where the PNG Customs are covering.
The Chief Commissioner of Customs, David Towe said they have collaborated with many other relevant state agencies and private sector but now aligning Customs policies and standards with the NISIT is very strategic.
He sees this partnership between NISIT and Customs would be very strategic in improving compliance and enforcing their regulatory arrangements, as in recent times there have been issues of non -compliance.
He told the NISIT Acting Director General that he would like Customs to engage with NISIT to know they have different standards which they want to be able to use for the Customs laws.
“Once your standard become our standard then once our legal receive is completed,” he said. “We want those standards to be incorporated into our law so that whoever that we issue a license to must be certified by NISIT.”
He said they currently don’t have expertise available to do the accreditation. Partnering with NISIT is very convenient.

Title: Four cops charged with murder
Content:
Four Manus-based police officers and a former Manus-based police officer have been arrested and charged with the murder of their comrade, the late Constable Ralwin Lamu, on May 5, 2021 in Manus.
Assistant Commissioner of Police – Crimes, Hodges Ette said the five individuals appeared in court yesterday, October 27. Their case has been adjourned to January 26, 2026.
According to the police brief, it was alleged that on May 5, 2021, the deceased was on a boat with the five suspects. They were headed towards N'dilau for a job. While on board, the suspects allegedly were seen hitting the deceased with hard objects at different locations near the village.
"From information obtained by police after executing their task, they returned to Manus Police Station,” Ette said. “Before they reached the shore, they found out that Lamu was not talking, so they called for a police vehicle to assist.”
“When they reached the shore, they transported him in a waiting police vehicle to Manus Provincial Hospital. “At the hospital, he was pronounced dead.
“A police complaint was registered, in which my officers went to Manus to carry out the investigation that led to the arrest of the five after four years,” Ette said.
He added that the five were charged with murder and are in custody at Manus Police Station.

Title: Polling commences for LLG elections
Content:
Polling for Local Level Government elections commenced today, Monday October 27, 2025.
“The PNGEC acknowledges the public’s strong interest in timely elections, and remains fully committed to progressing these elections and polling shall commence this week starting Monday 27 October 2027,” said PNG Electoral Commission Simon Sinai said in a media release issued today.
Sinai said the delays were caused by number of factors, including the new proclamations – the creation of new wards and LLGs in the country on the eve of the election – a process managed by the Department of Provincial and Local Government Affairs.
“This has placed extra workload on the provincial electoral staff to identify and create new rolls for the new wards and LLGs through the voter alignment process using the existing rolls,” Sinai explained.
Polling will end on November 8, 2025 and counting begins November 09.
LLG election writs will be returned on Friday November 21, 2025.

Title: Police Lead Strong Drive for Peaceful LLG Elections
Content:
Security forces in Kairuku District are taking center stage as the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) Elections get underway. It launched one of the most comprehensive election security operations in recent years to ensure a safe and transparent democratic process.
LLG Elections in the district kicked off today with Mekeo and Kairuku LLG. Kuni will hold its polling tomorrow, October 27, 2025.
District Election Operations Commander and Bereina Police Station Commander, Sergeant Willie Hoiba, confirmed that 84 police personnel have been deployed across the three LLGs - Mekeo, Kairuku, and Kuni - to maintain peace and order throughout the polling period.
“Our priority is to create a safe and secure environment for both election officials and voters. We want to see polling conducted without fear, intimidation, or interference,” Sgt Hoiba said.
Unlike previous elections where isolated incidents disrupted voting, this year’s operation focuses on strategic placement of officers and closer collaboration between the police, Electoral Commission, and community leaders.
The deployment plan assigns 46 officers to Mekeo, 22 to Kairuku, and 16 to Kuni, with teams already stationed at critical points to deter any potential disturbances.
“We are working closely with the Electoral Commission, local leaders, and community elders to make sure everything runs smoothly. Our officers will be stationed at all critical points to respond quickly to any disturbance,” Sgt Hoiba added.
While security teams work to protect the integrity of the polls, election officials are facing their own challenges in reaching remote communities. The Kairuku LLG Assistant Returning Officer confirmed that eight polling teams have been dispatched to cover 22 wards, including hard-to-reach coastal and inland areas.
“We have prepared well, and our teams are committed to completing their duties responsibly. The people of Kairuku are eager to make their voices heard,” she said.
Community leaders across the district have also called for unity, urging residents to respect polling officials and allow the process to run peacefully.

Title: RPNGC to host PinkTober fundraiser
Content:
The Constabulary's Human Resource Division is again spearheading the October 2025 fundraising activity, aimed at supporting the fight against breast cancer in the country.
The staff from Police headquarters will stage a BBQ at the Boroko Police Station on Wednesday, October 2025, from 10 am onwards to raise funds for the PNG Cancer Foundation and the Cancer Ward of Port Moresby General Hospital.
Deputy Commissioner and Chief of Police Administration, Dr. Philip Mitna, said the theme for this year's awareness campaign is "Together we fight, to save lives through cancer awareness."
Dr Mitna said the purpose of this fundraising activity is to raise money to support the work of the Cancer Foundation and the PNG Cancer Ward at the Port Moresby General Hospital.
DCP Mitna said, apart from breast cancer, the RPNGC recognises the existence of all forms of cancer in the communities and their adverse impact on society.
He said cancer has claimed the lives of many of our citizens over the years, and the RPNGC is no exception, while emphatically stressing the importance of this fundraising drive.
"To commemorate the start of the PinkTober campaign, the policewomen of NCD/Central Command will walk from the 4 Mile Traffic office to the Baroko Police Station in a show of solidarity and strength.
“They are not alone in this campaign because several countries around the world are also staging similar events in their quest to prevent or minimize breast cancer across the world,” DCP Mitna said.
He said last year the Constabulary raised over K90,000, mostly from donations coming from generous individuals and corporate entities in NCD and Central Province.
The Deputy Commissioner again appealed to the residents of NCD, both within the private and public sectors, as well as corporate entities, to support this worthy cause. He said anyone in society can one day fall victim to cancer.
Dr Mitna said the PinkTober initiative is all about uniting people in the fight against cancer. They must help each other to protect and fight against cancer in the community.

Title: One in custody over children’s death
Content:
One person of interest is in police custody following the discovery of the bodies of three children at 9 Mile Cemetery, Hagen Kona Settlement, yesterday.
NCD/Central Assistant Commissioner of Police Benjamin Turi, who visited the crime scene today, said they are also talking to other family members as investigations continue.
According to the crime report, it was alleged that on Friday October 24 2025, between 3pm and 5pm, the three children, all cousins, left their family home and went to fetch water in the same area in which their bodies were later found. They were alleged to have been accompanied by a female guardian. Police believe the children met their fate during this trip.
Police became involved after family members could not locate the three children and reported it to the 9 Mile police station the same day. The search for them ended with the tragic discovery of their bodies two days later.

Title: Smooth LLG polling in Lae
Content:
Polling for the 2025 Local Level Government elections began today in the 16 wards of Lae district, in Morobe Province.
For Ward 2 at Top Town, in the Lae Urban LLG covering the Ward Service Office Area, polling officials, led by presiding officer Timothy Holingu, commenced at 9am, with Holingu expecting a turnout of 500 voters for the area.
Polling started peacefully for Ward Two residents from the streets of Gannet, Falcon, Eagle, Crane, Plover, Swift, Tern, Quail, Hornbill, and especially those near the Huonville Primary School.
Moving to Ahi LLG, Ward Two of West Butibam polled at the Butibam Resource Centre, under the watchful eyes of polling team number 147.
Presiding officer, Basoka Mangheyuc, said matters had to be sorted hence polling started after 8am.
“We expected 1,170 voters; 618 males and 552 females,” said Mangheyuc.
“We had a little bit of a challenge; this is concerning our assistant presiding officer. The scrutineers and candidates asked me to swap and replace her, so we did that. So, our assistant presiding officer was sent to Butibam East, and we had to pull the assistant presiding officer from there to here. We had to swap for the sake of transparency.”
Lae Urban’s Ward Five, at the PNG University of Technology, had two polling venues; the polling venue near the coffee shop was under polling team 227, while the one opposite the uni force office was manned by polling team 228.
Presiding officer of polling team 228, Solomon Bulu, outlined that the only glitch today was the late delivery of polling materials from the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium, hence their two-hour late start at 10am.
“Due to the election being deferred a couple of times, it’s quite tough with us the polling officials,” said Bulu. “Polling officials were selected last minute so we were not prepared for that. So, we had to attend our training for a day at the eleventh hour and we came to the polling site. That was due to things beyond our control.”
Polling team 228 – consisting of seven officials and three law enforcers – is anticipating 1,000 voters for the one-day polling, which is set to close at 6pm.

Title: Admin Professionals Empower Themselves
Content:
The Papua New Guinea Association of Administrative Professionals (PNG AAP) held a one-day professional development workshop at the Mt. Wilhelm Hotel in Kundiawa, Simbu Province, on October 23, 2025, focusing on empowering administrative professionals to adopt modern office practices, develop digital skills, and enhance financial literacy.
The event was attended by PNG AAP President Kenny Supa, Vice President Clara Konia, registered members, and several new members eager to join the association.
The workshop aimed to transform administrative work culture by fostering critical thinking, strategic project planning, event management, protocol diplomacy, and teamwork while helping members adapt to the fast-changing world of artificial intelligence and technology.
Mrs. Supa, who also serves as Assembly Clerk for the Simbu Provincial Government, said the association’s vision is to strengthen the skills and creativity of administrative professionals across Papua New Guinea.
“Our main goal is to improve working skills, enhance creativity, and promote strategic planning. We want to build strong, diplomatic, and confident professionals ready for the future,” Mrs. Supa stated.
Vice President Mrs. Clara Konia, who is also the Simbu Provincial Administration Secretary, emphasized the importance of embracing new knowledge and digital tools in the workplace.
“Programs like this are vital for our members. Learning Wi-Fi systems, Excel, and word processing are essential in today’s offices. It’s about moving forward together with new knowledge,” she said.
Newly registered member Ms. Rose Dama, a Simbu Provincial Community Development Officer, expressed her excitement after attending the workshop.
“It’s inspiring to see how the PNG AAP connects members nationwide and globally through training and professional development. I’m proud to be part of this network,” Ms. Dama shared.
Beyond training, the association also runs a financial platform that helps members invest and access small loans. Mrs. Supa explained that the finance arm of PNG AAP offers two key options:
Long-term investment plans with high-interest returns.
Short-term savings schemes through TISA, available on a one-month, three-month, or six-month basis.
The PNG AAP continues to play a vital role in shaping capable, confident, and forward-looking administrative professionals across Papua New Guinea, ensuring that members are not only skilled in office management but are also financially empowered and ready for the digital future.

Title: LLG processes need reviewing: Sinai
Content:
Electoral Commissioner, Simon Sinai has raised concerns that the Local Level Government processes need reviewing so that the legal requirements for creating new wards and LLGs are strictly managed and guided by law and implemented within a fixed timeline.
Sinai said one of the delays and deferral of the LLG elections was being the new proclamations – creation of new wards and LLGs in the country on the eve of the election, a process managed by the Department of Provincial and Local Government Affairs.
“This has placed extra workload on the provincial electoral staff to identify and create new rolls for the new wards and LLGs through the voter alignment process using the existing rolls.”
“As such it is imperative that the administrative and technical issues identified herein be fully addressed in order to guarantee the special rights of eligible citizens under Section 50 of the Constitution, namely the right to vote and stand for public office.
“These are legal issues that needs to be handled with care. Such as identifying a voter for the new ward and creating a new roll.
“Once you have separated the voters according to the new wards from the existing rolls, you then take into account new voters who are not on the roll but turned 18 and are eligible to vote.
“The 2022 Electoral Roll can be used as the base to update the rolls, but if any person who is not happy must object to the enrollment which is provided for under Section 48 of the Organic Law on National and Local Government Election,” he said.
He said the PNG Electoral Commission is committed to upholding the highest standards of electoral integrity and ensuring that elections are free, fair and credible.
“It also recognizes the importance of LLG elections to strengthen grassroots democracy and inclusive representation.
Mr Sinai said the Electoral Commission by law is required to prepare the Electoral Rolls six (6) months before the anniversary of the next election, may it be National General Election or Local Level Government election.
“Due to staff shortage, PNGEC gets support from LLG public servants and the provincial administrations to assist with the roll updates in the provinces.
“This is why the Electoral Commission is embarking on all of society approach to fixing the roll issue using a photo to the name.
“We are asking the National Government, provincial administrations, Local Level Governments, Wards and citizens to help identify the voters and prepare a biometric electoral roll for the good of the elections,” he said.

Title: K56b spent on districts
Content:
Prime Minister James Marape recently highlighted that over K56 billion in public funds has been allocated across Papua New Guinea in the past six years.
During the launch of the Reset PNG@50 blueprint at the University of Papua New Guinea, he urged government agencies, provincial administrations, districts, and public institutions to deliver tangible outcomes from these investments.
Marape explained that this significant amount represents total funding distributed by his administration since 2019, covering a range of sectors including provincial and district governance, health authorities, and educational institutions such as universities and colleges.
“That is not a small sum. Every leader, administrator, and public servant must ask: what have we done with it?”
He said the amount represented the government’s commitment to decentralising service delivery and ensuring every level of government had access to resources.
“But I ask again — what has been achieved? Where are the results? The money is being released, but are we seeing improvement in schools, hospitals, and roads?” he said.
He revealed that recent administrative reviews had uncovered serious gaps in financial reporting and compliance, including agencies and authorities that failed to submit expenditure reports for several years.
He shared a recent example involving a senior official whose contract renewal he was forced to reject after discovering a five-year failure to provide expenditure reports.
“I had to cast a deciding vote against his reappointment,” he said.
The Prime Minister reiterated that the government will no longer tolerate poor financial management.

Title: NMCA to probe government spending
Content:
Prime Minister James Marape has announced the establishment of the National Monitoring and Coordination Authority as part of ongoing efforts to enhance value for money in government spending.
This initiative was unveiled during the launch of the Reset PNG@50 blueprint at the University of Papua New Guinea.
The new authority will be tasked with overseeing project implementation and monitoring expenditure, ensuring that public funds are utilized effectively and transparently.
In his address, Marape emphasized the importance of financial discipline and accountability, calling on provincial administrators, district development authorities, and departmental heads to adhere to these principles.
“This new authority will check where the money goes, what it delivers, and whether it benefits the people,” the prime minister said.
“Money must move from paper to the ground (an) if it doesn’t reach the people, then it has failed its purpo
se.”
Marape reminded leaders and officials that their positions are a privilege, not an entitlement.
“If a minister or superior asks you to do something against the law, stand for what is right,” he said.
“The country’s laws come first — not politics, not personalities,” he said.

Title: PHA Sets Leadership Benchmark
Content:
A smooth handover of leadership took place today at the West New Britain Provincial Health Authority (WNB PHA) as outgoing Chief Executive Officer Stanis Tao formally passed the baton to incoming Acting CEO Dr Joseph Nale.
The ceremony, facilitated by Board Chair Steven Raphael and witnessed by board members and staff, marks a purposeful step in ensuring continuity in health leadership for the province.
Mr Raphael thanked Mr Tao for his dedicated leadership and the many services rendered to the people of West New Britain. He then welcomed Dr Nale, expressing full confidence in his capacity to steer the authority over the next three months, as a recruitment process is underway for a permanent CEO.
Legal Counsel for the National Department of Health (NDOH), Margareth Sinimbi, praised the WNB PHA for its “smooth transition”, noting that many comparable health authorities across the country struggle with change-overs.
In his remarks, Mr Tao thanked the WNB PHA team for their dedication and tireless service, and urged them to embrace Dr Nale’s leadership and work cooperatively during the treatment of the interim period.
With this handover complete, the authority now looks ahead to a three-month interim before a permanent appointment is made, assuring health staff and the public of no interruption to services.

Title: PNG commits to global peace and development
Content:
The Papua New Guinea Government has committed to global peace and development on United Nations Day in Port Moresby.
Minister for Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs, Soroi Eoe, speaking on behalf of Prime Minister James Marape, said PNG’s modern nationhood was deeply linked to the United Nations, from its early years under the UN Trusteeship system to its admission as the UN’s 143rd member on 16 September 1975.
“When our flag was raised, the United Nations did not merely recognise Papua New Guinea — it welcomed us home,” he said. “That moment affirmed our place within a family committed to peace, justice, and human dignity.”
He noted that Papua New Guinea’s cultural and linguistic diversity mirrored the UN’s global mission of unity through diversity. “Like the UN, we are a nation of hundreds of languages and cultures, yet united under one flag,” he said.
Minister Eoe outlined how, over the past five decades, Papua New Guinea had exercised principled leadership at the UN, especially on issues that directly affect its people.
“We speak for communities on the frontline of climate change,” he said. “We advocate for sustainable oceans, forest stewardship, and financing models that reward countries protecting the lungs and blue carbon sinks of the planet.”
He said these positions were rooted in the daily realities of Papua New Guineans — from the Highlands to the Sepik, and from the Bismarck to the Coral Sea.
Minister Eoe highlighted the strength of the partnership between Papua New Guinea and the UN across key areas such as climate-resilient infrastructure, clean energy, and job-creating agriculture.
“When droughts, landslides, and health emergencies struck, the UN stood with us — from vaccination campaigns to emergency relief and reconstruction. This is multilateralism in action: a hand extended when it matters most,” he said.
He also paid tribute to the UN’s role in peacebuilding efforts in Bougainville, acknowledging its contribution from ceasefire monitoring to post-referendum dialogue.
Minister Eoe said the recent visit of UN Secretary-General António Guterres — the first by a sitting UN chief — was a defining moment in PNG-UN relations.
“His visit reflected the UN’s confidence in our leadership in the Pacific,” he said. “He met Prime Minister Marape, addressed our National Parliament, and visited Wewak, Nuku, and Mt Hagen, witnessing the resilience and hope of our people.”
He noted that Prime Minister Marape’s address to the 80th Session of the UN General Assembly in New York underscored PNG’s leadership in global advocacy.
“Prime Minister Marape reaffirmed our commitment to the UN Charter and called for reforms to the global financial system to value forests, oceans, and climate resilience as global public goods,” Minister Eoe said. “Papua New Guinea will not be a bystander — we will be a solutions country.”
Minister Eoe said PNG supported reforms to make the UN “more representative and responsive” to today’s global challenges, including geopolitical tensions, food insecurity, and climate impacts.
He thanked the UN Country Team for its work with PNG’s government, churches, youth, and women’s groups, saying the partnership’s impact was “measured not in reports but in results — in the vaccinated child, the safe school, the functioning health post, and the peaceful community.”

Title: LDC Taps Local Expertise for Asset Valuation
Content:
The Livestock Development Corporation (LDC) is charting a bold investment path for Papua New Guinea’s livestock industry through a nationwide asset valuation project that is set to redefine how its public assets are leveraged for economic growth.
